Together, Gastonish and Xonox thought about a suitable location to hide the suit-case. For fear of being captured, Gastonish remained inside the summer log-home. Xonox made several trips outside the cabin to examine their surroundings. Finally, they found there was a wood shed, out house, storage shed and a deep water supply well, all in close proximity to the small log cabin.
Gastonish tried to look at her situation and see the big picture. As she continued to put her thoughts in order and find the options which were available to her, Gastonish felt the unceasing weight of her emotions coming over her. Nevertheless, she continued to arrange and rearrange and resolve her volk thoughts. Against her will, Gastonish continued to go back to thoughts about the loss of her husband, Mulunac. She knew her time was limited. By morning the creatures of this planet were sure to find her. The night was the only way to leave the cabin without a chance of being spotted from the air. So, while Gastonish was organizing her thoughts and fighting the annoying effects of the illness, she was waiting for the night to come.

Rich gold colors from the yellow sun marked the end of the day. When night fell, and darkness came upon the land, Gastonish crept out of the cabin with her suit-case as her intension was to hide it.
The volk mind of Gastonish began to pick up an intelligent telepathic frequency. At first, Gastonish felt relieved as she thought she was connecting to the minds of other volks like her. Running out of the cabin, Gastonish looked to the night sky. There she saw many brilliant lights flashing and moving about in a zig zag fashion.
It was not long before Gastonish realized the dancing lights in the sky were not volks. Such erratic flight patterns could not possibly be volk. The strange beings in the star lit sky had honed in on Gastonish's brainwaves, much like transmittable broadcast radio waves.
The thought waves were rude in nature as they pried into her mind to probe to unlock secrets. Such a method would result in great pain to a human's mind, but a volk was more capable telepathically than the strange minds attempting to torment her. The lights moving about in the stratosphere were asking Gastonish a question, 'Where did you come from? Please open your mind to us so we can communicate with you.'
Able to close off access to the telepathic probings of the creatures with ease, Gastonish decided to respond. 'Come down here to me and we can speak.'
The moment Gastonish sent the telepathic response, the lights in the sky came down low and hovered slowly over the property of the hunter's cabin. Upon seeing the bright colors of the flashing lights up close, Gastonish recognized she was not familiar with the alien space crafts. The smooth shiny surface of the space crafts were like that of a vorogon to her, but Gastonish had never seen Vornocks quite like these before. As curious as she was to know why a sophisticated creature like these had not already encountered her kind at some point in the past, Gastonish, with her suit-case still in hand, activated it and the suit-case interchanged slightly.
Under the flashing lights of the alien crafts, Gastonish began to remove her human clothes. As she did so, Gastonish's suit case reached out and coated her exposed body with her intricate volk suit once again. 
When Gastonish was fully dressed in her own glowing skin tight circuitry suit, she found one of the creatures from the space crafts were standing beside her. Moving with a cautious stance, it reached out to feel her clothes.
The creature was grey in color from head to toe. Its limbs were thin as well as its neck and fingers. How it was able to support its unusually large head was very strange. Gastonish thought it was a vornock when she looked at it, but as she beheld the creature more closely in the intense light, she found it was not a vornock, but something else indeed.
The face of the creature was more simple than a vornock, with a smooth round head and large black eyes which contradicted its very small nose, mouth and chin.
Near to the cabin, Gastonish could see one of the space crafts had landed and from a small portal under the craft, a couple other alien creatures came ambling down the ramp with little steps.
Sensing something terrible was about to happen, Gastonish prepared herself by amping up her power. Looking into the minds of the aliens, Gastonish found the aliens had a primitive form of thought process. Realizing the creatures were alien to this particular planet, it became clearer as to how these creatures had primeval minds from a volk's perspective.
The aliens, though very logical and curious, believed themselves superior over all other living beings who they had encountered in their travels. From eons of observing and collecting information at their discretion, the aliens had not only become arrogant, but emotionless as well. They granted themselves their own status. As a race, sharing one mind, they had granted themselves the pristine status of gods. They were not altogether evil or destructive, they simply went about doing what they thought necessary for the sake of their own studies to better their kind. They had no rank among them for as a people of one mind, they all believed themselves to be number one for no other creature they knew could contend with their brilliance and power... Until now.
Fear was another emotion the aliens hadn't had much experience with, but Gastonish was a creature unknown to them and they feared the unknown. The alien, nearest to Gastonish, lifted a small object which it suddenly possessed in its thin long fingers. It quickly moved the object to touch it to Gastonish's head but Gastonish moved so fast, she seemed to be outside of real time. Spinning, she confiscated the object and used it against the alien creature by tapping the alien object to the alien's own head. The alien's body stiffened and fell backwards to the ground with a deathly thud.
The other two aliens ran at Gastonish as she was suddenly engulfed in light. The light came from an over head space craft and the power in the light was like matter which held Gastonish with enough strength she was unable to fight it. Becoming concerned for her pregnancy, Gastonish needed to resolve the situation right away.
'Xonox, as thrustle-T you are under obligation to protect me.' Gastonish spoke to her sertz telepathically. Instantly, her tiny robotic guardian flew out from her ear and shot tiny colored beads of light energy at the source of the beam holding her.
The source emitting the light of matter from the space craft underwent considerable damage before going out. When Gastonish was free from the light, she did not fall to the ground. With the power of her own pink glowing volk suit, Gastonish remained floating in air like a celestial being.
Xonox engaged a telepathic projection into the alien's minds. The projection was one of dominance and anger with a level the aliens had never experienced before. The strain of mind put the aliens in shock from their own escalating fears.
Gastonish became aware of a danger which was soon to happen. While the aliens prepared to attack her, Gastonish prepared a defense of her own. Removing her hickoop disk, Gastonish began to unfold it.
As the disk shaped space crafts began moving out to escape Gastonish, one of the crafts retaliated by blasting Gastonish with a searing heat ray. Gastonish had already powered up the protective field of her hickoop which protected her from the deadly radioactive blast of heat.
Driving her hickoop, Gastonish flew upwards, high into the night sky. Though the aliens feared her, they kept their distance and followed her. Because they did not understand her the aliens could not just let her go. Hundreds of miles from earth's orbit, Gastonish brought her hickoop to a stop.
The alien saucer shaped space crafts surrounded Gastonish, careful to safeguard themselves with ample distance. Knowing the aliens were more observers of the planet and not socially integrated, Gastonish wanted to be sure they did not get in her way while she set out to fit in with the non-telepath prevalent humans of the planet.
Gastonish hit the minds of the aliens with a sophisticated form of telepathy with a message attached to it. The telepathy was saturated with a powerfully dreadful feeling which was both mysterious and spooky for the creatures. With this they received a message; 'Stay away from earth or your minds will be wiped clean throughout the galaxies.'
The aliens left the planet earth and returned to their home world with the memory of the message which they would communicate to their kind. The aliens deliberated on this message, but they also obeyed it as long as Gastonish's telepathic mind could be sensed.
Gastonish lingered outside of the earth for a while where she waited to be sure the aliens truly did obey her. Peering deep into space she wondered if any volks were out there and if they could at all sense her.
When Gastonish returned to the hunter's cabin, she reformed her volk suit to its compact form and dressed into the human clothes again. Using Xonox to lead her, she made her way to the well. Stumbling and tripping numerous times on rocks and roots protruding from the path, Gastonish cradled her suit-case in her arms. She previously wrapped the pink glowing suit-case in a blanket and tied it with some twine which she found in a cupboard. At the well, Gastonish had to move a ply wood sheet covering. When she had access to the mouth of the well, Gastonish dropped the concealed circuitry designed suit-case in. There was a count of five seconds before she heard the splash at the bottom of the well. After carefully replacing the ply wood to its original position above the opening of the well, Xonox led Gastonish back toward the cabin.
All Gastonish was wearing were simple beige shorts and a denim shirt which exposed her for who she was, a volk, with greyish blue skin and deep black eyes. Gastonish was hairless with naturally grown shoulder plates of bone. These plates were also found on her forearms and the tops of her feet. The tendons or metacarpals of Gastonishs hands were white and out-set, greatly detailed and obvious. This gave the hands a characteristic of strength. Gastonishs grey skin was a little dry and flaky. She was hungry and thirsty. Unable to identify the cans in the cupboard as a source of food, Gastonish ended up going outside to eat leaves from the trees and drink water from the lake. 
She went out of the cabin periodically to eat and Gastonish nodded off from time to time as well. Next thing she knew, it was morning. The golden glow of a new day came through the crack of the open door and painted across Gastonishs face. The warmth of the sun and the song of the birds woke her from her sleep.
Sitting up quickly believing she had a nightmare, Gastonish quickly realized she hadnt had a nightmare at all, her fears were her reality. Gastonish was still in the strange alien dwelling and her heart was beating harder and faster than usual as though it was going to beat right out of her chest. Listening more carefully, the sound of anxiety wasnt coming from her heart; it was the sound of distant helicopter blades approaching. Gastonish peeked through the slight opening of the door and strained her eyes to see the helicopter in the distance of the morning sky.
The cabin was suddenly a much too obvious hiding place. Gastonish swung open the door and ran outside. With wide quick strides, Gastonish raced along the trail which led around the lake.  The helicopter was much to close for her to continue. She jumped off the path and hid in a bush near the wood shed. The AH-64 Apache military helicopter rose over the trees from a near by hillside and immediately it was right over top of Gastonish. Clearly they knew where she was. The search light blinded her eyes with its intensity and it also lit up her surroundings. With a quick glance she saw the wood shed was the closest place for her. She dashed for it to find cover. 
The Apache helicopter considered her actions to be aggressive. It wasn't until she was out of sight when the helicopter retaliated. They squeezed off a burst from the helicopters main frontal flame thrower at the wood shed and it bursted into light, splinters and fire.

With her eyes opening to a movement of strange shadows, Gastonish perceived but could not decipher between dream and reality. The shadows became beings, but not volks, and the dream became reality, but not a reality Gastonish had ever known before. The beings moved back and forth as though confused and panicking. Searching the minds of the being who surrounded her, Gastonish could not find evil and malice in them. These creatures, she found, wanted to learn more about her. Though the creatures could be moved to violence quickly through fear, they preferred peace so Gastonish did not reflect harm or violence on them. 
Bonds restrained Gastonish's limbs to a bed and needle like devices endlessly probed her body. Gastonish noticed her body, different now but she was unable to determine exactly how different it was. The endless probing was so painful. Bright lights flashed in the tight room. Some penetrating lights would flash directly into Gastonishs eyes causing flash backs of her life. Flash backs of her husband's death. A speech was exchanged between the shadow beings but Gastonish could not understand the words. This made little difference because she could hear their thoughts and knew their meaning. Awake for only a few minutes, before a wave of pain rolled over Gastonish and she helplessly fell enslaved to the reality of dreams again and slept.

Gastonish woke up and fought with passion to stay awake. Hours must have gone by but she felt so fuzzy headed Gastonish was not sure just how much time eluded her. Lifting her head, Gastonish realized just how stiff and sore she was before looking around the room. Eyesight blurred, the room was bright and hazy. Relying on all of her senses, Gastonish noticed she was alone. She wanted to cover her face with her hands in fear, but Gastonish's ankles and wrists were still strapped to the bed bars with leather bindings. A sudden sense of captivity shivered through her body, waking her up to a new reality as a stranger in a strange world. Gastonish found the foreign feeling terrifying. Her entire body was numb, cocooned in bandages, and itchy. The itchy feeling was like a tormenting pain and Gastonish tried to think of just one place on her body where she didn't painfully itch, but she couldn't. She relaxed her hands and tried to scream but Gastonish could not because her throat was too dry and sore from oxygen feeding tubes. Within her mind Gastonish called out to her sertz 'Xonox!'
I AM HERE, ROMULAW, ANCHORED TO YOUR MIND. NO ONE HAS DISCOVERED ME YET, BUT IT BECOMES MORE DIFFICULT TO REMAIN ELUSIVE WHEN THEY KEEP ON COVERING YOUR EARS WITH BANDAGES. AT FIRST I WAS CONSTANTLY ON THE MOVE TRYING TO SABOTAGE THESE BEINGS STRANGE EQUIPMENT. NOW, I REALIZE THEY SINCERELY WANT TO HELP YOU TO GET BETTER AND STAY STRONG. IVE BEEN WORKING YOUR NEURAL SYSTEMS TO HELP YOUR BODY HEAL FASTER. The little synthetic robot paused as something disturbed it. SOMEONE APPROACHES, MAJESTY, I MUST LEAVE HERE NOW AND KEEP FROM BEING DISCOVERED. Exiting the ear and burning through the bandages, Xonox sped away toward the ceiling in a twisty fluent flight. Again, Xonox virtually disappeared.
A group of six men entered the room wearing white full body protective suits and heavy black rubber gloves. It looked like they were called in to handle something radio active, like uranium. Xonox flew outside and hid outside the window when one person immediately began to monitor Gastonishs body with a Geiger counter while the others stood around her and watched. Another of the men bent over her face saying, She is awake. You think we should continue, Dr. Grant? It sounded like the voice was being spoken into a bucket.
We are here to do a job, aren't we? Of course we will continue. replied the muffled voice of Dr. Grant.
But don't you think we will have a problem if she sees herself in the mirror after we have taken the bandages off? I mean, there is no telling what she maybe capable of.
We will deal with that if we have to but I don't think it matters if we get a reaction out of her now or later do you? It will be the same reaction no matter when we do it. Besides, she's weak. I don't want to see her upset when she's strong. Whats the Geiger reading?
Examining the reading from the devise, the report came from the assistant, We are at safe levels of radiation here, sir.
But sir, perhaps we should cut the bandages off while she is tied up anyway. The doctor gestured with one hand.
All right, Dr. Evon, we'll do it your way. Lets get busy men. At the word, everyone went straight to work.
They cut the bandages off slowly... Too slowly. The sound the scissors made as they cut through the bandages were almost enough to drive Gastonish mad. -Scrunch - scrunch - scrunch!- Gastonish watched what was happening from the mirror at the far end of the wall. When the final bandage was removed and the man stepped out of her way Gastonish took a good long look and was horrified at what she saw.
 Skin, blistered and blackened with burns of pink and red, Gastonish examined her flesh; scorched, melted and much of it missing all together. Gastonish's hands didn't have the metacarpal raised from the surface and her muscles were substantially smaller. Where Gastonish used to have hard plates on her shoulders, forearms, and feet, she found nothing more than black charred remains of the bone plates surrounded with scarred tissue. Her ears were burned completely off. Her fingernails were black or missing. Her entire gum line was still full of molar size teeth as always, and her skeletal frame also remained original with long limbs, fingers and neck. Gastonish didn't know what to think of any of it. Was it a dream, or a joke? Surely, it couldnt be real. The creatures of this world had physical structures like volks, and if they were burned like she was, theyd appear quite similar. Gastonish wondered if the creatures of this new world thought she was one of them. Only, Gastonish had no doubts, she was hideous and she would remain so until she found a way home to her own kind. Rather than crying out savagely, Gastonish just lowered her head and wept mournfully. Her skin still felt like it was burning as it made contact with the air.
The men in white suites became very busy poking and prodding Gastonish in all sorts of places. They checked her eyes, mouth, nose and what was left of her ears. Gastonish was relieved Xonox had the good sense to get out. They checked her skin and temperature and by the time they were finished, Gastonish felt like her skin was going to burst into flames again.
In just a few minutes, Gastonish heard a nurse enter the room. She observed the shadowy form holding a tray. Is this a bad time for me to try feeding her? asked Nurse Sophia compassionately. It would be a good idea to get her started on eating for herself again. Ive brought something simple to start with, apple sauce and ice cream.
With dirty blond locks of hair and thin gold rimmed glasses, Nurse Sophia was very beautiful. When she spoke, her soft pink lipstick became the focal point. The second thing the doctors noticed was a beauty mark on her slender naked neck.
No, it should be all right. We are finished here, but we will stick around to help you re-dress her wraps and monitor any changes. answered one of the men in white. Nurse Sophia nodded and approached Gastonish with the tray of clean dressings and a small dish of apple sauce. Gastonish lifted her sad eyes to Nurse Sophia and asked, in a raspy voice, W-w-what is this place?
Nurse Sophia cut in, Hold on. We have lots of time to talk. We are sure happy youre awake. Now, why don't we take it real slow. I'll just take this intravenous out and start you on some ice cream. It should go down easy. With a snap of her wrist, Nurse Sophia pulled the thin tube of intravenous from Gastonishs arm. Gastonish flinched and gasped in surprise. She would have responded with a sharper reaction, but her body was drained physically and emotionally.
Sorry about that, but if I warned you, it would have hurt more. You have surprised me. I was not expecting you to be in such a good mood. Dr. Evon began to communicate, 'Please, you are making a mistake here. No one wants to bring harm to you or your offspring.'
'Listen to him, he is right!' Dr. McNeil added in support of the situation.
'I do not believe you. Your people are unpredictable in the ways of truth. How can I be certain my babies will be protected? Or do I need to destroy all human life on this planet to ensure our safety and survival?' asked Gastonish with a most dire threat.
'You are powerful,' Dr. Evon told Gastonish, 'We value not only our own lives, but the lives of everyone throughout the world. We will do whatever it takes to protect ourselves and if that means protecting you and your babies, then that is what we will do.'
'Besides,' the mind of Dr. McNeil added, 'We also value the lives of your kind as well. We do not wish to harm you. We only wish to understand you better so we can one day co-exist in peace.'
Dr. Evon contributed next, 'Let us agree from this moment, in the name of peace, you and your kind will never use your abilities to harm a human again, just as none of us will harm you or your kind in the future. Agreed?'
Gastonish processed this thought for an extra second or two before answering, 'Agreed.' because Gastonish found sincerity in the doctors, she agreed, but she was prepared to disappear from the sight of humans until she was strong. Then Gastonish would have brought death upon the humans of this world.
The force holding the doctors and nurses to the floor vanished. And everyone stood up with caution. Dr. Evon was the first to figure out how Gastonish was able to use her telepathic powers to cause everyone to project upon themselves, the notion of being held down to the floor.
While Dr. Evon was making preparations to have the volk baby cleaned up and delivered to the mother, Dr. McNeil was busy making preparations to have the body of Dr. Grant laid to rest. Dr. Evon did not take the egg out of the room, rather he simply placed it onto another portable table and used a sharp surgical tool to carefully cut the egg open.

At the dawn of a new day, I was carried into the light, and everyone could see me. The doctors and nurses crept closer for a better look. They could practically see right through me. All of my parts were right where they were supposed to be. My skin, muscles and bones were translucent. Everything was exposed, even my brain, body organs and strong beating heart.
A meeting took place where Dr. Evon and Dr. McNeil were appointed powers from both the president of the United States and the secretary of defense whereby, Dr. Evon inherited the title of president of all Knolix projects, and Dr. McNeil was granted the title of vice president. Between the two of them, they were to share the responsibility of first hand executive stewardship over appropriated extra-terrestrial life.
Dr. Evon did all he could to keep his mind on his job and not let the death of his mentor affect him. I was cleaned up quickly. Dr. Evon wrapped me in a soft baby blanket and placed me on my mothers chest with kindness and care. Other doctors released the straps for Gastonish so she could hold me. 
Gastonish, my mother, held me onto her chest by my ankles as she rubbed my back forcing clear liquid gel out of my lungs. When I took my first breath and coughed, I did not cry.
Dr. Evons eyes became glossy as he was in deep thought or perhaps some sort of shock. He examined me with a look of surprise and awe in his eyes. They were all looking at me, studying me up and down, but mostly, the people were fascinated by my eyes. I made connections with each one and learned a lot. It was like each person in the room had a photo album of their mind and I quickly flipped through their histories. For the people I connected with, they to saw images of their own past. Dr. Evon didnt realize that he took a step back with worrisome eyes full of questions.
While the two babies were being measured for size and weight, a photographer entered the room. He tried to step close and slipped a little on the wet floor when he first saw the babies and mother. An obvious subconscious battle within the photographer did not permit him to cross the final distance of five feet. He relied on his zoom lens to capture the close-ups.
With a more extensive study, Dr. Evon noticed odd baby blue lumps which formed on my shoulders, fore arms, and feet. The same lumps were also found, quite smaller, on each of the white metacarpals of my hands and the metatarsals of my feet. My fingernails did not cover only the top of my fingertips but the entire fingertips, the same went for my toes. My ears were pointed at the ends 
My ear pinna, or more specifically, my tragus and anti-tragus was able to open and close which could choke off my auditory canal completely like using ear plugs or sticking my fingers in my ears. This was handy as a reflex action to sudden loud noise, much like blinking ones eyes. 
The doctors studied my feet. They found they looked much like any humans feet do except for how they could move like hands to claps objects. My big toes could move around and perform like a thumb. My volk eyes were an opaque glossy black, but the most unique trait was how defined and muscular my body was in comparison to regular human babies. 

After isolating and analyzing the DNA of Eddy Evon, Dr. Evon watched as each of the top technicians were fired one by one when they reported traces of insect in the adherent molecules. Such a suggestion was considered impossible, but after nine technicians had lost their jobs in a row for having the same findings, the top leaders of the project began to listen to this possibility.

Gastonish held me to the sensitive burned flesh of her breast, and instinctively I latched on and began feeding. The miraculous bond between a mother and her baby had begun as she looked down at me and I returned her gaze as I looked up at her. We were locked in a world of our own as our eyes were locked onto one another.
Immediately, the doctor wanted a full examination of the living baby. He was very forthright about the record of size, weight, time, etc. However, Gastonish refused to allow anyone to handle her baby but herself. She realized this was the first moment where a human had seen a volk. A nurse laid a dark blanket over the baby who did not make it. She knew, by the way the staff would excitedly look at each other, their thoughts were not of good intentions. They wanted to take her baby away. Gastonish feared they would want to study her living child as well, and probe him, test him, maybe even look inside him. Could she trust the humans and their ways? She knew so little about them, but as she looked into their thoughts, she found though they were capable of great evil, they were bound by commitments which kept them from taking the life of her or her son. She knew she and her son were valuable to the humans and as long as she could have the reassurance of knowing volks were valuable, she would find it in herself to trust them. A group of doctors and nurses left the room as they carted the dead baby out with them. She was sad for the loss of her baby but for the time being, all she wanted was to hold her remaining child in her arms forever. Bending forward she took in the smell of her new born. She thought long and hard about where she might find a little protection.

Chapter 3

I was a baby like no other the planet earth had known from its past. A volk baby with the ability to suck information from the people around me like a sponge sucks water, I could make a carbon copy of any persons, or animals life experiences and file it way in the vast storehouse of my mind and no one was the wiser for it. I analyzed the information and learned at an extraordinary rate, but I also learned how to mimic the ways of a human child as a front to protect myself from the humans. It was because of my incredible gift to acquire knowledge effortlessly how I found it difficult to respond as helpless human babies did. My mother was impressed. She thought I pulled off a splendid performance.
This is my baby and no one is going to make decisions for him but me! exclaimed Gastonish, with every instinct of motherly protection buzzing in her mind.
A half smile cracked along the doctors face. He hoped he could convince her to give up her new born willingly. Dr. Evon loved intellectual challenges and he was positive his friendly authority complex could ultimately succeed. Miss, please, I can assure you no harm will come to your child, but we must understand it before we can permit it to grow up in the world. This facility is equipped with most of the necessary equipment to provide a thorough diagnosis. If we need to provide a further in-depth study we will let you know, but first, we must be allowed to examine your baby.
Gastonish peered into the doctors sharp, trusting eyes. She looked down at her baby, suckling her breast. No. her child was so captivating, Gastonish seemed to be in a trance.
Dr. Evon was at a loss. He never needed to separate a mother from her child with force before. It was something he did not believe in. Perhaps, he thought, he could jog the conversation and entice patient-X to speak. You have the most interesting baby I have ever seen. In fact, he is the most beautiful baby in the world. Wouldn't you agree?
Yes. Gastonish smiled, never breaking eye contact with her baby. She didn't even seem to blink.
I feel a great love and respect for your baby as well. Have you decided what you are going to name him? The doctor asked.
Gastonish considered the question as she chewed at her bottom lip. Her son would have to have a name, but the entire situation seemed so strange. In her minds eye, she began to reflect on the nebula phenomenon which brought her to where she was. She loved Mulunac, and would never forget how she felt when she was with him on their honeymoon. Eddy. Gastonish said, His name is Eddy.
Eddy? How fitting. Thats a very good name. Dr. Evon would not give up easily. He was determined to have the baby. You know, I have never experienced a birth like this. Nothing like this has ever happened on this world before.
Because you have never encountered a volk before. Her statement was the cause of a reaction, but the doctor tried to hide it. Am I right? Gastonish was still unsure of where she was and who she was talking to, so she was not sure how strictly she should conceal her identity or keep secrets.

Of course. She answered with her course, raspy voice.
Well look who is coming out of her shell? There is so much we still don't know about you and your son. I hope you will trust us enough to explain a few things? asked Dr. Evon as he rung some water out from the bottom end of his long lab coat.

You know enough for now. She cut him off, as she was trying to sway her baby from side to side as though she was attempting to separate her babys comfort from the tension building in the room.

Dr. Evon stood up and walked over to a fluorescent panel on the wall. I have a few X-rays here I was hoping you could explain. He popped the films up under the clips at the top of the lit panel. The first X-ray showed Gastonishs entire body. Everything here looks pretty normal, as you know. Your bones are somewhat heavier, dense and longer set than an average human females and your teeth are all molars. Your fronyal teeth, the bicuspids, cuspids and incisors are the most oddly shaped molar teeth I have ever seen. I have not seen anything like it before. I figured they would resemble those of leaf eating dinosaurs, but your teeth are unique, unlike any on earth. Later, I want to ask you a few basic questions about your eating habits but in the meantime maybe you can tell me if you are a vegetarian like everyone suspects?
I am able to consume practically anything which grows from nature. Gastonish answered.
Hmm, interesting. The doctor thought briefly. He made a brief note in his folder to test Gastonishs digestive abilities.
He took the X-ray pictures down from the clips and put them away in a filing cabinet. He fingered through another file in the same drawer and plucked out a couple of other X-ray photos. How do you explain this? He slapped two X-rays up into the clips and pointed to the first one, This is the spine of an average human being. Notice the curvature and the vertebrae. Now, this other X-ray is of your back. It has us all baffled. What is this, Two spines? 
Yes, of course, it is not wise for you to compare a volk to a human. We are completely different species. The more you look and compare the more this fact should be obvious to you. The way Gastonish spoke to Dr. Evon made the doctor feel like he was three years old.
The Doctor looked at her for a moment. Next, he looked back at the charts. He shook his head a little, before he said, Now, Gail, I want you to look at this next X-ray very carefully. The doctor chopped the fuzzy transparent image into the clips of the fluorescent panel. The image was of her head only and it exposed her skull, brain and everything. If you take a good look at your inner ear in this photo you will find there is a strange small object there. Through careful analysis we have found this object is not an error made by the X-ray shot. It is, in fact, made of small semi metal parts. Other aspects of it appear organic but it is very small and the resolution maybe flawed.
After a split second conference with her sertz, Gastonish answered. I don't know what kind of explanation you are looking for from me, but I can not help you find the reason for this representation.
Very well, strangely this is the only X-ray photo which has this possible mistake. You know Gail, you and I are going to have many more conversations together. This is just the tip of the iceberg. Dr. Evon wanted to gear Gastonish up for a long haul. He required her co-operation and truthfulness.
A nurse came in through the door holding a small bundle in her arms and behind her a medical practitioner also entered. The nurse approached Gastonish cradling a sleeping grey baby in her arms. The nurse bent down to Gastonish and handed the baby to her. Gastonishs burned face brightened. Though smiling was painful she couldnt help herself as relief filled her eyes to see her baby boy well and unharmed. He is much cleaner now, thank you. She said, with gratitude gleaming in her dark eyes.
The medical practitioner, who had been quiet in the past, decided to speak up. Our studies are amazing! The texture of your sons skin is comparable to a baby elephants. Yet, these are only surface similarities. For example it is able to withstand more temperature fluctuation than a human can. The new doctor was pleased to say. Dr. Evon looked at the doctor and his pleased expression dropped from his face. The doctor seemed to be able to read Dr. Evons thoughts. He stood up and left the room.
Dr. Evon turned back to Gastonish and opened his folder. Now, as I have noted in my report, Eddys eye sight is also quite remarkable. Through infra red surveillance, we have found Eddy is able to lock his eyes onto virtually any moving object in the room even when it is pitch black and virtually silent. We also tested his eyes against light, and he started squinting after an abnormally high brightness. I think his eyes are much greater than ours, beyond our current range of testing. His focus and range of the spectrum need more study. 
We next felt it was appropriate to do a blood test and we found his immune system is so advanced it is possible it might be impossible for him to get a disease. As I suspected, his immune system is able to seek out even air bound diseases and destroy them. The question came up! He said with enthusiasm, 'Could it be Eddys eyes are able to repair themselves unlike our light sensitive cells?
As we were checking his muscles and joints, we found he was positively too smart for his age. He would mimic us and observe all we did. It was important for us to know if his actions were authentic or just a fluke. We ran a cat-scan of his brain. His mind is unusually active and the chart was unreadable. No ones mind has ever functioned like his before. His behaviour seems to limit out temptations of aggravation or relaxation. Unlike other newborns who need lots of sleep, he must always be kept busy, and rest very little. Hes had only three short naps since his day of birth, three days ago. 
As you can clearly see, Eddy has large muscles, but we found his muscles have developed much more, than what it looks like. I have no doubt in my mind your son could beat a body builder in an arm wrestle. Eddys blood is blue when inside his body because inside his body there is less oxygen, like our veins. As I said, through rigorous testing, we have found, to date, how Eddys blood can't be infected by any known diseases. Including the HIV virus yet it may be too early at this time to quote this as a reliable statement. Furthermore, Eddys blood could not be used to help others because it is so different and it needs carbon dioxide to live. If he is cut, the blood will turn a dark red in contact with oxygenated air.
'That was more than enough for them to know.' Gastonish thought. She gave her sertz a mission to find out a little more from the good Doctor Evon than he was telling them. Xonoxs programming prohibited it to respond to a plan which consisted of deceit, but the programming changed when it was given authority of acting thrustle-T.
The little sertz flew about the room right out in the open and even flew right up to the doctors face. Dr. Evon waved his hand to waft it away and he believed it was a common house fly. The sound it made in flight was also quite similar to the sound of a fly. It circled the doctors head, before it darted into his ear. The doctor stood up and slapped his hand to his ear with his eyes wide with panic. He turned and ran, knocking over a table with medical supplies on it. He tripped and knocked his head against the lower cupboard counter. He laid on the floor face down and groaned.
Nurses came running to him. They were worried he had broken his neck. They called for help on the intercom, Emergency in room 005, code 711, Dr. Evon has been hurt and assistance is required immediately. He may have head and neck wounds. Everyone was running around like crazy. Gastonish just remained in her bed. She was the only one to notice Xonox fly out of his ear. Xonox cruised across the ceiling just before it dropped down to Gastonishs ear.
Within her ear, it relayed information of the doctors final thoughts, just after he had spoken to Gastonish. She listened and heard the information as though it was coming from his mouth. No harmful diseases can be traced in Eddy to harm others, and because the only thing wrong with him is his appearance, I was told to let Eddy live. This way we can watch Eddy and study him as he grows. If I turned him over to other government agencies, I might see a wealthy pay-off and be granted great recognition, but Eddy would surely die throughout many tests and surgical experiments until finally dissection. Because I am a good doctor, and make a good living, I don't need all of the money they offered me. If I turn your son over to a much more aggressive organization, doctors all over the world would cut him up and analyse each separate piece. I am here to protect you and your son, Gail. Besides, I would rather keep track on how he grows so I can find out what kind of adult he will grow into.
When Gastonish could see the level of Dr. Evons sincerity and how personally attached he was becoming to her and her son, she found he could be trusted after all. 

The next morning, Gastonish was wheeled into a new wing with baby me cuddled up tightly in her arms. We were taken into a room where Dr. Evon was waiting for us. Many other personnel were in the room but they quickly cleared out when we arrived.
The room was quite simple and bare, just like an interrogation room; white walls with a large mirror on one wall and at the center of the room was a table and a chair. In the corner, beyond the vacant chair was a plastic baby crib. Mom was wheeled right up to the side of the table opposite from the vacant chair. On the table was a glass of purple juice and a machine with paper scrolled through it and wires hanging out of it. Immediately, Gastonish was told to drink the grape juice as the nurse who wheeled her in took me from her arms and placed me in the crib. She drank every last drop of the juice and as she gulped it down she never took her eyes off me for a second. Dr. Evon came around to the far side of the table and pulled the chair out, before he sat down. Good morning, Gail. He said pleasantly.
Gastonish was surprised to find the doctor with a butterfly bandage on his fore-head, a neck brace around his neck and a white patch of gauze taped to his ear. Good morning Dr. Evon. Hows the bump on your head? She asked, equally pleasant despite her raspy voice. 
Grumpy, Dr. Evon cleared his throat. Um, yes, sorry about that episode yesterday. He said sheepishly. The doctor looked at Gastonish curiously, I was stung by a bee In my ear very strange. He looked down and shook his head. The doctor took a deep breath before he began to ask Gastonish some very simple questions. At first the questions were basic and Gastonish answered them easily. Soon Dr. Evons questions became more aggressive and Gastonishs head started to feel strange.
Gastonish, if you can understand what I say, nod your head. At Dr. Evons request, Gastonish nodded her head. I have mixed a powerful truth serum in with the grape juice you drank. I am going to ask you some difficult questions and you will answer me truthfully. Nod your head if you understand what I am telling you. Gastonish nodded again as she found herself captivated in the power of the Doctors persuasion. Where were you born? the doctor asked.
Telemar. Gastonish answered truthfully.
Telemar? Where is that? the doctor pressed.
Fon dur 14,985,830L; 10,549,674S; jai auce 294,065,002F; thur min 9,642E-78,603T; wir 9,408,763,094,567GHL; tona 93,975,765BVY; Telemar. Gastonish answered truthfully though this answer made no sense to the Doctor.
What? Hay, don't play games with me, just answer the question. Dr. Evon could not understand what was being said because the dose of truth serum Gastonish was given in the grape juice was enough to keep an elephant from lying.
Like a drunk, Gastonish slurred her words as she spoke. Those were the best directions I could give you. If you followed them you would have to be brain warped to not find the planet.
Planet. Dr. Evon grumbled. He looked behind himself at a two-way mirror and shrugged inquisitively.
A loud voice bellowed out of a speaker from the ceiling. Uh, She seems to be immune to the truth serums effects. If there have been no signs of the drugs effect by now, there will be no surprises later.
I wonder? Dr. Evon whispered to himself. Gail, what kind of directions did you give me?
I quoted the dimensions of Lornels direction. A language of code used primarily for directional purposes and designed flawlessly by the volk space scholar Lornel Von Gurdi. He was a space explorer who perfected star maps to an easy to memorize system. With his great contribution, many volks who were lost in space were found. Gastonish told the doctor, Not all of them were alive. She added.
Even still under the effects of the heavy drug, Dr. Evon made a mental note how her quick bird-like reflexes slowed not. Could you repeat the code once more? Asked Dr. Evon.
Fon dur 14,985,830L; 10,549,674S; jais 294,065,002F; thur min 9,642E-78,603T; wir 9,408,763,094,567GHL; tona 93,975,765BVY; Telemar. She repeated perfectly.
Dr. Evon could not wait to play back the recorded conversation and try to break the strange code.
Within Gastonishs ear, Xonox, her sertz, was upset Gastonish was speaking about forbidden topics. Xonox tried to keep her from feeling compelled to speaking the truth, it even searched her mind and body to pin point the cause of her influence. Gastonishs body was sweating as it eagerly fought off the drug she was given. As her aggressive volk immune system absorbed and destroyed the drug, she came around to her senses. She dodged the questions with unrelated answers and used her wits to out smart their testy methods.

In the first few days after I was born, it was routine for Gastonish and I to take a radiation neutralization shower. A man, dressed in a rubber suit, took me through first. Naked, Gastonish stepped into the private specialized shower stall alone. From the next room, unexplored by Gastonish, a group of security guards and scientists observed her through a wall size X-ray screen. It was the usual routine, until one day when the metal detectors traced a small object. The buzzing alarm scared Gastonish and Xonox. Xonox dashed for safety within Gastonishs ear. As the scientists observed the screen they located the metal fragment signature from within Gastonishs ear. Immediately, Gastonish was removed from the shower and before she could towel off, a doctor shoved a long needle-like tool into Gastonishs ear to examine it. The tool was actually a video cam which looked like a wand with a little light at the tip of it. Xonox flew against the lit viewing tip of the tool and zapped it. Unable to make a clear reading, the doctor removed the tool and Xonox escaped without being noticed. They made her shower five more times that day, but there was no re-occurrence of events.
The circle of scientists who worked closely with us under Dr. Evon, developed a full body suit for my mother to wear. It was skin tight and black. Absolutely no skin was exposed. The suit covered her mouth and all with thin breathing filters and black goggles to see through. The purpose of the suit was to protect Gastonishs sensitive skin and keep her low radiation levels from contaminating anything and to keep her disguised from spies and other such reporters.
It was hard for a baby to look at a black shadow of a person with no face or loving expression and imagine she was smiling down at me. It was equally as hard for me to look at the shadow with the love and respect I would have for my mother. When my mother and I were alone, she would remove her mask and smile at me with her burned disfigured face. It was the burned face which I learned to love first. 
Gastonish would put on the mask and sometimes she would remove it in plain sight for me. It was not long before I found it in my heart to accept the mask as my mothers other face. Intuition told me the love was the same.
After a great deal of moving from one government facility to another, we finally settled for a while within a secret military base. As time went on, my mother went through strong emotions of loneliness while she struggled to accept both the death of her husband and the detachment from her home world of volks. On many occasions my mother would tell me exciting stories about my father and how he would help uphold the law. He was a thrustle-T. Such an occupation was best described as a futuristic policeman. I depended on the stories to provide a sense of a fatherly figure in my life. Though I never knew him, I missed him very much. From the stories I was told, my father became my hero.

As a child I went through all the normal toddler mishaps, you know, like running into walls, (Often right through walls.) digging large holes, jumping from heights which were too dangerous and making noises others found too loud. This would happen usually when I was excited. It was also said I could yell very loud. People tried to keep me from crying, laughing or basically from getting too excited, but I was just a little kid. Shut me up? Impossible. Naturally, as a volk, I was quite awake and energetic for six full days, but I needed one day of the week to sleep for a full twenty-four hours. 
Before I became a toddler, my favourite past-time was jumping around within the jolly-jumper, which was basically a seat suspended from the ceiling by elastic cords. I would kick out with my little energetic, muscle-chunky legs and the rubber jumper would sling shot me all over the room. I usually found something to crash into. My mother dreaded each moment of my feeding because I would sneeze, spit or throw mushy food at her. I also ate a lot, which meant I was messy, very messy.
Dr. Evon, became close friends with my mother and I. We trusted him and felt we owed a lot to him because if it wasn't for him, my mother wouldn't have been given such a beautiful spacious apartment to live in. We were given the opportunity to choose our own styles of clothes and the custom measurements were usually perfect. Boxes of groceries were delivered to our door and Dr. Evon would visit and help my mother prepare meals. We all sat down together or with a few guests who Dr. Evon would invite. His friends were always very important people. For example, different presidents of the world, the secretary of defense and others who had a similar hand in the upper ranks of our worlds monopolized Government. 
My mother was brilliant. While most single mothers were out trying to make ends meet in order to provide for their children, my mother was beating the system. Humans would listen to her with expressions of great concentration on their faces. My mother could toy with the humans by losing them in conversations of suggestive academic techno-babble.
Xonox and my mother quickly developed a compromise to solve their little problem. Xonox would decide what information was non-threatening to the future, and Gastonish became rather skilled at giving just enough information without being too revealing. She did not forget to leave room for mystery. No information given was without a problem to be solved. As long as my mother would talk, we were welcome at the base and allowed to enjoy the pleasures they provided. When my mother was pressured to give more information than she should, she would become upset and give a performance of innocence which convinced the humans she simply could not provide all of the answers. Or she would change the topic with a new perspective to a relative interest.
The things she would tell them were how to collect certain ingredients from the earth and mix them into medicines. She gave a written Government policy of volk law which was followed and regarded as flawless through-out the endless reaches of space. This was the most difficult idea for the humans to accept. I was not involved in all of what she told the humans but sometimes her words would cause the humans to embark on great field expeditions. My mother always refused to go, using every excuse available. Many times she told them it was too difficult for her to leave me alone. After a few ventures where she was forced to go, she began to make the operations difficult. If she did not get her way, she would foul the entire expedition all together.
The doctors, scientists and biologists studied me all the time. There was not a time when eyes were not upon me. 24 hours, 7 days a week and they expected my behaviour and development to dictate the information in their notes. Many of the more significant changes which were taking place in my body were overlooked because their research was not extensive enough. They would get hung-up on the simplest things, like the way volks, un-like humans, would make quick movements. A tilt of my head or a gesture of my hand was just such mannerisms which astounded the scientist, but why? The only reason volks move this way was because we think super fast. Super high intelligence with reflexes like a squirrel or a bird. Obviously, my mind was wired differently from a human's, but the doctors spent far too much time concerned with this simple matter. Perhaps they were too excited with the whole idea they were the first to study me. Their notes would make history and their names would live forever. Perhaps they thought, because I was a baby, I was too delicate to risk on certain types of experimentation. Perhaps they felt they had lots of time. If I were to die they could open me up, freeze me or extend their studies with any number of similar ways. Whatever the reason, the lack of a more strict and organized research procedure led to the absence of recorded progress.
From my skin samples, blood samples and bone marrow samples, researchers could not find links which could relate to other samples of earth origin. Rather than breaking the information down, one thing at a time, the researchers looked at everything as a whole and decided such a mountain of information was too much for their capabilities. In their lack of efforts to go further in their journey down the road of research, they missed out on discoveries of my metabolic history which was millennia older than me but contained light years of advantages for them. It was obvious my body was more capable of adapting to the planet and it was also stronger in every way. Equally as obvious, it would seem to me, was my kind, volks, and how they had over come greater disease and a harder way of living. To search for the elements which made me who I was, became the most important, but least ventured aspect of their research.
Later, as I grew, the researchers finally pointed out how I was developing at a more rapid pace than their own human children. Another thing which set me apart from human children was my seemingly endless supply of energy. Like batteries which needed very little time to recharge, I just kept going and going. When I was old enough to speak, I made it obvious I did not like to be cooped up within the electrical wired fences of the base. I wanted to play with other children and go to school. I loved to learn. I always have and I always will.
Some said, I had an obsession to work out with my weights, lifting weights and playing hard was all I did most of the time. All the while, I was feeding my hungry mind. My thought process developed at an exponential rate. Any strong emotions could get me lifting tons. There was never enough homework, so I would bring home stacks of books from the library. Encyclopedias would entice me to set out on countless voyages of library digging. When I was shown how to use a computer, I found it very useful but slow. Exercise and surfing the net was not simple but I did develop a basic work area where my computer and desk were strapped to me and I could keep my legs active on the spot.
I did not have any toys but mom did request a skin diving suit for under water exploration and a small telescope to study the stars, along with a thick book of Master Magicians magic tricks. These things were quite interesting but they did not satisfy my loneliness. I needed friends to share them with, and freedom to visit new places and experience other sights and sounds.

Chapter 4

At three years old, I was getting a lot of attention on the base. I was invited to observe the soldiers practicing on a training obstacle course. Dr. Evon was there with other military officials. I loved watching the men train and I insisted I try the obstacle course. It looked like so much fun. When I was denied access to the training course I became up-set, cried out loud, and I mean loud. The soldiers who were trying to train were concerned, and distracted. I suppose I cried differently than human infants did. They said I sounded like a raving animal.
I would not give up. The humans would give me what I wanted. It worked before. The soldiers who saw me for the first time were mesmerized at what they saw. They wouldnt drop the stunned looks from their faces nor would they take their eyes off me. Dr. Evon took a syringe out from the pocket of his white lab coat and approached me. I had been poked with a billion needles in the past and none of them had taken any effect on me yet. How he thought this needle would be any different from the others I couldnt guess. Finally, the training instructor signaled for Dr. Evon to approach him. He appealed to his good will and persuaded Dr. Evon to put the needle away. He suggested I be granted the opportunity to monkey around a little on the training site.
When I was told I would be permitted to try it out, I immediately stopped crying and whaling. I stood up proud and straight and marched in through the gate of the chain link fence to the training field. The drill sergeant stood at ease as I approached holding Dr. Evons hand. All of the training cadets stood in single file, erect, strong and professional. They looked straight ahead, across the training facility, never breaking formation.
This is Eddy, sergeant. I would like to thank you for giving him the opportunity to try your training course. Dr. Evon said.
With a single nod and an expression of stone cold seriousness, the drill sergeant looked down at me and cocked an eye brow. You ready? he asked me with a mix of seriousness and kindness.
I started jumping up and down. I was so excited with a grin which stretched from ear to ear. Ya-ya-ya-ya! I answered, shaking the doctors arm.
I believe what you mean to say is, Yes, sir.
I quickly composed myself and saluted the drill instructor, Yes, sir. I said clearly with a perfect mimic of the drill instructors voice.
Lieutenant Fang! Front and center! The drill sergeant commanded.
One of the soldiers stepped forward from the formation, pivoted quickly, facing us before he marched to us. The moment he stood before the drill sergeant, he stomped his foot and saluted. Sir, Lieutenant Fang, sir! He quickly slapped his arm back down at his side.
Your mission is to accompany our guest and assist him if he has any trouble throughout this course. Understood?
Sir, understood, sir! Answered the soldier with strict obedience.
Now, listen up! Eddy will run the course of this exercise alone. No one else besides Lieutenant Fang will interfere. The drill sergeant turned back to me and said. Your mission is to run this course in as little time as you can and grab the flag at the top of the fort. Understood?
Sir, understood, sir! I answered, saluting him. I noticed half of the sergeants mouth curl up in a grin, just before it disappeared quickly.
The drill sergeant held up a digital stop watch and said. Ready? He looked at me with a lazy skeptical stare and pressed a button on the stop watch. Go!
I sprang from the foot of the drill sergeant and dashed into the training field. I caught sight of the distant tall fort at the end of the course. I judged the distance quickly before I approached the first obstacle. It was a rope hanging over the middle of a dug out pool of water. I jumped from the edge and caught the knot at the bottom of the rope. As my weight came down my whole body shook and my grip slipped away from the rope. I fell into the water. My legs folded to absorb the fall as the surface of the shallow pool closed up over my head. Lieutenant Fang was reaching out to help me. However, I quickly found my balance and powerfully leaped out of the pool onto the edge at the other end. 
Next, I was faced with a field of fire. At the fore-front of the field was a series of tunnels. I dove into the middle tunnel. My soaking wet clothes did not slow me down in the least. Within the tunnel I found the air hot and heavy to breathe. It was dark with many turns. The other tunnels would join one to another along the way. This obstacle was to test a persons sense of direction. Lieutenant Fang had difficulty keeping up with me in the tunnels. Before long I found my way out at the other end. 
I did not wait for Lieutenant Fang and continued onward to the next obstacle, a high wooden wall. The wall had five ropes hanging down the face of it. I jumped onto the wall securing a strong hold onto the rope. Persistently, I climbed the wall. Hand over hand, I climbed, not looking down until I reached the top. I was surprised at how high I transcended. Lieutenant Fang was still not out of the tunnel. I slumped over the edge and continued to work my way safely to the ground. I crawled under fifty feet of barbed wire, before I climbed hand and foot across a wide webbed bridge made of rope. This bridge was suspended over a deep gorge with a river running through it. Finally, I looked up and found I was at the base of the tall wooden fort. The fort itself was built upon pillars about eighteen feet high. I climbed the ladder with ease. Within the fort I jumped high and snagged the red flag from the top of the pole. I went to the window and waved it at the distant drill sergeant and other on lookers. I saw Lieutenant Fang hoist himself up and over the tall wooden wall.
The drill sergeant used a speaker system which was wired throughout the course to broadcast his voice. Well done, Eddy. said the drill sergeant. Lieutenant Fang! Please return to the front of the training course. I would like to have a word with you.
The Lieutenant jumped down from the rope of the high wooden wall and let his shoulders slump at the voice of the drill sergeant.
Eddy? I have a new challenge for you. Your next mission will be to bring the flag to me. No problem. The training course was a snap. You must go through the training course once again only this time my cadets will be doing everything in their power to take the flag from you. They already had a head start.
He was certainly right about that. The cadets practically traversed the entire course. Biting down on the red flag, I moved from the fort as fast as I could. I slid down the ladder to the ground. Three of the most expedient cadets were already climbing across the loosely woven rope bridge. I ran at them and jumped into the air. I landed in the center of the rope bridge causing the other three cadets to bounce into the air. When they came down two of them fell over the side and into the river below while the other one was tangled in the rope. Next, I ran, jumped and slid under the low barbed wire using the plates of my fore-arms as skis. I avoided the other cadets under the barbed wire with speed. Rolling and sliding to dodge my pursuers.
Between the Barbed wire and the high wooden wall were many cadets who were waiting for me. They jumped on me trying to tackle me to the ground but I wouldnt go down. One of them grabbed the flag and pulled again and again but I would not release my bite. I was small but I would have to show them I was strong. Like a bull, I began to charge forward. On my back I carried the group of soldiers. Some fell off while others continued to hold me and dig their heels into the ground to stop me. I felt like nothing could stop me. I pushed forward even more powerfully when they applied their resistance. Like a horse, I took the crowd with me as I rammed the high wooden wall. I broke right through the wall before I headed straight into the tunnels.
I pushed my way past anyone whom I found in my path. Most of those underground did not even know who I was because the shrouding darkness concealed me so well. I dashed out of the hot tunnels, flag in mouth and ran to the rope which hung over the middle of the pool. Four cadets gave chase from the tunnels. I didnt want to lose my grip on the rope again for a second time. I jumped from the edge and grabbed hold of the rope once more. I swung across the muddy pool of water and landed on the other side with a solid thud. I gave the flag to the drill sergeant pounding my feet and jumping in excitement with a cheer.
The drill sergeant looked shocked as he stood with his mouth open holding the red flag in his hand. Dr. Evon was proud and tried not to make eye contact with the sergeant. Instead, the doctor paid more attention calming me down. 
Enjoy your little pet, doctor. the Sergeant said in a strange and rather unfriendly sort of way, It is just a matter of time before he is mine. The moment was somewhat awkward as the defeated cadets began to filter into single file. They were in rough shape.
Dr. Evon snapped around, Over my dead body, Sergeant. Dr. Evon spoke loud and clear as he shot a look at the sergeant which meant business. 
The drill sergeant smirked in response. He puffed up his chest arrogantly, You know what they say, doctor He spoke coolly, be careful what you wish for. 
Not a glimmer of fear or intimidation could be seen in the eyes of Dr. Evon. He simply turned his back on the sergeant and directed me off the training field and drove me home in an army jeep.

Finally, I started my first grade at the age of four. Within one of the many rooms of the bases complex was my class room. Every child who saw me would freeze in their steps and just stare. One of the older children snickered to his friends and said, So, when did aliens start taking steroids?
Another boy responded, equally as cocky, I don't know, but they're taking way too many. The group tried to conceal their giggling, but they failed miserably.
Inside, I was saddened, but for their sake, I brightened my face with a smile and responded by saying, Steroids? That is a human solution for muscle tone, but me, Im all natural. 
I approached the door where a soldier stood guard next to it resting his rifle against his shoulder. Sitting in the desks of the room were human children. I was thrilled to see them. I never met these children before but they were pretty much all in my age group. At first none of the children liked me. They were scared of me because I was different. I couldn't blame them. I was quite a bit different, but with a little time and patience, the opinions of the children began to change. I met with many of them just one on one where we spoke about all sorts of things. They soon found their interests were not much different from my own, for the most part. They were surprised when they realized I was not a danger or a threat to them. Finding it apparent how I genuinely cared for them, the children found a basis to begin trusting me. They also found I had the same array of feelings and just wanted to make friends just like they did. Soon, everyone wanted to be my friend. Rather than believing I would never fit in with humans, I willed myself to believe I was destined to be the most popular kid in school. 
One little girl told me I was fascinating, and this was why none of the other classmates could get enough of me. I didn't want to admit it but I did find it annoying at times to have thirty kids huddled around me watching everything I did. When I wasnt at school, I had thirty doctors huddled around me watching my every move. It was something I had to tolerate with loads of patience.
That year my teachers name was Mrs. Wooly. A forever frown was painted upon her face, with tiny bi-focals perched at the end of her nose. She was an obese X-drill sergeant. When the bell rang Mrs. Wooly began her day the same way every morning by speaking through her big buck teeth. People! She wore a sassy expression on her face. Silence and sit down! Don't start this year with a bad impression. Now, I want you all to take one and pass it back. Mrs. Wooly held some test booklets of some sort. Handing a small bundle of the test booklets to the child at the front of the rows, the students began to hold one before passing them back. Before long everyone had a booklet. This is just a standard aptitude test. Mrs. Wooly explained solemnly. You have twenty minutes to fill in the answers. Pencils up Ready? Go!
Everyone of the students heads dropped down to their test and they began to fill in answers as fast as they could. As I got started in the test, I found it was all but standard. I filled in the blanks as best as I could but it was tricky with all of the fine details which were seeded to throw us off. The twenty minutes went by fast but I was able to finish in time and check over some of the previous questions. Pencils down! Heads up! Mrs. Wooly called. The children dropped there pencils onto their desktops at once with a clatter. Some children gasped for air. It was understandable for the test was full of trickery and puzzling questions meant to confuse each one.
A group of four men in business suits came into the room, single file. They sat at a long table at the front of the room. The tests were collected and the four men began to mark them. You little worms! Mrs. Woolys voice rang loudly like a bell, yet a few children continued to murmur amongst themselves. At times I wondered if Mrs. Wooly had a split personality because she could start speaking grumpy and by the end of her sentence become as nice as pie. If you will just settle down --Silence!!!-- for a little bit of reading. She opened up the bible and began to read. When she finished, I had my head down on the desk. I must have been the only one who felt a little tired. She called my name and it rang in my ears. Her voice was like nails on a chalk-board and it sent chills up my doubled spine --Eddy--!
Yes? I snapped my head up, before she rolled out of her chair and hauled her large body down the isle toward me, pushing the desks apart. She was dressed in her old military uniform, decorated with the medals she earned for her years of service to the core. She slammed her hands down on my desk and bent over. She put her face close to mine and said, Could I see you outside for a moment?
Yes maam. I smiled back at her hoping she would smile too, but it didnt happen. 
Outside the classroom, What grade are you in? Immediately came a question from Mrs. Wooly. 
Grade one. I replied.
Do you know how to read, count, add and subtract numbers? Mrs. Wooly was easier to speak to when we were no longer near the other children.
Sure, some people have been surprised how I could multiply and divide fractions and enjoy learning algebra. I answered enthusiastically, I've read one hundred and eighty-seven library books, some of them were text books, three magic books, which my mother gave to me, and half of the bible over the summer.
You read that much? Would you mind if I gave you another test later? It won't be for your grade, just for fun.
I don't mind if its for my grade or not. Its all the same to me. I told her casually.
What did you understand from the bible? She asked as she folded her arms over her chest. As she straightened I remember how tall she looked.
I remember everything I see and hear, however, I am unable to relate to the unattainable concept I read from the bible. Science fills us with in-depth explanations to help clarify how something works or has come to be. The Bibles answer to everything seems to be the power of God, or miracles. Unless it is evil, then it is the devils fault. I find it difficult to live by faith, yet I understand I could never attain all of the control in the world. It is an interesting way of life and has gained a lot of support from archeology, but I remain skeptical. It is a useful concept for getting people to obey laws and develop order, but much of it seems too hocus-pocus to me. Where is the tangible proof or logic in a God. It sounds to me like people need something to believe in, they have big questions about their own existence or how the world came about, so they developed the bible to quickly answer the unexplainable without the complications of scientific trails or mysterious unanswered strings.
Silence! Announced Mrs. Wooly, How dare you talk about God with such insolence and disrespect! You're too young to know what youre saying.
I am sorry. I suppose youre right. I am young and until God has revealed himself or there is a connection made between science and God, I will follow science. The truth didnt seem to be working out for me very well as I spoke in my own defense.
A quiver rippled through Mrs. Woollys cheeks with frustration. She pushed her glasses further up her nose and looked down. After Mrs. Wooly took a deep breath to clear her head and compose herself, she said, What I brought you out here for is to tell you, your test was marked first and it appears you have an amazing skill at learning. At this point you have been tested at a high school level. The school board, decided to not bump you quite so far into the ranks of the school system. In taking care not to move along too rapidly, at this moment we have put you in a grade three class. However, you won't stay here for long if you continue with this attitude of yours. Warned Mrs. Wooly. Remember Eddy, the other children look up to you for strength and guidance. If you have little faith they too will have little faith.
I was amazed at the words being spoken by this lady. I was not interested in getting into a religious debate with her. I let her win this round. I was going to be bumped up to grade three! We went back to class, and I had never been so distracted in a classroom as it was then. I was teased because I couldnt wipe the smile off my face.

That evening at home, I told my mother the good news and she said, I heard about it earlier, Im glad your teacher told you. I wished I could see through her black emotionless face mask. The moment may have felt more real if I could see her smile and delight in the joy in her eyes. Ive prepared a cake. Lets celebrate tonight, Eddy... Just you and I. The excitement in her raspy voice made all the difference. I had never been so excited before in my life. The rest of the day went by faster than ever. Later that night I prepared for my twenty-four hour sleep, but it wasnt easy because I heard several gun shots outside and wondered what could possibly be going on within the perimeter of the Base. Mom called Dr. Evon to find out what was going on but he reassured her there was nothing to worry about.

Elsewhere, at approximately the same time, groups of heavily trained soldiers were hustling from place to place within the shadows of the fortified military perimeter. With state of the art stealth techniques, the soldiers remained in contact with one another. The radios they used were designed for silence as well. When everyone was in position they initiated the next step and released the dogs. Four Dobermans came scampering out of the darkness and they were hungry to kill. The dogs were so vicious they would pant and growl at the same time as they ran. They darted in right through the hidden groups of soldiers and dived right in behind a parked military truck. A great scuffle was heard and some loud thumping sounds. The security dogs yelped out loud with pain as they were beaten to death. Out from the darkness came a thinly framed short person who had an abnormally large head. The creature held two dogs by the throat in each hand. As the soldiers leaped out from the shadows, the creature began to throw the dogs at the soldiers. The power at which the dead dogs were thrown was of such force it knocked down the entire groups at a time. Machine gun fire began to light up the area as the soldier retaliated.
The creature was exposed in the flashing lights of gun-fire. It was an Ornock, a living creature from another planet, and it was being held in the barracks Top secret. Bullets crossed and struck it just as it began to run forward. The Ornock quickly ran to a group and struck a soldier knocking him ten feet into the air before it punched another officer in the chest repeatedly as though he was mimicking the rapid fire of a machine gun. But it was the final strike for the Ornock as it was mutilated within a circle of cross fire.
At a glance one might make reference to the similarities between a volk and an Ornock. They both had grey skin, large heads and black eyes, but their bodies were very different. Where an Ornock was short and thinly framed, a full grown volk was on average taller than a human by a couple of feet and solidly built with muscles.

Two days later, the doorbell rang and a heavy fist knocked at the front door. My mother was quick to answer the door and welcomed Dr. Evon into our home. When he walked through the open door I noticed he was carrying a large black box. He looked over to me and said, Hello, Eddy. I've brought you something.
A gift? I asked. Dr. Evon did not reply. Connecting the television to his black box, he abruptly began fiddling with wires. Both, he and my mother, had smiles on their faces. The more he fiddled the more curious I became.
There we are. Said the doctor as red, green and blue lights lit up at the front of the black box.
What is this machine for? I asked excitedly.
Its a DVD player. Said Dr. Evon. I was hoping to watch a movie with you. It is called Alien Terrestrial. It is very popular. After the show, we can discuss plans for our future over dinner this evening. The doctors tone in his voice made everything seem so pleasant.
Dinner and a movie, eh? Is this some kind of date? I asked loudly.
Gastonish looked at Dr. Evon but her facial expression was concealed behind her mask. It was quickly established how the doctor was not trying to imply anything by the occasion.
When the movie began, Dr. Evon and I were very interested while Mom would laugh or chuckle at the special effects used to represent the spaceship and aliens. As the story went on mom became even more interested. I don't think Dr. Evon heard her but, when the television screen showed a full view of an aliens head, I could almost swear I heard Mom say, Perhaps Ornocks are the answer.
Later, during the movie Mom began to look sad, pale, and sick when an alien was being dissected. Before the sad dramatic climax at the end of the movie, Mom was crying. She quickly stopped when she realized Dr. Evon and I were sobbing with her. Mom suggested we all go into the kitchen for something to snack on. I quickly took my usual seat at the table. I didn't know what ingredients my mother used when she created a meal in the kitchen, nobody did. However, what she made had an original taste all its own. Everyone who tried my mothers food always enjoyed it. What she served us for a snack was small, bite size, black, crunchy coated cookies with a murky, yellowish filling. The taste was incomparable, but satisfying.
Eddy... Dr. Evon began, Your mother has brought to my attention how you are pleased with your first day of school.
Yes sir. I said happily, I have been bumped to a grade three level.
Well, The doctors face stretched out abnormally from side to side as he smiled brightly. You are developing fast, super-fast and super-smart. A moment was lost as he smiled down at me, lost in his thoughts. This calls for a celebration! the doctor returned.
I'm sure it does but deep down, my feelings have remained the same. I am not happy here. It feels like I am going to be here for the rest of my life. Trapped. I said.
Wha-- Really? Dr. Evon was surprised but, I had told him about my feelings before. Well, I guess this is as good a time as any to tell you about our plans to move you to a new secure location.
A secure location would be no different than where we are right now. Gastonish voiced, What my son and I want is to be free. Like animals, we are being held against our will and like animals we should be set free so we can try to go back where we came from. Gastonish frowned.
We have considered that idea, but there is too much to lose. Perhaps you don't realize how important you are to us. If we let you go, we run the risk of losing you forever, and without our protection you and your son would be in great danger. 
If you hold us here against our will, a day will soon come when you all will be in great danger. Gastonish warned.
