The doctors face hardened into seriousness. I have told you before. You need our protection. Our tests have revealed you and your son are not human. In this world you will always be in danger as nations throughout the world learn about you. Don't take for granted, the kindness you have found here in us, your friends. You are from another planet, a planet you called Telemar. Gastonish smiled inwardly, because Telemar was the name of a city of the planet Verticus. She remained quiet and let the doctor continue. I am still amazed at how this situation has become our reality, but here it is. You are not from this world and yet I communicate with you. You have done well, Gastonish, to co-operate with us. Youve made some worthwhile deals for better living accommodations.
What do you mean? I perked up and asked inquisitively, What deals?
I have traded a few ideas of mine for a better way of life for us, Eddy. Gastonish cleared her throat as it irritated her to speak.
And she managed to do it all within the legal limitations of our justice system. No one has to convince me you are both aliens and now you are the only living aliens with protected rights.
Dr. Evon, there is something else, I would like to work some kind of deal for. suggested Gastonish as she shifted her weight for a new comfortable position.
Oh? What would that be? Dr. Evon asked curiously, pointing his nose in the air.
I have been looking into the surgical practices of reconstructive surgery. After putting a lot of thought into what information I would give for such a gift, I believe a mutually beneficial agreement could be met. I will not go into great detail about what kind of agreement I have in mind with you but I trust you can promptly make the necessary arrangements for me to meet with my lawyer to draw up the proposal.
Dr. Evon smiled and lowered his eyes for a moment to appreciate the firm grasp of control Gastonish was capable of having on people. He took a long breath as he considered what he heard and how he felt about the reality of its possibilities. Im so proud of you. You have learned so much about our world, but Gastonish, do you really think it is wise to reconstruct your disfigurement so you can walk this planet with the appearance of a volk, rather than a burn victim?
What makes you think I want to retake the appearance of a volk? Spoke my mother quietly.
Dr. Evon and I were amazed at what we heard. Gastonish was suggesting she would willingly take on the appearance of a human.
Mom? Using my innocence of youth, I captured her attention. If you do this will I be able to recognize you?
If I were able to have my burns fully healed I don't think you would be able to recognize me. At least this way I would not be considered a freak by this world.
And what about me, mom, am I supposed to have reconstructive surgery as well? I asked.
No Eddy, I could not bear seeing you go through such an unnecessary surgery. You are perfect in my eyes. This is something I have in mind for me alone. She bent down on one knee and gave me a hug. She pressed her head against my cheek before she whispered in my ear. You will not grow up as a freak, Eddy, I have plans to negotiate terms of our freedom, it is just not time yet.
Gail, I can not make any promises about your plan to have plastic surgery, but you know I will back you up as much as I can. As for freedom, it is not as easy as that. Dr. Evon straightened. You can never live free enough to roam this planet as you wish, like a human. But as I was saying, we have a new place in mind to send you both. It is secluded, and you will feel the riches of freedom there. You won't find electrical fences, curfews or the nagging of constant supervisions. You will still be required to have regular physical testing and other similar check-ups, but it will be nothing like what you have experienced here.
Why, the sudden interest to consider our request? We have asked you to support us for the past few years for the sake of freedom and every time we have been denied. Gastonish was very suspicious and curious.
I was not allowed to share the information of the locations development before, but were finally ready to get things rolling. There have been rumours, someone from within the base is leaking information about your existence. Looks like quarantine is not as top-notch as I was promised, which is very dangerous for you. For now until the time you arrive at the new location, you and your son are forbidden to speak to anyone at all. If someone comes to you and asks a question, say nothing, and let me know as soon as possible. Please trust me... You will be free.
The freedom he spoke of was not exactly what my mother and I had in mind, but we recognized any more freedom than what we had was a step up. I crumbled off a bite from one of my mothers cookies. The silence was broken as I munched. My bashful smile stretched from ear to ear. Picking up on a signal, like a radio frequency in my mind, I sensed how my mother was pleased. I did not feel comfortable about her decision to accept treatments of reconstructive surgery from humans, but she was my mother and I could not argue with her easily at such a tender age.
The doctor left the table and went on his way to collect his DVD player. Mom opened the door and when Dr. Evon was about to head out to his car from the complex, Mom softly called after him, Wait! When should we begin preparations for the move? There is still so much I don't know.
As Dr. Evon turned to answer her, the DVD almost slipped and tumbled out of his arms and he replied, I am limited as to how much information I can give you at this time. Just be ready as soon as possible and remember, total silence. The doctor whispered before he made a motion with his hand at his mouth to suggest he was zipping his lips shut.
Gastonish answered the doctor with, Thank you. before she waved good-bye. When Gastonish saw Dr. Evon had reached his car, she closed the door.
My mother and I were ecstatic with feelings. We began to pack our things immediately. Neither of us said a word to each other because we were worried a spy may be listening somehow. We were not about to take any chances to jeopardize our opportunity to be free. Shortly after Dr. Evon left, some soldiers came to the door and took me away for some extended mental and physical testing. I was much more patient and helpful with the scientists, as I clung to my new hope of freedom and change, I found strength to endure the test procedures.
     
I spent the night under going long hours of exercise and studying, while my mother slept. Before she woke-up, I had a quick shower before I went to the kitchen for breakfast. I sat down and mom placed before me the usual; four sandwiches dripping with honey. Black specks were mixed in with the honey. I was also served a large jug of fruit juice. 
Mom? I asked looking up at her with my large glossy infant eyes, I have been meaning to ask you what these black specks are that you crunch up and mix with the honey.
Its kind of like, pepper. she replied with a shrug of her shoulders.
I ran over to the shelf where the spices were kept. With a leap I grabbed the edge of the counter top and hoisted myself up onto the counter. From there I stood up and opened the upper cupboard door. I took a jar from the shelf. This is it, right?
My mother became annoyed. Give that back! She demanded sternly. You shouldn't be climbing on counters, you could break something. Now, let me help you down and don't do that again.
I quickly opened the container and emptied the contents out on the counter. Thousands of dried insects spilled out all over. I looked at my mother with disgust written all over my face.
Don't be silly, Eddy. She said strangely. You don't really believe I would feed you insects, do you?
I'm not sure. I said suspiciously.
Gastonish lowered her head and breathed as though she was defeated. Believe it or not, and I am trusting, you wont tell anyone of what I tell you, Im sure if she wasnt wearing her dark goggles see would have been giving me the eye. There is a mystery here in these insects. I have found too many similarities between the insects of this world and Verticus. I think if I carefully study these earthen insects we can acquire critical knowledge which will help us to figure out how to return home.
My mother was serious about studying the insects so I believed her and tried not to bring up the subject again. However, later, Gastonish did confess to using insects for her special ingredients. I did not understand how Gastonish was able to separate the insects innards from their dry outer skeletons, but she did. Gastonish kept specific insect meats and organs in a multitude of separate jars. I must commend my mother for her ability to create the most tasty foods, snacks and medicines from bugs. Crunchy bug rolls, critter crackers, creepy crawly cookies, Anty ma-ma pancakes, thick tick shakes, chocolate rocket roach bars and cheese bug burgers. Somehow my mother could cause the insects she collected to grow larger than usual. Many were the size of lobsters and the dinners were usually quite exotic and she had the ability to make common house flies into delicacies, like mosquito flame-bo. She told me how each of her dishes were very nutritious and most importantly, very top-secret. Only mom and I could enjoy them.
Eddy? asked Gastonish as I took the first bite into my sandwich. After today, we will be free and I will find someone who will be your new teacher. He will teach you everything you'll ever need to know.
My curiosity had quickly peaked. Who is it? I asked impatiently. She looked at me blankly, Hey, wait a minute, is it Dr. Evon? I asked with disappointment.
She giggled, No, no, it is not Dr. Evon. Its someone from verticus. Now hurry up and eat, I will tell you more about who your new teacher will be, when we get to our new home.
I was such a young volk and I had an over active imagination like any human child would. Though I did not speak it, I thought Gastonish was referring to my father. I came up with possible scenarios as to how Mulunac may have survived and where he was.

The next day was moving day, and the movers were working like ants in single file. Gastonish was dressed in her specially designed black body suit, as usual. She stood outside with Dr. Evon and a few other high military officials. I was supposed to stay in a trailer, out of sight, but I was too excited to experience the promise of freedom. I wandered inside one last time to say good-bye to our empty suite. I heard some workers grunting as they worked in my bedroom.
Hey, Tom, why don't you go back to the van and get some pliers. This is ridiculous. said a mover from within the room.
I walked toward the door and a tall skinny man walked out with a flushed face. When I entered the room, I found a large man dressed in worn blue jeans with sweat pouring down his face.
Wheezing as he breathed. He said, Hey, boy, you lived here? He wiped the sweat from his forehead, removed his sunglasses and turned his head down to me for a better look, Oh, sorry, I have explicit instructions not to say a word to you.
What is your name? I asked.
No, don't ask, I am not saying another word. He replied.
My mother and I lived here. I pressed on.
Well, He spoke softly. He turned his head from left to right to be sure no one else could hear him. He bent forward and smiled, Who lifts these weights? He wiped off some sweat, from the back of his neck with a rag.
Stepping toward the barbells on the bench, I placed my hands on the bar. Only my mother and I lived here and she hardly ever touched 'em.
I grabbed the two hundred and fifty pound barbell with both hands. Next, I propped it up onto my right shoulder, while supporting it with my right hand. Bending down with my knees, I pick up a smaller thirty pound hand weight with my left free hand, and left the room. The mans jaw hung open as he watched me leave. I love being a volk. I smiled inwardly. I was lightly reprimanded by a sergeant for leaving the trailer, before I was rushed to a nearby van.

Hidden in an armored van, my mother and I were driven from the base. Our possessions, transported in separate vehicles, we traveled night and day, before the van stopped and my mother and I were directed to get out.
Within an underground parking lot we climbed into a huge box trailer of a tri-axle tractor truck. By human standards it was cold in the trailer with the boxes of cargo. The box compartment was hoisted from the flat bed trailer where we were loaded onto a sea faring cargo vessel. It was like we were traveling for an eternity. As we were rocked back and forth over the waves the boxes around us would shift and slide.
When the ferry finally docked, we were once again loaded onto a flat-bed tractor trailer and on the move. We drove a short distance along a dirt road, before we were told to get out and climb into yet another vehicle. I jumped out of the trailer and took a good look around. My eyes adjusted quickly as the salty warm ocean breeze swept over me. I was momentarily tranquilized by the air and beauty of the Island. I did not expect to find such lush green growth. We were truly on the Island. I had to lean back as I tried to take in the great cone shaped mountain of the ocean which stood before me. Heavy waves pounded against the surf. A steep rocky cliff wall towered over and around us almost like a giant cave. Deep shadows contributed to its awesome size. A pick-up truck which looked like it had seen better days, was parked nearby. The driver opened the passenger door from where he sat and waved for us to get in. Just before I entered the truck I paused to take in one last look at the incredible Island. Another gust of wind washed over me before my keen ears heard the songs of strange birds which I had not heard before. I could not contain the smile which stretched across my face. I bounced into the truck with an energized happiness which fed my already joyous mood.
The smell of pine, with a dash of salt, filtered through the vents and filled the cab of the truck. The humans who accompanied us all made a few comments, Hey, my butt hurts! How are you?
Flat as a pancake of course, yee-ouch! How much further?
Ah, here we are, just around this bend. In all, the trip took us about ten hours to complete. The road gave us the opportunity to get a good look at the Island. A few areas were thick with jungle bush, but for the most part the Island was clothed with mainly green virgin forests of tall ancient woodland trees. Though the Island was primarily a single mountain protruding out of the sea, and considered a small Island, I was overjoyed by its beauty. I could not wait to enjoy the freedom to venture into its indigenous forest, but any outdoor life was great after spending most of your life on a military base.
Eddy. My mother called quietly, Look over there. When I looked over and spotted our new home, a magical feeling came over me. As we drove closer, the front door opened and Dr. Evon stepped out to greet us. Somehow, he had beaten us there from the ferry. The truck came to a stop and I stepped out. Birds greeted us from the trees, and the sun filtered through the leaves.
The rickety little cabin had faded with an old chipped wood exterior. The roof was covered with moss. It could have been just me but it was as if the house was slightly slanted to one side. This may be in part of the challenge the builders would have had because the entire right side of the cabin was built into the steep rock wall of the mountain.
The drivers backed the moving truck onto our property. My mother and I could not hold back our excitement, we just had to go inside. Amazingly, the interior was much different from the exterior, only where I expected to find a wall of rock, there was a natural wooden wall with a closet. The walls were mostly hard wood tongue and groove. We had all of the comforts of our previous apartment, electrical power, gas heating, plumbing, kitchen appliances, utilities and even a workable indoor bathroom. A large window on the far side of the room looked out over our yard to the surrounding trees. To our left were two doors to each of our bedrooms. We explored as much as we quickly could, opening cupboards, testing faucets and light switches.
You are going to just love it here, Gastonish. Dr. Evon told her with a smile.
Doctor, why did you call me, Gastonish. She asked surprisingly.
Well you'd better get used to it because you have no secret identity in this town. The doctor said as he started the gas fireplace. You will notice you only have one phone and it does not come complete with numbers to dial out. This phone is strictly for emergencies. When you lift the receiver, you will be instantly linked to a military base which is not far from here. They will answer your questions and deploy a squad to deal with any emergency you might have.
What kind of emergencies are you talking about? My mother asked.
Lets say you saw something unusual, or you felt you were in some sort of danger. Pick up the phone and tell the voice at the other end. They will instruct you further. We have a code which you and Eddy will have to become familiar with while you live as civilians here. The code is the law of the Island and you must respect it. In time you will become more familiar with how we do things here, but for now you need to understand you have majestic clearance to go anywhere you wish on this Island, but there are certain military areas which are off limits to you. Do not interfere with military activities. The only people who can enter such places have a code clearance higher than yours which is Q clearance. You will know the difference by the ID cards people carry around their necks.
Gastonish looked at Dr. Evons ID card which hung from a long chain around his neck. It was clearly marked with Q clearance. He pulled a couple of other ID cards out of his pocket and put the chains over the heads of my mother and I. Ours were like everyone elses except we didnt have our pictures on them.

Before long, the movers finished unloading and pulled out. We were left in the small cabin with the gas fire as our only source of light. The room was filled with boxes. I started to unpack my things into my room and assemble some furniture. I could see just fine in the soft lazy orange glow.
Eddy. called my mother in a soft voice. Don't unpack right now, come here and sit with me.
But mom, I protested. We should, at least check to see who is standing guard for us tonight.
No one should be standing guard anymore. but as Gastonish thought about it she too became curious if the humans would be true to their words. She stood up and approached the door. Quietly Gastonish called to her sertz, careful not to reveal the existence of the small robot to me. Xonox, please sweep the area for the closest humans to this dwelling. opening the door just a crack to peek out Gastonish allowed her sertz to slip through unnoticed into the night.
Before long Xonox returned and flew into Gastonishs ear. MAJESTY, THE CLOSEST HUMANS ARE THOSE LIVING IN NEIGHBORING DWELLINGS.
Neighbours Eddy, the only people out there, live in distant homes and they are our neighbours. So just sit, Eddy... Please? My mother comfortably curled up onto the sofa with a warm smile. I pulled the couch, angling it to see both the fire and the scenery. Words were not spoken, but feelings were exchanged through our heightened volk senses. More specifically these were feelings of comfort, peace and freedom.

After about a week, I felt so much more comfortable at my new home. My mother and I would plan what we were going to do with the area around our home. I had great plans of building unrealistic projects which were unnecessary, for example, a sixty foot tall look out tower with an elevator which was powered by the circulation of water, or my idea of an elaborate underground bunker which could sustain life for years. Though my ideas would have worked, they were more optimistic than practical. I had a knack, as a boy, to set huge goals for myself. My mother always supported my ideas, no matter how outrageous they may have been. In the end she would persuade me to do the lesser, more rational of the ideas. I built a bridge which crossed a small stream that ran through our backyard, a wood shed and a strange insect hotel of my mothers design. Her fascination for insects was not strange to me as a child, but interesting. She spoke about insects with great enthusiasm and admiration.
We had to go to the Islands lumber yard for supplies. Everyone who worked there was interested in me and they always had a compliment concerning my strength. Mom would use the phone and ask for a ride. Shortly after, Dr. Evon would arrive driving yet another one of the Islands famous old pick-up trucks, which he used to take us into the town.
The road weaved in and out of the Islands folds as we circled around to the north side. The Island was small and the town, set deep into a crevice, was no bigger than half a dozen old cabins. Much of the Islands roads and land markings were through large dug out portals or other odd gnarly shapes. When I turned from the dream like Island and looked out across the vast ocean, it was like we were the last survivors of a worldwide flood. It wasn't just lonely, it was eerie.              
                                 
 It was not long before other people began arriving to the Island. They appeared to be simple civilians. The people were relatively good hearted and simple to figure out. The Island was like a seed and a small community developed from it. I soon started school again. The new comers to the Island wore casual clothing; jeans, T-shirts and boots, and other items of the sort. Dr. Evon and his unit wore strikingly clean white lab coats and all military personnel wore camouflage uniforms. Even with my precise sharp perception, I was not always able to notice a soldier against the thick growth of the Island right away.
Only a few weeks after arriving to the Island, my mother was taken away from me to begin her reconstructive surgery. Once again she managed to negotiate terms to bribe officials and bend her desires to her will. Dr. Evon took care of me during my mothers absence. I was able to keep in contact with her through the doctors portable computer terminal and two way video, but I was not allowed to visit her. I pictured my mothers face after a successful surgery as one where she would be the most beautiful volk ever. I imagined all human women envious of her beauty. Huge magazine labels would offer her millions of dollars to have her photo on their magazine covers to be distributed around the world. Only, as the governments best kept secret, this would likely not happen, no matter what she looked like.
When she finally returned, I blocked my feelings of longing to hug her and kiss her. She did not look like the same mother who left me before the operation. She looked remarkably like a human yet odd facial features such as over developed cheek bones, chin and eyebrows were unmistakable trademarks. Not to mention, her over all skull was noticeably, yet subtly larger than everyone elses. Her height and build also contributed to her noticeable differences which also added to the proof how a human impostor could not pull off such a masquerade. However, her skin was pink and smooth, but there was one draw back, she was unable to grow hair. She was given an assortment of wigs and she liked them all. It wasn't until she spoke to me and our minds touched when I knew, without a doubt, she was my authentic mother. What do you think, Eddy? I sensed she was uncertain if she could pull off a successful human look as well.
I wont lie to you, mom. It may take some time to get used to it, but in comparison to the severe damaged skin you had before, it is certainly an improvement. I smiled to her with loving assurance.
I agree with that, Eddy. And this skin is so much more comfortable. She confirmed as she stroked the bare skin of her left arm.
It only took a day or two for me to begin feeling comfortable with my mothers new human appearance, but the feeling soon grew into discrimination. As she began to seem more accepted into the human world, I was more like the one and only freak. My mother was no longer a volk like me and it was like a silent wedge had been driven between us from that point on which would last a long time after.

One clear sunny day, mom and I decided to pack light and go hiking up the steep mountain. The sun was hot but we were safe under the canopy of trees. Because of the Islands single peek, we began to climb its steepness a few feet from our home. Do you like school? asked my mother, breaking the silence. She leaned hard onto a walking stick which she had carved. 
Sure, the work is easy, and I am learning something new either on the computer or in the components of the computer every day. I responded as I pushed bushes out of my way. We were not a trail, rather we were on a heading which was simply up.
Eddy, remember when I told you I could get you to meet someone who could give you a much better education than anyone else on earth could? She swung one of her long blond braids back behind her shoulder. 
I remember. It sounds too good to be true! What do you mean, like tutoring at home? When can we start? I paused in mid stride to hear Gastonishs answer clearly.
Today. She answered confidently with a sense of being in control and of possessing power, but she would not elaborate further.
We made our way over a small ridge to an equally small clearing. We have much to discuss. I know you are hurting, Eddy. While I was pregnant with you, I hoped you would grow to become exactly who you are, a healthy Volk. You are normal all right, in fact, six months before you were born, I looked much like you do now, and before that your father and I had just been married.
You and Mulunac, right? I cut in.
Thats right, only at the time we went to the Genation nebula, not only did your father die, but I believe something else happened, something very strange. The on-board navigational system malfunctioned and sent me to this uncharted planet. She explained while pondering her own words.
Hold it, mom. Every time you start talking about dad, you always make up this ridiculous planet called Verticus before you tell me about Genation. As much as you explain Genation, I still haven't got the foggiest idea of what it really is. Are you covering up for something else? I want the truth. I spoke as stern as I could, but moms face did not falter and I knew whatever she was saying really meant something to her.
I am telling you the truth! She raised her voice. Now sit down, Eddy, because for once, you are going to hear the truth.
I sat on a damp mossy topped rock which was directly behind me. Mom remained on her feet, pacing back and forth as she talked. I put one hand down on the moss and gave her my full attention.
As I was saying. Your father and I were in our Zandith Crockmior, racing through space. Your father wanted to take me some place special. Soon we came upon a beautiful twin nebula. Volks call it the Genation nebula. He was abducted by some strange blue lights which took him away like some sort of comet. I, still within the Zandith Crockmior, was sucked into the blue twin before our navigational processors began to fail. You and I are lucky to be alive. She turned and sat down looking at the scenery. The sun luminously lit the clouds over the horizon with the most dazzling colors of yellow and golden orange. If only I remembered a camera, for the fiery beauty was surrounded with a strange stillness from a clear sky of soft blues and purples. As we watched the light dancing over the edges of the clouds, beams of sunlight stabbed through and reflected off the distant waves. We sat in silence for some time. My mother was obviously lost in her thoughts.
Well, what do you say about moving on, I mean we did start hiking, why don't we finish. We can talk on the way. I tried to break the tension and pick up the pace. She took a deep cleansing breath and stood up. You can explain what a Zandith Crockmior is to me? I added, she loved hearing me ask questions like that and I think she enjoyed explaining such things to me. A few feet into our continued hike, I question which I would consider odd at any other time. Mom, is Verticus really that much better than this world?
Good question, Eddy. I would say as far as a natural world, this planet is amazing. It can sustain life easily without assistance. Verticus has been going through Volk alterations since the beginning of time. Everything and anything you might need is readily available for you. When I first came here to this planet, I was so anxious to go home I became very prejudice toward this world. But lately, more than ever, I have found myself stopping to take in the natural beauty which surrounds us.
The path became very narrow, and the left side dropped away down a cliff to a roaring creek below. Eddy, don't you like this world you live in today? She started.
I can't imagine a better world. I replied.
I can. A glint in her eye and a dreamy lull in her voice told me I touched a nerve. I know a world without so much danger. War is an ancient idea of the past, volks are more peaceful, and there is plenty of food, water, housing and personal care for everyone. I could go on forever.
Don't bother, I cut in. What you're describing is a boring carefree world. When do you grow up, take responsibility or get some excitement?
Oh, well, I guess I'm not explaining myself clearly enough then, because Volks are very mature. They take so much responsibility it would break a human. And excitement? Have you been sleeping in the past when I have spoken of your father and the adventures we had? In your eyes, my up-bringing on Verticus would seem like a life lived in a fantasy world, but this is a primitive world. Just consider this situation if it were reversed. We are human, I'm your daughter and we've found ourselves stranded on an Island occupied by a primitive culture, like cavemen, explain this world in such a way I'll believe you. We may have the capability of fire, if not, you could provide it and those who dwelt among us would think of us as freaks. You try to explain your home of automobiles and air planes...
Okay, okay, I've got the point. I told her with typical adolescent behaviour.
Eddy... you see? Nobody understands how hard it has been for me. She added and it all began to sink in for me and become clear. I was beginning to believe her.
If this story really is true, then you are suggesting we need to find a way to travel through space. I looked up to the sky and smiled, before I brought my gaze back down to my mother. I can't wait to hear how you plan to work this out. I mean how exactly are we supposed to get back to where we belong? Build a radio or beacon? Because you can not seriously suggest you and I are going to build a space ship.
My sertz can not establish contact with our kind but I believe there is another way. She cocked her fake eyebrow as a plan began to come together, You are going down into Anderson Lake to retrieve the Zandith Crockmior L/X. Then you will repair any salvageable components.
Ya, sure mom. I commented only half listening to her and the strange words she used. I found it tiresome to question every word I didn't understand. Whatever you say. I added sarcastically. It would be like sending a monkey to be a mechanic.
You are four years old and the insectular is most likely damaged beyond repair, not to mention the excessive abuse it took from its mid-flight battle. Your father would probably try a retrieval operation, so I will have to get you a tutor to teach you to think like he thought. She raised her head and said. Xonox!
I thought my mother had finally done it. She was definitely coo-coo. As she tilted her ear to me, a small pink light emerged and said, WHAT MAY I DO FOR YOU, ROMULAW?
Xonox, I would like you to meet Eddy, my son. She said. The small object came closer to me and as it did I could see its fine detail more clearly.
Its a small robot! I exclaimed with exuberance. It sure is tiny. I added.
Yes, its my sertz, its name is Xonox. Xonox, bring to us Mulunacs sertz.
JUST A MOMENT, MAJESTY. The robot spoke before it took off in a blurry streak.
Majesty? I questioned. Did I also hear it refer to you as, Romulaw?
Thats right, all sertz refer to their female consort as Majesty, Romulaw or more elegantly Romlessa. It is a gesture of respect and loyalty and a great honor from ones sertz not to be taken for granted. When Xonox reappeared, it was accompanied with another new, slightly bigger, sertz. 
Was the Zandith Crockmior damaged? Can we salvage anything from it? Gastonish asked Xonox.
THE ZANDITH CROCKMIOR HAS ALMOST ENTIRELY ROTTED AWAY, YOUR MAJESTY. My mothers eyes were so innocent and helpless. WHAT IS LEFT IS ITS OUTER INSECT SKELETON, AND SOME ITEMS WHICH THE LATE MULUNAC WORE AT THE TIME OF HIS DEATH AND A LARVA POD STILL IN STASIS. From the report, Gastonish gained her strength back, and some. She smiled contently as she turned my way. She walked over to me and rolled up my sleeve.
Eddy, hold out your palm.
I did what she asked and the bigger sertz came over to me and examined my hand.
CLOSE YOUR EYES. spoke the words of the bigger sertz.
I closed them and I was concentrating on the nerves in my open hand. I felt a pinch.
My hand!!! I yelled, as I quickly jerked my hand back. What did it do, mom?
Don't worry Eddy, it had to examine your cell structure to find matching relative code to confirm you are Mulunacs true son. she explained away my short lived pain.
Why didn't you just tell me it would pinch?! I exclaimed as an attention thirsty child does.
I didn't want you to move your hand away. This sertz with these four small rockets, or repulsars, behind it was once your fathers. It has deactivated and remained that way ever since your father died. You have come of legal age to inherit his sertz and it has been reactivated. This sertz has found a new purpose to continue on for you. The sertz of Verticus are all linked through the sertz central collective. Where I come from they share important, up to date information. This system assisted all volks to share and collaborate information and learn in unison. At first you will find your sertz is over run with information as it will thumb print our history to your mind. Since our sertz have lost contact with the central sertz collective we can not be informed of events to date. Your father called his sertz Zip because of the noise it made at high speeds. When you name your sertz, your last name will become its first name, meaning your fathers full name was Mulunac Zip. My name is Gastonish Xonox. Your name is Eddy...?
Evon. I answered proudly, because Dr. Evon was the closet person I knew who fit to a father figure in my life.
Chapter 5

Our steep trail joined a dirt road 600 meters above sea level. From where we were we could see much of the Island below. The movement of people and vehicles through the small town was comical. My mother and I tried to point out things to one another asking; Is that the road which leads to the huge open cave at the beach? Gastonish started.
That must be the ferry dock in the harbor. I pointed enthusiastically.
Yes, it sure looks small from here. Added my mother as she squinted her eyes to see the distant ferry.
Seeing with the eyes of a volk is superior over what humans see through their eyes, right? We often had humans on our minds.
It would be difficult to make that assumption unless we could see with human eyes and compare. Gastonish answered nodding her head. In light of many other comparisons, Im sure our eye sight is superior. Gastonish filled her lungs with the salty breeze before she let it out with a new thought. This place has been created to give the observer the impression this is an insignificant Island full of poverty and out of touch from the sophistication abroad.
We took notice of the thin air and though we climbed a long way we still had a long way to go. To traverse the Island was to find out just how big it really was. We decided to mark the spot and return there again one day. Heading down the dirt road, famished and sweating from head to toe we longed to collapse on the beds of our cabin. Gastonish was so hot and sweaty, she even took her wig off. 
I should have been admiring the trees and the fresh woodland scents, or the sun on my face, but the only thing on my mind was my sertz.
As my mother and I were walking down the dirt road, I started talking to both her and my new tutor and friend, Evon. Every question I asked was answered and I had a lot of questions. We found our theories for getting back to Verticus were no less unique and innovative but uncertain. To be prepared for the possibility we would not return, we decided I should stay in school and complete my education.
When things quieted down, my sertz flew into my ear. I was so surprised I was filled with fear. I slapped and dug at my ear to get the sertz out. Though my mother tried to assist me, she could not understand what was going on. Eddy! Are you in pain? She was half worried there was a life threatening problem. I fell to the ground screaming for help. I thought my sertz had gone berserk and was trying to attack me. Is your sertz causing you pain?
I thought about what she said and sure enough, the sertz was not causing me pain. It was invading my ear, trespassing in an uncomfortable and violating tickle. I heard my mother tell me, Just let it go. I focused on her eyes as we locked our arms together. I breathed and tried to accept the living nightmare of having the strange sertz establish itself inside my head. The incident did not last long until I felt it move. Struggling under my mothers powerful hold, I resisted. As Gastonish talked me through the moment, her soothing words helped me to understand what was happening. Soon after, Gastonish explained how it was normal for a sertz to reside within a volks ear. 
Eddy, your sertz, when anchored to the cranium within your ear, can assist the mind to help deal with problems or feelings. It will deliver peace in times when there is no peace. It can help your body to remedy many illnesses and it has the capability to translate thoughts telepathically. It functions as an aided shipper & receiver of thought. It can shut off pain if you are injured so the pain does not distract you, if you so wish. She put her hand on my head and gently slid it down over my cheek. There is so much it can do for you that one day you will wonder how you ever survived without it. But keep in mind it is important your sertz is not discovered. Everything depends on it. My sertz has done very well, so far, and it is best to have it hidden in your ear. This way you can keep an open communication with it in private. Make sure it leaves if you know of any X-ray or surprise body searches.
Oh, how uncomfortable it was to have to adjust to a sertz parking itself in my ear. It took some serious getting used to. The road led us all the way back to the cabin. Despite the many twists and turns our journey home was only a fraction of the time it took for us to hike up.
The night sky was particularly clearer. The stars were so bright and the constellations, so apparent. We sat outside on the porch. Mom and I had the most interesting conversations as we stared up at the twinkling depths which shrouded us. The air was fresh and sweet, a perfect temperature with just the right breeze. My mother and I talked, but that particular night was not a casual conversation. We planned our first attempt to bring the Zandith Crockmior out of the lake and onto the shore.
This Island does not have a boat dock or any boats we can steal. I suppose the people who have arrived don't feel like they will ever leave. The only way on or off the Island is through use of the transport which brought the people and ourselves here. I have asked Dr. Evon if you and I could go to the main land. His reply was the main land was unsafe. This Island is not on any charts so people will not be visiting. The Doctor has gone to great lengths to give us a life of freedom on this Island. And we would jeopardize our life of seclusion if we were to leave, but I believe we must risk everything to get to the Zandith Crockmior, before its too late.
How do we get off the Island, exactly? my intention was to get right to the point and ask how do we get to Verticus, but obviously steps would need to be taken.
We must wait until you have your day of sleep. Dr. Evon knows your sleeping schedule so you must force yourself to somehow sleep a day early. We will stuff our beds to let it seem as though we are sleeping in them. When it is dark, you and I will go to the transport ferry at the beach and sneak aboard. The ferry will take us to the main land where we will find the lake and the Zandith Crockmior L/X. We will be given an entire day where no one should suspect we left.
Okay, lets say your plan could somehow get us off this Island. How are we going to get to Anderson lake, recover the Zandith Crockmior, repair it and return to our world without Dr. Evon realizing we are missing and starting a global government search? And if he does start a search, Anderson Lake would certainly be on his list of places to look.
If we were to take longer than expected, then their efforts will not matter because once we are at the Zandith Crockmior, we will be as good as gone.
All right. I said. So I'll use my scuba diving gear and search the location where its buried. If I find it, I'll retrieve as many items as I can. I will go down a second time and try to move it. I paused for a second, trying to think of all of the possibilities which might endanger our plan.
Satellites. I said, and jerked with the thought. It was highly improbable yet, still I felt it would be a good idea to hide the craft as we pulled it ashore. I read in magazines how satellites are able to take photo-graphs of a mouse in a field, or the license plate of a car. Knowing this, we should hide the craft, not only from satellites, but from other surveillance possibilities.
Then we'll set camp. My mother abruptly cut in.
What will we use to pitch a camp? I asked.
All I need to do is get us to the lake, from there everything else will be easy. Leave it all to me, Eddy. She stood up and went back into the cabin, thus ended the conversation. Obviously she knew more than she was telling me, but her instructions were, To get to the Lake. And it just wasnt good enough for me.

As days passed, I was unable to think about anything but the plan. Gastonish also became lost in deep thought on many occasions. Altering my pattern of sleep was necessary but no simple task. I was not tired so I had to take many cat-naps through out the day. I could not simply say I was feeling sick because it would cause the doctors and nurses to pay more attention to me. Besides they knew the capabilities of my immune system. I had never been sick in the past. Before I knew it the time arrived, I could see the anticipation in my mothers eyes.
We silently went to work, rolling up blankets and stuffing them under the sheets of the beds. We used pillows to add the curvatures of our decoyed bodies. My eyes were much sharper than my mothers when it came to seeing in the dark. The Island was darker than we anticipated, and the sliver of moonlight gave us little to no assistance.
Through a pre planned short-cut which led us through the forest, we quickly arrived at the beach where the ferry transport was. We were not sure about its schedule, so we waited for a while to see if it was ready to leave. The men who were in the area did not seem to be in any rush to get their jobs done and go. They sat and talked and smoked cigarettes. Somehow, my mother and I were going to create a diversion while we snuck across the beach to the transport, but how? Gastonish had all of the answers. She figured if we were caught and questioned it would be better if I really did not know the details of her plans.
My mother took me by the hand and led me through the woods around to a nearby empty flatbed five ton truck. She slowly opened the passenger door and helped me in. She crawled in behind me and made certain her head was low. She reached out and took the receiver from the C.B. She pressed the button and listened. I shifted my weight to get more comfortable and she shushed me to be quiet. She switched the channel of the C.B. and pressed the button again. Still she did not hear anything from the loud speaker. She tried once more with the next channel and the C.B. aboard the transport made a clicking noise. My mother made certain she heard it by asking me to listen and she clicked it a few more times. I did in fact hear it and acknowledged it to my mother.
Transport vessel. My mother spoke into the C.B.
A man near the ferry hopped up onto the deck and entered the small navigation room. This is the Caruso, Over. The man spoke and his voice came through our C.B. as clear as a bell. Mom quickly turned the volume switch down.
You are required to return to the mainland immediately. Oh, and don't forget to take the truck with you. I was amazed at the risk my mother took.
Control, this is captain Jonathan Chase, of the Caruso. I have no report confirming a boat launch at this time, nor the passage of cargo of any kind.
We know, there are people who require the truck on the mainland and it is very important. Just came up. It was obvious mom was not a master at the language of CBs. I wondered how long she could successfully keep it up.
This is not standard procedure, who is this? Give me your operating number.
That is not necessary. You are required to follow orders, now take the truck and move. All of the um, clearance sheets will be ready for you to sign when you reach the mainland. Gastonish had great confidence she was going to complete her mission, and it showed.
All right, but I don't like it. Now what truck am I supposed to take with me?
Uh, we have assigned a driver to the truck who is supposed to have its lights on. This is the truck you are to take. You may confirm this request with him. My mother had a slightly slow reaction time. The captain looked out of the boat just as mom turned on the head lights.
With an experienced eye and hardened faced which had been weathered by years of life out on the open sea, Captain Jonathan Chase glared suspiciously at the headlights shining from the road. With a gnarly old under bite of white whiskers, the captain shouted, Aye, soldier, bring yer rusty over haul down here.! Waving his arms wide to signal the driver to approach. The only piece of uniform the old captain wore was his captains hat. Surely, his dirty t-shirt and pants were not up to code.
Gastonish started the engine and eased the truck forward slowly as she neared the dock.
The captain tensed up as he tossed his receiver onto the counter and walked toward us. He walked along the beach within the brightness of the headlights. He lifted his hand to shield his eyes and tried to get a look at the driver. Walking around at a distance from the side of the truck, he saw a figure sitting in the front seat looking down.
As he approached he realized it was the face of a woman wearing a cap with her hair tied back. They said you were going to be a guy. The captain said as he reached out for the handle of the door. I am captain Jonathan Chase, and you are?
I heard him fidget with his keys in his pocket with one hand. He had his other hand on the holster of his side arm. He let go of his keys and cautiously opened the squeaky hinged door and my mother sprung out of the truck surprising him. While the captain struggled in my mothers grip, he managed to pull out his gun, but it slipped from his fingers and fell to the sand. Gastonish restrained the captain and pulled him into the cab with great strength. She held the mans mouth and pushed a small metal pipe against his back. Move or make a sound and we will have to clean up a big mess! Mom whispered in his ear.
What do you want? The man asked in fear. It was pitch black. Others on the beach could not see past the headlights of the truck and the captain did not know who we were or if it was in fact a real gun at his back.
You are going to take us off this Island. Now load this truck onto the transport and get us out of here.
The captain drove the truck up the ramp of the transport and turned it off. Another man from the beach approached carrying a flashlight and hollered. Hey, Jonathan, is that you?
Gastonish nudged the captain with the metal pipe and said, Get out and answer him.
The captain stepped out while Gastonish held his wrist in the truck. A slight change of plans Harry, I am to return to the mainland with this truck.
I was not notified. The man behind the flashlight said.
I just got off the com with the brass. They will confirm it.
Okay, whatever, I just work here. The captain was unable to give a sign of his distress in the unstable flashlight beam. Have a safe trip, buddy.
When the flashlight dropped away mom crawled out after the captain, her grip was like a vise. They moved into the small control bridge of the transport. Mom smashed the overhead light as the engine started so the captain could not see her face. I climbed out after and stood by the door.
You know, once Harry calls in to confirm my departure, they will come looking for me. We will all probably die unless we turn back right now. Please, I have a family.
Nice try, but I saw your friend was not in any hurry to phone anyone. Now is this the throttle? Gastonish lurched the throttle forward and the ferry belched as the old motor thundered.
When we were quite some distance from the Island, a voice came over the C.B. and asked a question. Gastonish instructed the captain to report problems of static over the air-waves. Communication was null. Next, Gastonish tied up the captain in thick rope. She used her pipe and smashed the C.B. in both the ferry and the truck.
In the soft hue of morning light my mother and I could see the mainland crest the horizon. The captain was terrified when he could recognize us in the morning light. Apparently, he must have known we were the secret of the Island.
Why do you seem so frightened? My mother asked him.
I was told not to ever speak of the Island to any one nor was I permitted to take people near there, but you... you are the reason, aren't you. The Island is probably full of strange people like you. We will probably see a flash of jets pass us over head then, BOOM! We will be blown-up. The captain sincerely believed what he said. Sweat dripped from his fore-head.
Fortunately, Harry did not bother to investigate the captains abrupt departure. No military air-force came to blast us out of the water nor was there anyone to greet us when we came ashore.
We did not plan to take a hostage, but the captain continued to make things a whole lot easier. My mother and I could not have navigated the ferry and we had no idea how to drive the truck. Though we would have liked to let the captain go, we needed him to drive us to Anderson Lake. It was also a good way to keep an eye on him, otherwise he would just squeal on our plans.
Mom dropped the metal pipe and untied the captain as the ferry strode into shallow water. So, you didn't have a gun after all. The captain realized as he examined us carefully. He took a good long look at me; short, grey skinned, bald and heavily muscled. Fixing his eyes on my mother he studied her as well; tall, strong with an inhuman bone structure. She had dark hair tied back into a pony tail from her accentuated facial features.
 The ropes slipped off the captain and he surprised us, as he attacked my mother. He pounded on her stomach with his fists. I ran to assist her but before I could do anything, my mother reached around and grabbed the captain by the back of his shirt. She lifted him off her. Gastonish was quite taller than the captain, and her long strong arms held him a safe distance away. The captain swung his arms and tried to kick her, but he could not reach her.
Now, now. My mother taunted the captain like he was a child. I could kill you faster with my bare hands than I could with any weapon. Now, slow us down and park this thing on the beach then drive us to Anderson Lake. She tossed him to prove her strength was for real and the captain collapsed to the deck like a rag doll. The captains face flushed to a pale white, and his eyes twitched with fear.
The captain wiped the blood from his nose and stood up awkwardly. He did as she commanded. The ferry slid onto the rugged Canadian shore line. The ramp fell and we drove off on our way to Anderson Lake.
I opened the glove compartment and started pulling things out. Gastonish reached down and plucked a map out of the clutter of junk. She opened it.
We just need to read a few street signs to find our location on the map. I offered.

     The energy bubble appeared with a sound like an electrical hiccup. The pink bubble took us down the mountain, over and across the small town and tree-tops and further out over Anderson Lake to a small pile of rocks which marked the burial sight of the Zandith Crockmior L/X.

The projection altered to a state of light and dark blue hues. Ghostly blotches of blue circular shapes structured over top of the mountains. I realized I was observing an X-ray of the mountain.
Everything in blue... represents each large solid rock... within the mountain... You may find this representation strange... but it is the most accurate way... for us to see the separation of sediment from solid mass. explained the Ornock. We will find the biggest... and most suitable rock... to hollow out a stable cave for you... and your son to repair your insect vehicle.
We turned to the yellow screens and noticed a beam of light emitted from somewhere under the ship. This light penetrated the steep mountain side. The light was like a great laser and it eased into the rock like a needle into flesh. We saw the biggest blue solid rock with a line scorched into the center of it by the light. When the light stopped, a black metal sphere was immediately launched directly into the center of the mountain through the scorched corridor. While the sphere was in the center, it began to vibrate. Next, it began to move about within the rock, leaving a tunnel behind it. As the sphere made its way hollowing out the inside of the rock, it would jet dust and small rock debris out through the mouth of the new corridor. The plume of fine debris resembled a young volcano letting off a little steam. I watched as a throat-like tunnel was dug connecting to a large empty stomach shaped cave. At the base of the large stomach shaped chamber were twelve separate smaller chambers.
Finally, the Ornocks sent a long thin tentacle into the caves mouth from the vorogon. The tentacle sprayed the interior of the cave to give it a crushed crystal effect to the walls. Later, as the crystals grew, they gave light and stability to the dwelling of the cave.
My mother and I were getting nervous. Though the ornocks were working extremely fast, I could not shake the feeling the air force would intervene if we took any longer.
The sphere finished its work and returned to the vorogon. From the organic amber bubble-like viewing monitor, we could see a great empty cave with pillars through the blue translucent forms of great mountainous rock.
Gastonish spoke to the Queen Ornock, We must leave quickly. No more time for talk. The Queen nodded her consent as she controlled the long tentacle to retract out from the cave. My mother and I had been throughout the halls of the vorogon enough times to know where we were going. We quickly ran through the vorogons dark tunnels before we reached the cargo hold of the dismembered Zandith Crockmior.
An Ornock telepathically told Gastonish of a rock or boulder outside the entrance of the cave. Only my mother or I could move it to open or seal the entrance to our cave because it was touch activated. Our touch to this boulder would also make the crystals glow within the cave. All of this was powered by the force of a waterfall which roared as it dropped from a height of over two hundred feet. The narrow water fall slunk over a flat protruding rock plateau of the mountainside and plummeted through a deep nearby ravine.
The Queen, surrounded by her loyal Ornocks, approached us to pay her final respects... a respect which was mutually and unjustly short lived. No words were spoken and no thoughts were exchanged as though neither Gastonish or the Ornocks wanted to tamper with their delicate final understanding. The Queen caringly tilted her head to one side as she studied Gastonishs expression of emotion. It was time for the mind wipe.
Stepping to the side with her thin legs, the Queen waved one of her Ornocks passed her. The Ornock held a large object the size of a dinosaur egg. When he held it out to us we saw it was the life-boat from the Zandith Crockmior L/X. A synthetic larva encased within a stasis cocoon as signaled by the green light which pulsed near the top. The Ornock handed the object to my mother and Gastonish graciously accepted it first bowing to the Ornock then to the Queen.
The parts and pieces of the once great Zandith Crockmior L/X began to float up from off the floor. The pieces moved through the air and circled around us magically. Shortly after, the bottom of the vorogon opened. At the same moment, my stomach began to feel very light. I was paralyzed once more, but it did not scare me this time. I rose off the floor along side Gastonish before I started to unintentionally lean back, until I was in a comfortable recliner position. My mother, cradling the life-boat in her arms, was immobile as I was, as we floated out of the aperture. I looked up to see where we were headed and I noticed the pieces of the Zandith Crockmior L/X entered the mouth of the cave before us.
The mountain air was cold and damp with a slight breeze, the likes of which were expected from most nights. After returning to earth, I learned not to take such pleasures for granted. I remember the deep breaths of fresh air I took. The moist stale air within the vorogon was like o-zone and uncomfortable to breathe, even for a volk. I had a sense of security when I was brought back to the planet, as though I was back home.
We landed safely on our feet on a level landing area just outside the caves entrance. When we turned to the vorogon, we saw a thin red beam hit the Earth only a meter from where we stood. The beam came from the vorogon and it zigzagged down the mountain. When the beam stopped, a clear trail was the result, complete with switch-backs. 
Gastonish stood up and suddenly I was aware of what she was about to do. She linked her mind to the Queens one last time. Gastonish surprised them all by turning an old trick of theirs against them. Just as they have abducted humans and put them back with no recollection of their alien encounter and experiences, she erased their short term immediate memories and set them in the same situation just before Gastonish sent a mental signal out to them with the use of her sertz, Xonox.
The vorogon became red hot and glowed with waves of energy moving across its surface like fire. Hot red fumes were expelled at random along the outer hull. The ground around us shook in the low humming vibrations of the vorogons power. With tremendous speed it shrunk away into the distance where it became one with the stars.
She turned her head and looked down at me, Well, we may not be home, but we now have a dependable means to get home all on our own.
Will the Ornocks ever return? I wondered.
If I call them they will, but until then they shouldnt bother us. Gastonish reassured me.
I dont ever want to see them again. As an after thought I asked, Shouldnt we be worried the Ornocks might discover these repressed memories? I asked her.
I did not repress anything. That would be their method. No, I erased the entire experience from them all. Her answer was definite. Gastonish inhaled deeply through her nose, taking in the fresh mountain air. She scanned across our view of the lake below and the distant mountains. Eddy, Verticus is Earth. her voice full of wonderment. Gastonish realized Verticus was not quite so far away anymore, before she smiled down at me. I have a new appreciation for this world. I nodded back at her reassuringly, her face hardened and I could see she was concentrating on the work at hand.
My mother and I realized the repairs were going to take much longer than we first planned. After testing the weightlessness of the protective boulder, Gastonish led me into the cave where we saw the disassembled parts of the Zandith Crockmior littered over the floor of the crystal lit cave. Before anything else could be done, we had to find away to properly store and keep the giant insect parts from draining all of its synthetic fluids onto the floor. Together, we structured a system where we allowed a trickling stream of water to fill a low sink hole area. We placed all of the insectular parts into the shallow water. It was crude, but it would keep the Zandith Crockmior from dehydrating.
The sound of running water gently trickling echoed throughout the cave. A small tunnel of water opened up to a stream at the far corner of the caves large belly. With a function which would put an old style water-wheel to shame, the alien design used the motion of the water to keep the protective boulder and glowing crystals active.
Mom, I don't think this is a safe place for us. I am sure we could live in this cave, but we were protected at the Island and the captain of the ferry is on his way to report this area as the last sighting of you and I. If the humans try to find us here, their will be no telling what devices will be used for their search. If they follow the scorched trail or detect the crystals which line these inner walls, we will be discovered for sure.
Gastonish looked at me trying to find a simple answer for me. What do you think we should do about this?
Well, for starters, we could go back to the Island. I suggested with a shrug.
Go back to the Island? They would know we were gone. What good would that do anyway?
I am sure no one realized our disappearance yet. We really haven't been away for a very long time, its only been seven hours. The Knolix Island is still probably sleeping. Besides, it would keep the humans from any attempt at a search. We could use our hickoops and get to the Island in seconds. We will probably have time to spare before the captain of the ferry contacts his superiors and says anything. By the time anyone checks on us we will be in our home waiting to greet them at the door. If we go now, I could try to catch up on some lost sleep... A moment was lost as Gastonish considered. If we go now. I persisted.
I wanted to get busy setting up the larva life-boat of the Zandith Crockmior. Gastonish stated with eager eyes.
The life-boat has a strong stasis hold. I think we should leave now and come back later when we are more prepared. If we don't act now and get back to the Island, we won't have a second chance.
With a nod, she agreed. Using our hickoops we fled the mountain and return to the Island.

The voyage to the Island was as instantaneous as a blur. Xonox and Evon guided our hickoops. They were precise to the decimal point with their navigations. We moved through the atmosphere so our hickoops would blend in amongst the glow of the last remaining specks of morning stars. When we were directly over the Island, we dropped straight down to our home below. Branches of trees and fresh greenery withered and sizzled as our hickoops passed too close, instantly burning them to a dry brown crisp.
At ground level our hickoops popped as the energy bubble went out. We stepped off our hickoop frames and they folded up into their contained disk shape. Our suits were still glowing, so to keep from being discovered, we undressed. Without the light of our gear, I found it was very dark under the thick canopy of the forest. The small white glow of Xonox came out of Gastonish's hickoop disk and naturally entered her ear.
Evon came out of my hickoop immediately after with red glowing eyes. Using supernatural speed, Evon moved through the air and darted into my ear. My mother took me by the hand and led me through the dark. When we were about twenty meters to the door of our home, my mother stopped and said, Give me everything you are holding.
Why? I questioned quietly.
We need to hide them from the humans. She answered in a whisper.
Where will we hide them? Wondering if she had some place clever in mind.
I will take everything out into the woods and bury them out there.
Why can't we just use one of those old wooden crates outside, We can place everything in it and hide it under the porch? I suggested.
Too risky, they might find it when searching the cabin. You go ahead now and get into bed. I will be along soon when I am done.
I gave my arm load of objects to Gastonish. Next, I went in and was careful not to turn on the lights or bump into anything. I made my way to my bedroom where I stayed awake trying to listen for Gastonishs movements in the woods. She was very quiet. Finally, I heard Gastonish approach and enter the cabin and go to bed.
Images of what happened haunted my mind and did not allow me to sleep. Evon, please help me to not worry about Ornocks, Zandith Crockmiors, vorogons, hickoops and such, so I can get a good nights sleep. I felt a new hope for our future. Evon helped to soothe my mind. It was that sense of comfort which lulled me into a deep, deep sleep.

Jolted like some childs doll, I was awakened irritatingly as a soldier slapped me out of my sleep. Wake up! He said. You have some explaining to do!
The slap was more than enough to clear my thoughts as to what was going on. --Interrogation. The captain told his story and the soldiers were ordered to break into our home and prep us for questioning. I was in need of my entire twenty-four hour shut-eye and when I do not receive it I can become rather cranky.
Gastonish and I were treated like criminals, shackled at the ankles and wrists. Next we were taken out of our home to a clean white van which was parked outside. We were dressed in our pajamas and my mother did not have an opportunity to grab a wig before we were forced from our home. Within the van we were told to sit on leather seats. The captain of the transport ferry who took us to the mainland was there as well. Four field soldiers also accompanied us in the large van. They held automatic rifles across their chests.
Finally, the captain of the ferry lost it and bellowed out words of his patiently contained rage. Why did you leave this Island, and how did you return so fast?!! The captain spat, he was yelling so hard. His dirty unshaven face was beat red with anger. I was too tired to answer but my mother must have seen the captains aggression as a sign of weakness.
We were driven along the windy dirt road, littered with pot-holes. They took us right through the little town and finally to the beach where mom and I first high-jacked the ferry. On the beach people were alive and busy. Within the first light of the day, military personnel were measuring sections off at the shore line. Sure enough most of the activity was at the area where the ferry had been. I noticed a man pouring plaster moulds of certain foot-prints. This disturbed me. One Mi-17 helicopter was taking off from the beach as another was arriving. Further back from the shore a large tent was being pitched next to the steep over hanging rock cliff. We were heading in that direction. We had to wait in the van until the tent was fully assembled and the chairs were put in place within. Finally, we were directed from the van to the tent. Inside the tent, Gastonish and I were seated at the front before a panel of Island officials. Dr. Evon arrived and ran to my mother. He was so concerned and worried I dont believe I ever seen him like that before.
Gastonish, what have you done? Holding Gastonishs left hand with both of his hands. Dr. Evons left eye twitched in the corner. Gastonish gave him no expression to ease his curiosity. An Island official took Dr. Evon by the arm and walked him to a chair at the head of the tent. Dr. Evon reluctantly accompanied his companion to take his seat joining the panel of Island officials.
Would everyone please quiet down now? Spoke a bailiff loud and clear at the front of the tent. This inquiry is now in session.
A man at the center of the panel stood up and began to speak, It seems, an incident has been reported by captain Jonathan Chase of the transport ferry Caruso with the most unusual incident taking place here on the Island about thirteen hours ago. This counsel addresses Gastonish as to her story of what happened.
If it pleases this counsel, Gastonish began, I would like to have more information about what exactly took place. Thirteen hours ago my son and I were asleep, just as we were twenty minutes ago as well.
No! She lies!!! She lies! Captain Chase feared for his life. His head turned as he looked at everyone at a time. She is an evil, deceitful creature from hell. He had shifty eyes and his fore-head began to bead with sweat. The room was filled with the sounds of gasping breaths. The captain was losing control. Now, he was sweating from head to toe, his hands began to shake and his eyes shifted from side to side all the more. H-hey, comon, you guys dont actually believe her over me do you?
Gastonish played on the captains fear, she stood up to address the panel. May I speak with Dr. Evon outside for a moment? She asked calmly. Dr. Evon stood up promptly but a hand took his arm and gently motioned for him to sit down again. Dr. Evon looked down at the hand from an official military member seated beside him. He knew it was out of order to act without the panels support so he sat back down.
While this inquiry is in session, anything you say must be spoken amongst all of the ears present.
The fore-telling of my mothers eyes made it obvious she was clearly aggravated. Would somebody please fill me in on whats going on here? What happened last night? Demanded the judge.
The captain looked like a mess and he stared at my mother and I with red blood-shot eyes of stress and frustration. You freaks won't get away with this! The captain whispered. I don't know how you got back to this Island so fast, but I'm gonna make sure you both pay. He grumbled.
I stared right back at him, still cranky with a loss of sleep. You have all heard this man threaten us. I will hold you all accountable as witnesses if he tries to harm us in any way.
Gastonish hushed me. She didn't believe I needed to say anything. As Gastonish wanted to protect us, she knew it would take her voice to be heard and all I would have to do is keep quiet. She wasnt finished playing the counsel to her own music yet. Sir, my son and I are dead tired. We were awakened by your men and you know we need at least twenty-four hours of uninterrupted sleep. Gastonish worked her magic to assume the role of the victim, trying to tie emotions of her innocent grievance into each spoken word. 
This is correct, youre honor. Dr. Evon stood up for a moment and raised his hand to confirm Gastonishs statement.
What does that person mean? Does he believe we left the Island? Is it possible he was not expecting you would find us here?
Affirmative, ma'am, the captain has been flown out here to the Island by chopper and he had a report you and your son captured him and took him to the UFO crash sight of the mainland. He guaranteed us you would not be found here.
Gastonish smirked slightly and rolled her eyes. Obviously his information is not true. Perhaps you shackled the wrong people? If he did not expect you to find us, then perhaps he was working with some accomplices who had plans to steal us away.
Accomplices? An official repeated, surprised at the suggestion.
If I were you, I would be questioning who it is the captain is really working for. Gastonish said with a stern nod of expectancy which suggested the officer conduct a more thorough investigation before he started breaking down peoples doors.
Searching the ground for the answer with his eyes frantically, the official felt compelled to agree with Gastonish. I agree ma'am. the official spoke politely. We do seem to have some inconclusive facts here which leads us to find out if there is more beneath the surface of these accusations. Certain aspects of the captains story do not add up. Sorry to disturbed your sleep but we have a situation here of misconduct and the matter must be investigated thoroughly. I suggest we take a short recess now and reconsider this case. Gastonish and Eddy are to remain nearby as, we will need to question you again. If we find there has been any sort of foul play by you or your son, Eddy, last night, you will find yourselves over your head in discipline. The officials saluted Gastonish and I. We were instructed to stand up and follow a soldier back out to the van. We sat down in the van and the shackles were quickly removed.
We were driven home a few hours after the hearing resumed and we did not hear from the captain ever again. That evening mom and I did not speak much, but we communicated plenty through our telepathy. We wondered if the soldiers would be back and we had a feeling, if they returned, it would be to finish us. Gastonish was certain the Island officials would find another way to control us besides discipline. From one mind to another, Gastonish told me how she regretted using the captain as she did, but she was determined to get us home and nothing would get in the way of that.

A few days after, Dr. Evon issued special fillings for the teeth of my mother and I. After our teeth were drilled, we were told a highly sensitive micro-chip was implanted in our teeth. The micro-chip was a tracking device which was monitored by satellites in orbit. It was a security factor to ensure the safekeeping of government property. This would have made it difficult to become settled in our strange alien working environment at the cave without being detected but Gastonish was always one step ahead.
Gastonish came up with detailed instructions, with the help of the romstrunn, to surgically extract the micro-chips but leave a slot big enough to reinsert the chip in case of an inspection. Otherwise, the sertz could hold the small chip or the chips could simply be left behind when we decided to leave the Island.
They made it mandatory for my mother and I to wear permanent tattoos on the side of our right biceps. The tattoo designs were of a planet and eagle with the words, Property of the U.S.A. They branded me with four small numbers under the tattoo, 2002 and my mothers number was 2001. My mother strongly disapproved of the tattoos and branding but it made little difference after it was finished. How could I forget the anger which burned in my mothers deep black eyes that day or how her red hair seemed to add to her kindled fury. The tattoos were tender for a few days but we became used to them eventually.
The Island officials decided to restrict any boat and ferry activity to as little as possible. It was as though I did not see any activity on the ocean after that point unless a transport arrived to unload a few more people and supplies to the Island.
I tried to keep my distance from the new comers as I was sure it was stressful enough for them arriving to the strange uncharted Island and settling in without worrying about the likes of me.

One of the new arrivals to the Knolix Island was a young boy, around my age who went by the name Domin. I heard he was muscular and mean and he had an accident with an animal in transport. The accident left him injured but I wasnt sure how serious it was. This particular boy, Domin, had a mysterious shroud about him.
I sent Evon to fly near to the new comers and study their faces from above eye level. Evon was very adept at keeping from being noticed. Images appeared on the display of my romstrunn. I stood at the window of an old mill where I was busy conducting a weather experiment. From that location I had a distant view of the five transport ships unloading near the sandy shore.
When I first saw Domin, Evon had captured a view of him stepping out of the hospital in the town of Scamp. Though he was using crutches to walk, I recognized him immediately. Domin was much larger than the others and he was practically as large as a volk. Dark raccoon like tattoos around his eyes made him seem to be haunted. His face certainly was cruel looking, like he was mad at the entire world, save a doctor who stood by Domins side and seemed familiar to me somehow. A white bandage of gauze and surgical tape covered the injury on his cheek. Some of his blood had seeped through the bandage to the surface. Domin also had a cast upon his chest.
The rest of Domins face was riddled with scars. A few of the skin patches looked discolored, as though some of his skin was like Eddys volk grey skin tone.
I quickly discredited the possibility of Domin being part volk because I knew all too well how impossible it was for human and volk to amalgamate.
Domin wore a toque over the crown of his head. His clothes were rather military in design with a black shirt, dark brown vest and dark green pants. They must have been custom fit clothes much like my own, I figured.

With any opportunity my mother would discretely suit up into her glowing futuristic suit. Gastonish made our sertz understand that when we climbed onto the hickoops and left, we would travel only a few seconds to reach one of only two destinations, the cave on the mainland or our cabin home on the Island. The journey to the cave was so fast, in itself, it lost its sense of excitement. It was like we straddled our hickoops and an energy bubble flashed to life around us, before we instantaneously arrived at the cave. Knowing watchful satellites were possibly observing overhead in our earths orbit, we were careful to move the boulder and duck into the cave as quickly as we could. We knew the satellites could not track the hickoops incredible speed.
Gastonish spent hours at night studying the details of insectular models using the information within the romstrunn. The stinging wasps belonged to the sub-order Apocrita of the order Hymenoptra. She wanted to learn everything about their entire body structure, and compare differences between real insects and living synthetic insectulars, but the romstrunn held so much information it would often take hours of Gastonishs time. She did, however, find out how to release the cocoon stasis hold and begin the life cycle of the synthetic vehicles growth. Before she could start the life-boat, as we later called it, she had to make some minor preparations. With careful attention to the instructions of the romstrunn, my mother and I designed a single honeycomb shaft large enough to hold the entire life-boat to the point where it could fully mature and come to age. The single shaft filled the center of the spacious crystal lit cave and stood twenty feet tall.
The honey comb was made of wood fiber and clay. After the larva life-boat was placed inside and the stasis hold of the cocoon removed, we had to cover the top of the honey comb.
While the larva was growing, the romstrunns instructions were for us to gather food for the Zandith Crockmior to process and place it just outside the base of the honey comb.
