The function was identical to a real insects habits. The only problem was the items listed for us to use as food were insects. The romstrunn was quite specific when listing the food items: winged female ants with wings torn off (discard female ants who already lost their wings.) The list went on: cicadas, cockroaches, spiders, beetles, caterpillars, mosquitoes and honeybees.
To collect such insects on Verticus would not be so tedious because there the insects not only over populate the planet, but they are of monumental size and proportion equal to that of the Zandith Crockmior L/X. Evon and Xonox searched the land of the Island to find the insects of the list. Their efforts were in vain, for no matter how hard they tried, the insects collected were never more than a fraction of what was needed to feed the life-boat. Later Gastonish learned the remaining parts from the original Zandith Crockmior would be a sufficient food to fuel the life-boat even though they were synthetic.
Oddly, Evon would occasionally report of how men were in the area of the cave looking for something in the dead of night. I would never enter or exit the cave if I knew people were close. We worked on and monitored the Zandith Crockmior L/X as frequently as possible and stayed as long as we could. Mainly we tried to take advantage of the shadow of nightfalls cloak.

Although Evon would accompany me to the cave and tutor me whenever possible about the ways of the future, I was expected to go to school and learn from a human perspective. Because I only slept for one entire day each week, I had hours and hours to keep busy on the Island. I loved to keep busy and I made a point of trying to meet with every citizen of the Island. I knew some great techniques to keep introductions from being awkward and though most people already had preconceived ideas of who I was, usually, with each first meeting, the people thought of me as a dangerous monster or someone who had a job to discipline and punish the people of the Island. It was friendship which would always win in the end. I looked forward to helping people and as I did I found lots of talk and interaction rewarded me with a new friend time and time again.
One day, I heard someone in the Scamp market make a comment of how inspirational I was and how I would take care of people. I was very pleased to pick-up on this conversation. The other mentioned how people were depending on me to get things done, but I was discouraged when they said, It is just a matter of time before the government tries to harness his good will.
With hard work comes more work. I thought. If anyone came for me I would have to stay ready. I would not go easy. The exercise I required was insufficient at the human gym. I needed to look for heavier harder jobs. Some people could not understand why I would do senseless jobs but it was simply because my body would require the exertion. As I grew, I would require more and more resistance training.
Jay, a single man who lived a quiet life and did not want to be too involved with what went on within the community, dropped me off at home each day after school. He drove a pickup truck and he was like the Islands school bus-driver. There was not one day when I would stay after school for anything, for example to talk to friends, hang out or to ask the teacher a clever question, or Id miss my ride with Jay.
Wearing his usual jean jacket, even on real hot days, Jay was like a silent loner type. He had shaggy brown hair and sideburns with a necklace of earthy Indian beads. I liked him mostly for his care-free lifestyle, but he wasnt considered a close friend. 
Evon was my closest friend and it taught me many things all the time, like how to strengthen my telepathic skills or to use my lintin. My fathers lintin was a small wrist band, resembling a pearly watch, which I received the same time I acquired the boots, Romstrunn, glowing gel suit, and hickoop from within the Zandith Crockmior aboard the alien vorogon.
When I was six years of age my build and body structure were said to be more like that of a thirteen year old human boy, only built up with ten times his regular muscle capacity. Such studies concerning my age in relation to a humans growth rate were performed and carried out by experts, whom I was told, I would never meet. I debated the issue once, but later I just left it to others to decide how accurate the experts were concerning my development. My opinions did not seem to matter to human ego most of the time.
I loved my life and wanted to stay on earth. I did not share the need in my heart, as my mother did, to go to Verticus. You could imagine my surprise when Gastonish would say, It wont be long now, Eddy. Very soon we will be going home.
I was seven feet tall and three men wide full of bulging muscles. I distinctly recall a time when I was playing rugby with some of my classmates out on the beach when the ferry docked. One of us shirtless boys put the back of his hand to his mouth to speak privately in a low whisper to the rest of us. Hey, check it out. He said pointing, Thats the new girl to the Island. Here she comes. Upon the time her eyes caught sight of our group, we all dropped our gazes to the ground.
She walked to the edge of the dock hugging her books to her chest and batting her eyes at us. Hi boys. She had the power to make us all blush, though the boys went red I turned more bluish.
The gang tried to ignore her but they all felt it. She was so beautiful. Even I felt something. Forget her. Bobby said, Even you can get hurt fooling around with the little town flirt, Eddy. 
It was sound advice even though it came from an elementary student. But I could not help but wonder if he was just trying to discourage us because he wanted her all to himself.
The boys would often compete to win over a moment of her attention. It was always exciting to find out more about someone who was new to the Island, and I went right along with the others. 
Her name was Sally Coppler. I guess I was drawn to her innocence. In the presence of Sally, I would begin to run faster than usual and chase my schoolmates around growling in good fun. She put a flare in my heart which kicked up my pulse and I was helplessly crazy when she was around. Playing baseball, I'd try to play at the same level as everyone else, but if Sally was in the bleachers, I would hit the ball out of the park and jump to first base in four leaps; or drag the bike racks out into the parking lot for a joke. I didn't always depend on my strength to enlighten my teenage dream either. I also liked to catch teachers off guard with a question they should know, but usually couldn't answer off-hand.
Instant popularity, was what Sally had with her beautiful young fresh look and just the right mix of charisma and confidence. With bright green eyes and a laugh which lured people in to her aura of fun, fun, fun. As far as I was concerned, the Island could use many more like her. She wore bright clothes which quickly set the standard for fashion amongst the young ladys at school. And she knew a different way to style her blond hair for each and everyday.
Many times I was able to draw a large crowd within the classroom by presenting one of my most favourite magic tricks. I mastered the art of trickery with hours of practice at the skill of 'slight of hand', the art of deceiving the eye with skillful movements of the hand. 
There was this one time when Sally first wanted to see one of my rumoured amazing tricks. First, sat in a chair at the front of the class with my back to the students and facing the chalkboard. I took a piece of chalk and crushed it in my left fist. My open right hand had a single sheet of blank paper set on it. I asked the class to select a silently student to walk up behind me and touch my back. 
Hands down, Sally Coppler was selected, though Domin was a close second. Sally moved as silently as a cat. She wasnt sure about me at all. Obviously I spooked her by the way she not only cautiously approached me, but after a quick gentle tap she spun and high tailed it back to her desk like she was being chased by the devil.
I moved my left fist over so it was held over the blank paper. By grinding my fingers, the chalk dust sprinkled onto the paper. Slowly, I moved my dusty left hand back to my left side so the others behind me could see it. With each of my hands held out at either side I began to count backwards from ten. This was simply to raise the suspense and anticipation.
When I reached, one; I jumped out of my seat and slapped the chalk covered paper onto the chalkboard. As the paper was removed I turned to the class without seeing what remained on the chalkboard. 
Everyone gasped and awed before I asked, So who was it who tapped my back? 
No one answered as the identity of the students face was displayed upon the chalkboard as clear as an old black and white photograph. I turned to admire the portrait of Sally Coppler. She was so beautiful, not even the teacher wanted to erase the depiction from the chalkboard for a week.
No matter how my school-mates begged, I would never give away the secrets of my tricks.
We had a very old fashion school of one room and many grades, however, Mr. Dalton, my teacher, was not old fashioned and he impressed me with how knowledgeable he was. When he and I first met he came on like a scientist with a wealth of information. Somehow we talked our way onto the topic of communication and I tried to explain to him how the alphabet did not need to exist, and how it was possible for people to read and speak with numbers alone. Letters were not important. I went into greater detail with him on how this would be done. This way numbers would come easier to people who have trouble with them. I explained.
Mr. Dalton was impressed by the theory and as I tried to show him how it was done, he didnt seem to have the ability to keep up with me. He was at a loss for words when I even further elaborated on the topic.

Strange things happening elsewhere in the world led someone to suggest my mother could be helpful with assisting a special top secret company. The company was called NICAP  the National Investigations Committee on Aerial Phenomena. This was the leading organization for dealing with everything and anything to do with extra-terrestrial contact. Oddly, Gastonish agreed to be an associate and offer her comments to many cases involving alien encounters or abductions. All of this came shortly after a little girl named Jenny came to the Island briefly.
Gastonish tried to help but after a short time, the people of NICAP told my mother how they found her to be a little too eccentric for them with comments and ideas which were just too spectacular to be true. She was dumped from the program.

I was able to get along with most of the other children at school. I was not cruel to any of them, but one boy named Domin knew how to push my buttons. He was the class bully and he would have gotten his way, forcefully, more often if I wasnt around to keep him in line. The children knew if I chased them around in a vicious manner, it was out of fun, but if Domin chased you, you ran for your life. Domin was larger than his peers, almost as large as me, and loved to rough house with them. Other than his merciless acts of so-called fun, Domin was a very quiet boy who kept to himself. At first I found evidence of blood in the bathrooms, and once in the hall. Rumors had it how Domin, notorious for his threats, was backing-up his claims and beating-up other kids. I went to Mr. Dalton with the complaint and he said, The school could not reprimand a child based on rumours of violence.
Scars covered Domins entire body like a road map or web. Most of the scars looked old like he had been going under surgical knives his entire life, but the three distinct cuts on his cheek from his recent encounter with a grizzly bear were still fresh.
I put the word out amongst the other kids I would protect anyone who was threatened by Domin. In the playground, every so often, a child would run to me and say Domin was chasing them. Sure enough, Domin would come charging around the corner of the school growling at the children in a threatening manner. At a glance, Domin looked at me and lost the violent redness of his eyes. With a snort, he turned and walked away, until one day, I encountered Domin angrier than ever. A young boy ran into me from behind. He was shaking, unable to speak. Domin was running for him, his clothes fluttering ferociously with each threatening tread under foot at attack speed. As Domin moved in, diving for the kill, I grabbed him and lifted him up by his shirt. He clawed and ripped at my sleeve. I saw the dark side of Domin which he struggled so hard to keep silent.
While I held Domin in the air, I turned to the boy and asked, What did you do to make Domin so angry? the boy had fallen to the dirt and was in a state of fear stricken shock.
Another child spoke. Jeremy told Domin he was a big dweeb because he was scared of you.
Next Domin struggled to be free before he said, I'm not scared of anyone!
Jeremy also told Domin about how he would leave children alone when he was around you, Eddy. The little chattery girl spoke.
It was clear what was going on, Is this true? I asked, but before I could get another word in, Domin ripped off my sleeve and started clawing at my arm. I shook him to distract him. It was difficult for him to scratch through my thick grey skin, but he finally managed to gouge his fingers in enough to draw a little thick dark scarlet blood. He kicked me in the face at the same instant. I was just about to throw him, when he ripped at his own shirt and fell away from my grasp. He not only land on his feet, but to bounce back toward me. The impact of his combined weight and strength surprisingly pushed me to the ground. Like a cat, Domin pounced on top of me while I was down. I did not think to fight back or escape, I simply wanted to defend myself. I took him by his hair and yanked him off. He came at me again ruthlessly, as he jabbed a fist out to strike me, I grabbed his arm and used his momentum against him. I picked him up and sent him flying into a bush. He crawled out from under the bush with burning eyes of vengeance. He growled low and sinister-like. I found his primitive rage amusing somehow and bellowed out a deep menacing roar of my own.
With incredible speed, Domin ducked back into the bush and disappeared into the woods. Domin strangely disappeared that day and soon after, a lot of chaos and activity started amongst the officials of the Island as they tried to find him. As usual, a huge Island wide search was organized and carried-out with military vehicles, search and rescue boats and helicopters. With all of the efforts put forth, Domin was always found. I was heavily investigated but no charges were ever filed against me.

I have so many memorable moments in that class of unique characters. One day Mr. Dalton took the whole class out for a field trip into the jungle forest of the Island. Sally and Domin were also with us as we all set out on foot through the trails. Mr. Dalton tried to explain different plants and their nutritional value, I ate all of the plants, roots and mushrooms that Mr. Dalton picked and from a small taste I could tell everyone about the percentage of nutrition as well as the medical benefits, if there were any. Mr. Dalton scribbled into his note pad franticly to keep up with me as he tried to write down everything I said so he could later verify it. 
How are you able to do that, Eddy? Mr. Dalton asked as he was astonished by Eddys incredible gift.
I just taste it and I know. I answered as it was all so simple to me.
Mr. Dalton frowned and stopped writing. He did not believe Eddy really had this ability and accused me of pulling a prank.
All of my other classmates tried to eat the plants which I had pointed out as Edible, but they all said it tasted disgusting. 
Domin asked me to eat a plant that he knew to be very poisonous. Here, eat this. 
I took the plant and ate the whole thing quickly. Sally figured out what happened from the other kids who were snickering. She became very upset and raised her voice. Mr. Dalton! Eddy has eaten a poisonous plant. What are we going to do? 
Domin stood back with wide eyes and wondered if Eddy was going to die right before their eyes. Mr. Dalton urgently searched his pockets for his radio communicator. Blast, I cant call for help, we will have to get back to the school as fast as we can.
Mr. Dalton? I called to the teacher, I knew the plant was poisonous before Domin handed it to me. I have eaten it before. I just wanted to prove that it wont harm me.

A few weeks later at the end of a school day, the usual bunch of kids and I were waiting for Jay to come and pick us all up again and drive us to our homes. The kids who stood with me and waited, looked at me as though I was a comic book hero of sorts. Little Jimmy piped up one day and said something which I found both peculiar and profound, I can hold my breath under water for a whole minute.
He, no doubt, wanted to impress everyone with what he thought was a special ability. Tony said, So what, everyone can do that.
Abilities are not to be taken lightly, Tony. I said, I think surviving under water is thrilling, dangerous and takes skill.
I dont just hold my breath for a long time, Jimmy added, I can jump from Eddy's leap rock while reaching my arms into the air, waving them around in complete freedom.
So inspiring, Jimmy. I said, as I was not trying to seem sarcastic. I was truly inspired by him. Do you know what else you can do, Jimmy?
I can walk around my house in complete darkness. I can do cart wheels too. Jimmy added.
You can do so much more than this. You can read countless books, you can take apart your bicycle and put it back together, you can start a business, design an engine which runs off a new form of energy, discover a form of life even if it's only new to you. You can create your own motion picture where you're the star, or make your own unique music, while you discover how to do it you can lead others to assist you, doing this will not only earn you friends but great respect as well. Shout to the world, Look at me! I am alive and it feels so good! Express this in all you do. You could make me want to buy your product, you could single handedly change the future. You could save a life. You can love another person. A simple act from you can change not only a life but the entire world. Your reach must be global, your intensions always noble and your heart pure and good. Positive thinking is constructive, unlike a negative word. You can be president for in one way or another you guys are this world. You can keep rhythm to your own beat and know no one else compares. Through simple understanding you can control and improve on existing systems.
Jimmy caught the bug of my message before he added, I know what youre saying. Thats why they brought me to this Island I think. My power is infinite. I can heal by love and laughter. I could do anything without permission I have it all under my command. I can guide a jet aircraft by the mere will of my thoughts and hit a target with uncanny precision and accuracy. I could connect with this planet and be a part of every good thing about it, or I could be a part of its pain and suffering. A strange rippling vibration moved under our feet and I saw small stones begin to bounce slightly on the dirt road. I could witness a birth or flatten a nation. Armies will fight for me and I could pick and choose who will rise and who will fall. The government knows I have potential, but I never told them I have infinite potential. The wind blew over us in a powerful gust. I could destroy this island if I orchestrate a plan to do so! Or why don't I just split it right in two! 
The ground shook under our feet and fear gripped our hearts. Trees were almost uprooted, when Jimmy had to sit down at the edge of the dirt road and breathe. As quickly as the strange occurrence began, an omniscient calmness surrounded us and everything settled again. I put my hand on his back and said, Im sorry, I should have known better than to get you all worked up.
Jimmy looked up at me and said, It is not by my strength but by His whereby I can do what I do. 
Who are you talking about when you say, His? I asked in awe. Jimmy pointed to the sky, and I was amazed. 
Jimmy refused to show me anything more after that incident. Though he did say, That was fun. You know? I can ride my bike with no hands
I smiled at Jimmy, when within my ear, Evons voice gave me a message from my mother. She was at the cave and she needed Evon to assist Xonox with collecting insects for a new project she was working on. She believed she could find a way to make the insects she collected grow to the size specified for the Zandith Crockmior life boat. I called it a long shot, nevertheless with a thought, I sent Evon to help my mother. Inconspicuously, I threw a stone into some bushes at the other side of the road. The other children responded to the sound of the stone snapping through the bush. I let Evon launch from my ear. In a blink of an eye, my sertz was gone. 
Faintly, I could hear our ride rolling closer by the minute.
I looked around and found my peers were very comfortable with me around. I did not take that for granted, not even for a moment.
As Jay proceeded to drop off each student, I found his driving was much more aggressive than any other day. I remembered how he would always say hello or smile when he came to pick us up. He didn't respond at all, and I kind of wondered what was upsetting him, yet I still paid it no mind. Everyone has a bad day.
My stop came up next. I always found it was a very obvious spot where I was let off, but Jay drove right past it. When he stopped to let the next kid off, I asked him why he didn't stop.
Oh, sorry, I have a lot on my mind. Don't worry, I'll get to it. Jay replied quickly, but I was skeptical about his intentions.
Yes, but can't you just turn around? I asked, Because my mom is going to be worried if I'm not home soon. And the delay would interfere with my regular scheduled studies. I thought to myself.
I'll get to it, I said! Jay snapped at me.
He went about his business returning the children home. When I was the only one left, he proceeded up the road.
You are going the wrong way! I told him sternly. I have to get home now!
This is a short-cut! Jay shouted out of the window. With a flick of his wrist, he turned on the radio and the heavy metal music thundered from his cab.
I thought immediately, Short-cut? Ya, right! I know these roads well enough and this is no short-cut. He is taking me up the mountain!? We began to travel quite high and the road dropped off to a sharp cliff to the right of us. Something is very wrong here. I thought, But what would Jay want with me? I became skeptical and started sweating. Jays driving became much more aggressive the further we went which made it difficult for me to just jump out of the truck. As he swung the truck around a sharp corner, I was involuntarily thrown right out from the back of the pick-up.
I hit the ground so hard and so fast, I was shocked. I could have broken my neck. Under great pain I found my ankle was injured.
Jay hammered on his brakes and slid to a stop over the dirt road. After a little gear grinding, the white reverse lights came on. His engine roared and his trany wined as his truck approached me. The way he slammed the door after he got out of the truck was very rash. As he came closer he became increasingly perturbed.
My leg! I told him, I think its broken. I played into my pain to make it seem worse than it was.
Great! Damaged goods. He grumbled, What am I supposed to do about it, freak? Jay said. He wiped his nose with his sleeve before he slapped his leg. Dust formed a small cloud around the slap as he looked down shaking his head. Thanks a lot. You couldnt just stay in the truck? He was frustrated and disappointed with me. I hope your foot isnt hurt too badly. They might try to take it out of my pay.
Jay, look at me! I said, trying to talk sense into him. I can't move. Please, just go back to my house and bring my mom here, she will know what to do.
Oh... Jay sarcastically sighed. Does Eddy want his mommy? Look, we don't have time for this, now get your grey freakish-butt in the truck so we can get out of here.
Violently, Jay grabbed my shoulder and flipped me onto my front. Sloppily, he found out the hard way how he was not going to be able to move my two hundred and forty pound body into the back of his pick-up. Finally, I decided to assist him as I basically climbed into the back of the truck myself.
Jay walked around to the drivers seat, hopped in and forced the trucks stick into gear. The wheels spun as we continued our journey, racing through the windy dirt road of relentless pot-holes. I laid down in the pick-up, playing dead, trying to figure a way out. Evon was bound to return to me soon. How long would my mother need his assistance? I clung to the hope he would not be too late but as time moved on, all hope dwindled. I never before felt so helpless.
When we stopped, I had an incredible urge to peek over and look at my surroundings. I could not, of course, because I was afraid if Jay had a gun. My ankle was feeling better but I felt my safest bet was to just play dead, and listen.

The door to the cab clicked as it released. It squeaked open from the dry rusty hinges, before the door violently slammed shut. Something was tickling my nose. I couldn't move, no matter what happened. The crunching of the dry gravel under Jays feet became louder as he drew closer. It stopped for a moment while he looked in. He took in a breath of air, before he let it out in contempt. Jay proceeded to the back of the pic- up and yanked the tail gate down.
Okay, get up! Ordered Jay, C'mon, I know you're playing possum, you big lumpy grey freak!
He grabbed me by the scruff of my collar and tried to throw me off the edge of the tail-gate.
I was able to brace myself so I didn't go over. I couldn't help it, I had to look at Jay to see what he was going to do next. His eye brows met, his face went red, and he began to grit his teeth. I was uncontrollably reminded of the mover who helped my mother and I move to the Island. His face was just as tense when he tried to lift one of my heavy weights. It was not a coincidence, Jay was the same man. But it just didn't make sense... Why?
The pounding of his heavy boots entered the pick-up box, it made me shiver. But I couldnt be scared of a human, could I? I stood up fast and Jay was knocked over the edge of the box. The pain in my ankle was far greater than I expected it to be when I applied pressure to it. I lost my balance and fell over the opposite side of the box. I could hear Jay start talking, I was not listening to what he was saying, but by the tone of his voice, I knew he was sore as well, and angrier than ever. I struggled and squirmed on the ground until I found myself on my back. Covered in dirt, I heard Jay open the door of the pick-up.
I should have done this from the beginning. Jay said with the sound of metal clicking. The sound was just like he was cocking a rifle.
The truck door slammed shut and my body tensed. I heard his feet shuffle around the front of the truck quickly. Sure enough my worst fears became reality. Jay was holding a rifle.
 What are you? Jay said as he pointed the barrel of his rifle at me. Are you related to the elephant man? Look at your skin, kid, its grey, like an elephant.
I tried to jump and escape him as a last ditch attempt to survive but I was too slow. Jay fired the rifle and I felt the bullet strike me in the back.
I tumbled forward and fell down a cliff. At the bottom of the steep embankment, I landed hard onto the ground before I struck my head on a rock. Well, it looks like you are human. Between wisps of air, he went on. The evidence is all over you... red blood.
Jay dropped his rifle and slid down the hill. He ran to me and swung his leg back to kick me. As he swung his leg forward I reached up and grabbed his ankle. I squeezed and squeezed, before I felt his ankle cracking in the palm of my hand. I hated it, but I had to do it, I had to make him stop.
Jay screamed as if he was dying and he quickly pulled out his knife and stabbed me in my fore-arm. I let go of him and we both screamed out in pain. I pulled the knife out of my arm and felt something dangling at my back. My vision began to blur. Still I managed to brush my back up against a nearby tree. Something came off of my back. I turned and found a dart laying on the ground at the base of the tree. It was a tranquilizer dart. 

I shook my head to clear the effects of the drug. I noticed Jay was crawling and dragging his injured leg behind him. He crawled up the steep cliff. I was slow moving behind him but I had to follow him to be sure he wasnt going to try anything else. Whatever I did was better than to give into the effects of the tranquilizer. I peeked over the top of the cliff and saw Jay crawl to a cabin which was just beyond his truck. As I looked around the property of his run down cabin, I saw strange inventions undoubtedly created by Jay. They looked like bicycles because they were powered by pedals. One would heat coals, for a barbecue perhaps. Others had sharpening stones attached to them and other things I couldn't recognize. Strangely they were all used with the same design of a bicycle.
Behind his cabin, was a bath house and further back was his bright red out house.
The front door to the cabin swung open and Jay crawled out. He was holding a first aid kit and rope. I wanted to run but my body was still fighting off the effects of the tranquilizer. The pain from my ankle and stab wound was enough to prevent me from an escape. Jay limped his way over to me.
I could do nothing to fight him off. He turned me over onto my front and tied my legs and arms back. Grunting through the pain, Jay used his foot to press against my back as he pulled his knots tight. I was relieved for one thing, he brought the first aid kit. 
I could hear him behind me opening it, and messing around with the contents inside. I didn't say anything to him. Not only did I not want to discourage him, I could hardly move my mouth to speak.
After about five minutes of messing around with the first aid kit, I heard the lid of the kit click shut. Crawling toward the cabin, it was obvious, Jay wasnt concerned with my wounds at all.
Jay was just going to leave me bleeding. I started struggling to get free from my bonds. I remembered how I used to let my friends tie me up as part of my escape artist trickery. I would always free myself because I learned the techniques from classic escape artists through many magic books.
I would make a fist, pull and twist, then relax my hand, pull and twist. Though tight, Jay didn't tie a very difficult knot. My hands were free in about two minutes. I pulled the ropes with my arms and pushed with my legs and the rope snapped.
Jay noticed I was free before he started hopping toward me. Stop right there, freak!
The hopping was no good, he couldn't keep his balance. Jay fell flat on his face.
I wanted to open a can of hurt all over him, but the tranquilizer made me so light headed I barely kept myself together. I turned and tried to escape, but everything went into slow motion. I crawled on my hands and dragging my feet as I slid back down the steep edge to a clearing at the bottom.
I glanced behind me and found Jay was getting very close. My head felt heavy like it was full of cement. I couldn't think, as I rolled and tumbled. My cut grew wider and my ankle became seriously injured. The hot and dry dust surrounded me and filled my lungs. Rolling out onto level ground, I laid on the dirt waiting motionless for Jay to slide down the hill and kill me.
 
Above me, I could hear Jay make his way down the steep eight foot ridge. The air around me was a thick with hot coarse dust through my throat. I couldn't keep my eyes from closing. The affects of the drug were too strong after all, besides the dust had gotten beneath my eye lids. Jay landed beside me clumsily. He forced me to sit up against a wooden structure.
Look at me! he commanded, Look at me, monster boy!
I opened my eyes and to my surprise, he was waving a six inch hunting knife in my face. It had a jagged edge, and it was coated with blood, my blood.
I raised my hands to protect myself. Jay jerked the knife toward my face. As he pulled it back, the jagged edge cut my light blue knuckle capsule of my left hand thumb. The whole capsule split and it started to bleed.
Ooo, I'm sorry. Jay reproached with mocking sympathy, Its a pretty nice blade isn't it? He held it up and I immediately jerked back. Whats wrong? Don't you like blades? Here watch this. Jay began cutting his arm in quick random strokes. There, you freak, we're even!
He took out a skeleton key and unlocked a pad lock hanging beside my head. While he was fumbling with the lock, Jay flinched the knife inches from my face. Don't try anything. Jay warned. I looked behind me and found the wooden structure was really a door connected to a small square crate.
Open it. Jay commanded ignorantly as he either didn't feel comfortable working so close to me or he couldn't manage to open the lock himself.
I shifted my body weight out of the way before I fumbled with the key to open the door. I managed to get the door open though Jay was out of patience. I didn't know what this small door was for, but it was cold inside. The wood of the structure was old and grey yet still strong. It was an old crate half buried in the side of the sandy slope.
Get in! Jay commanded with a thrust of his knife. 
I shook my head, negatively. I willed myself to believe Evon would return any moment.
Again Jay waved his knife for me to get into the crate much closer and aggressive than before. His eyes were crazy with darkness and hate. How could this be the same Jay I thought I knew so well? Later I referred to it as 'the box' because from the inside, that was all it was. Jay locked it up and left me crammed inside.
My right hand was kept warm by the blood of my stab wound. I kept pressure on it constantly. Subconsciously, I was trying to determine how much blood was draining from my body per second. This, in conjunction with the tranquilizer, led to a self induced dizziness. It wasnt long before I also became dehydrated. My throat was dry, and it became hard for me to breathe. The walls seemed to be closing. Hope drained out of me with my blood. Scared to death I discovered the horrific experience of claustrophobia. Perhaps non of the symptoms were real, but I believed them to be real. It was possible I was experiencing the side affects of heart palpitations or perhaps I was simply not receiving enough oxygen. My skin felt irritated and itchy as though millions of insects and spiders were crawling and scurrying over my body. I was so scared and alone in the darkness. Alone and cold... Ice cold.
Within my nightmares of Jay, I wondered how he must want to kill me but make it look like it wasn't his fault, but something just didn't seem to add up. How could my death benefit Jay? He would tell them a story which wasn't true, and get away with it. Get away with what? Was I so threatening to humanity? I wondered if it was just a test, as if Jay was trying to analyze my physical strength to see how I would react when pushed too far, but I couldnt make sense of such an experiment either. Too much about this situation was senseless. Soon, I became tired of thinking, and too scared to sleep. I began to phase in and out of sleep in reaction to my trauma. 
My thought eventually turned to my mother with memories of how strong she was on the alien vorogon. I was to be more dependable than a man, I needed to be a volk. I didn't think there was any hope for me then. I was as good as dead aboard the vorogon just as felt within the box.
I heard Jay clanking something heavy and metal on top of the crate. It sounded as though a heavy rope was pulled through the thick metal ring at the top center of the crate.
Evon appeared inside the box with me. Its eye optics glowed red and lit the inside of the box.
MY LORD, I FOUND YOU. Spoke the little robot who was a welcome sight of security for my young helpless eyes.
Evon! Recognizing my sertz, I wasn't sure if I was still dreaming. No matter, I spoke to it, premonition or not. I need you to find Gastonish and give her an urgent message. In a lower, raspier voice, I spoke. Tell her, I'm in trouble... Show her the way here!... Priority one Hurry!... Go now! With no reply, Evon disappeared out through a small gap in the slats.
I heard a slight thumping. I imagined Jay, dressed in a dark hooded cloak, beating a drum as he was attempting to carry out some crazy cult sacrifice. The thumping grew louder as a constant chopping. It was not the beat of a drum I heard, it was something else, something from outside... A helicopter.
The metal on top of the crate was tugged firmly when the entire crate jolted skyward. A great force dragged the crate a short distance along the ground, no doubt the helicopter was the muscle behind the momentum.
The crate lifted off the ground. I felt the momentous swing as the crate brushed through the trees.
My crate swung forward as though the helicopter changed direction. It was like being on a roller coaster or a turbo accelerated elevator. I cleared the trees and I could feel myself being pulled higher and higher. Other air-force vessels joined in with thunderous after burners engaged as they darted past me. Strong lights sheered through the cracks of the crate. Voices in the distance were bellowing orders through a mega-phone.
'Would the rope snap in the next second?'
I was shocked when I heard the terrifying sounds of rockets blasting and ammo firing. The rope holding my crate did snap. Gravity distorted as I, within the crate, fell freely. The fall seemed to last forever as I tumbled into eternity.
The sound of a ricochet bullet twanged through the corner of the crate. I felt my weight return as the falling crate began to strangely stabilize and slow. The lock on the crate twisted apart and fell off. The crate gently touched down on the ground and the door opened.
I shifted my weight forward to allow gravity to pull me out. As I fell forward, I bumped into something... Something invisible, and it held me.
Eddy, I've got you. It was the soft spoken voice of my mother. Who did this? Gastonish demanded with heavy concern in her tone.
Jay... I answered meekly.
Gastonish's volk suit was warm and vibrant. Her arm slid over my shoulders as she sat down next to me. Where is he honey, I want to see him.
No! I said, my voice cracking. He will hurt you too... Hes evil!
No, Eddy. No one will ever hurt us as long as we are together. Now, stay calm and wait, someone will be by soon to help you! somehow when Gastonish spoke I knew the nightmare was over and everything would eventually be just fine. I shouldn't be found here with you. Promise me you won't tell anyone I was here, okay?
I promise. with dry sincerity I pledged my solemn word.
I was unable to sense the presence of my mother after made my promise to her. I rolled over onto my hands and knees. Crawling, I tried to make some distance between the crate and myself. My whole body was throbbing. Moving a full branch of pine needles from obstructing my line of sight, I fixed my eyes on a human form who was running through the woods. It was Jay and he was swept off his feet and thrown through the air. Jay's body struck against a huge tree trunk before he crumpled to the ground like a rag doll. I heard the authorities of the Island approach from the distance on foot.
There was another, a single person who moved in a diameter six feet from Jays body. I could hear the foot steps, but I could not see the persons form. Jay awoke and cautiously observed his surroundings. He heard the foot steps too. The invisible foot steps could only belong to one person, Gastonish. Her face appeared in the pink glow of her suit for just a brief second. When Jay saw this he was overwhelmed with fear. The amplified strength and fury of my mother was like a mystical unseen force. The crate was lifted off the ground and tossed onto Jay. It was as though my mother toyed with him like a child playing with a bug. His form was contorted into a disturbing pretzel shape after being stuffed into the box. The door of the box was forcefully wedged shut.
Jay was killed for his crime which was how he was later found.
Someone approached me from behind. Before I could turn and see who it was, I was struck in my back by another tranquilizer dart. This dart came from Knolix Island authorities. This time I had no strength left to fight its affects... Blackness draped over me.

I awoke slowly, collecting myself from another place. The sleep I came out of was so deep and comforting it was as though I was disconnected from both space and time. I was not familiar with my surroundings. Something was beeping and keeping with a constant pattern. A monitor. I was in a doctors office where people were scurrying about my bed busily. My wrists, ankles and waist were strapped to a high bed. Bandages dressed my wounds.
My wounds left me in great pain. Evon, ease my pain. I had just awoke so I said it as more of a test to see if Evon was still with me. A warm tingling sensation came over my entire body and I was no longer in pain. I was then reassured, Evon was with me. Nurse, how long have I been here? drearily, I asked.
A nurse alerted others to my consciousness over a com. She approached me and said, You have been here for six hours. How do you feel?
Not bad. shaking off the tiresome affects of sleep, I replied with more alertness.
The stab wound to my arm was stitched and gauze was taped in place. My ribs were tender but the bruises and swelling had already passed, not to mention the striking gash on my forehead. I noticed I did not experience any pain from my sprained ankle. The rope burns of my wrists and ankles did not hurt either. Nor was I stiff and sore from being crammed into the box.
Dr. Evon came in to check on me and released me from the bed bindings. I did my regular stretching routine and tried to pretend I woke from a bad dream.
Eddy, you were the victim of an unfortunate security breach. Dr. Evon cut to the chase and began to explain, Luckily the homing device implanted into your tooth allowed us to come to your aid as soon as we did. The man who abducted you was a spy from the foreign secret service. You are government property and you are very valuable to this nation. He smiled to me, reassuringly. You're lucky to have friends who will risk everything for your safety.
What I went through had a much larger impact on my childhood than the encounter with the Ornocks because it brought me so close to the reality of my mortality. Gastonish felt it was necessary to develop a way for us to track one another, but our options were limited. In the Ied era, another volk could be tracked anywhere in the galaxy with the help of a thrustle-T, a volk police officer, providing the volk to be located was not yet separated from its sertz. Unfortunately, we were without any possibility of thrustle-T aid.
When a sertz was unable to link communication with a thrustle-T, it could over-ride certain program regulations in favor of its situation of independence and survival. This was not an unnatural occurrence since many have been lost in space. Our situation required a special solution. Since all bodies, human, animal or volk, leave behind a distinct radiation, our sertz could adjust their ultra sensitive optical spectra to identify us by these means. To give our sertz the capability to distinguish my mother and I apart by our naturally unique residual radiation expulsions, we could follow ghostly trails of ones self radiation to lead us to the one who was lost. As a person walked across a room the sertz would see a bright human form, but the radiation or heat of ones body would leave a hazy trail through the air. Foot prints or objects touched throughout the path of the person were often brighter and identifiably unique in the sight of the sertz visual scope.

Days after this abduction attempt, I couldnt shake the uneasiness I felt. It wasnt until Evon brought to light how my subconscious was dictating emotional responses which affected my decision making in minor ways. I had trouble trusting humans and I became a quiet, private person. Evon was surprisingly helpful as the little centennial robot guided me through my emotions subconsciously. It was a long journey I had to take with small steps. Day by day, I grew stronger and more emotionally stable. I compared myself to Pinocchio as the freak who wanted to become a real boy. My popularity nose dived from a 100 to a -100. With the dwindling of my reputation came hurtful gossip and lies. The Island citizens honed in on my change. They knew something was different and the mystery surrounding me, though personal, caused the people to come up with all sorts of speculations. I found children and adults alike sneering at me and whispering behind my back. Still, I tried to hang around other kids and I wanted to fit in very much. No matter how hard I tried, I was destined to be the out-cast of the small Island community forever. 
I remembered how my life was before Jay abducted me. I was popular and happy-go-lucky... Or at least, that was how I wanted to remember I was. My memories were like someone elses at times. Everything just seemed so different.
Perhaps, just by becoming a more private person, I created a residual effect on the people around me. I did not expect such results, but I could not deny them either. The end results were too obvious. No one felt comfortable with me around anymore. This much was certain. It was the flip side of the coin. It was an uncomfortable feeling to not have a crowd of children around me cheering my name. The magic was gone.
Was this all some sort of racial discrimination?
Remembering back, I took it for granted how the kids couldn't wait for their turn to play with me. I remembered so clearly how I could make each one of them feel special and I felt special in return. Now, no one wanted to even look at me. They started out making cheap cracks. Perhaps they were looking for some reaction which would incriminate me in some way. Or maybe they were trying to crack my shell to begin their first step to bring me back to the volk I once was.
One very small boy approached me with no fear and said, I remember when you were teaching the class about things by the shore. You sat up on a large rock to look down on the rest of us. You talked about deep and insightful things which were actually very simple to you. It was like you treated us like lost little puppies. Do you think so little of us?
No, of course not. It was no use. No matter what I said, they had an idea burned in their minds, I was an inhuman creature who harboured dark thoughts. I was convinced they would not believe anything otherwise. The moment I thought humans no longer believed in me was the moment I decided to put up an emotional barrier, an invincible wall. As an emotional reflex I hardened myself. Slowly, I became used to people talking behind my back.
There was only one other I found I could relate to and he was the most unlikely person I ever would have suspected, but Domin was at my level of depression. The load of baggage he carried was equal to my own though he came from another world of problems entirely.
Domin and I never really spoke to one another when we were in the presence of humans, but if we found ourselves alone together we would begin to open up only our conversations were strange. Neither of us wanted to talk about our experiences so we dodged the specifics. What we found was a connection, an understanding, though neither of us would admit it.
As crazy as our conversations were, Domin and I needed to know we were no alone in the cosmos.

Helping Gastonish contribute to the well-being of the Zandith Crockmior life-boat became as monotonous as school. I would do my part wishing I was somewhere else. Gastonish tried to listen to me but she only gave quick advice with little love or compassion combined. It was obvious, her first priority was to go home to the Ide era. To her, the answer to all of our problems would be solved the moment we were off the planet earth and on Verticus. She had a one track mind; 'Tend to the Zandith Crockmior and complete the business at the cave.' At the age of seven, which was equivalent to the developmental stage of a sixteen year old human, Evon came to me many times to offer assistance in my despair. I never wanted advice from the tiny robot. Whenever I was alone seeking a peaceful moment to myself, there it was. I was so frustrated when Evon would try to teach me something or attempt to be my pal.
AM I YOUR FRIEND, MASTER? my sertz asked in one of many attempts in counseling me.
I don't have any friends. Just leave me alone. I would negatively reply. Refusing to accept any kind of reaching out from anyone was all I could do until I was sure how I would fit into this world. I also battled feelings of anxiety when I thought about going to Verticus, the world of volks. Would Gastonish be able to pull it off and take us back through time or dimension? What were volks like? Were they nice? Would we ever even find them? Perhaps we would end up lost, or dead, or would we find the new world? And if so, would I be able to adjust to that world? I could build up questions from that point which would scare me half to death. The whole idea of my situation could seem to be so much larger than I was.
Gastonish could see I was having problems. I saw it in her eyes. She wanted to be there for me but, to her, it was a job fit for my sertz and nothing more than a distraction between her and I and what we were trying to accomplish. What I hated more than my reflection in the mirror was my shadow on the wall. I was constantly reminded of how I didn't fit in. How I was a volk and would never be human. I just wanted to be treated equally and fairly. I deserved it. Judgemental opinions from the thoughts of people crept into my mind all the time. What I hated more than who I was, was who everyone else thought me to be. I had a fear or intimidation of growing up in the Ied era with other volk children. And though I loved the human children I couldnt imagine being one of them. Yet my mood of depression was like a heavy coat or yoke and I could not shake it off.

When Gastonish and I could no longer do anymore at the cave, and we had very little down time, we would telepathically link our minds and I could see the Ied era through my mothers memories. Our world of volks was fascinating, and through the mind link I fully understood why Gastonish wanted to go back so badly. I saw my father, Mulunac, and many other relatives whom my mother would try to describe to me. Not only did people dress differently than I expected, some did not look like volks at all, they were like insects. I thought everyone would be dressed in suits like the ones Gastonish and I wore, but they did not. They wore some clothing of fabric and not all volk outfits would glow.
The volks in Gastonish's memories ranged in size from one and a half foot muscle bound babies, to over ten foot tall giants. I saw and recognized, the top of an Ornocks head. I asked Gastonish where the strange alien-like people came from. 
There are very few creatures from other planets who live on Verticus except for Vornocks. Gastonish answered, as she vacuumed the corners of the floor with her futuristic boots. Most of the other creatures are not capable of surviving on Verticus because they were created for their own specific planets surface environment. So, though we do have countless other life forms who co-exist with us in our world, very few of them can survive with us on our planet unless they were to change our planet in some fundamental way. Gastonishs volk boots, along with mine, attracted dust and dirt particles. The soles of our boots could light up with ion light and this was used to sterilize the floor. As Gastonish walked throughout the cave she was also keeping it clean from dust and bacteria. The boots were only activated when we were indoors. The dirt and dust were then compressed into pellets of stone for easy disposal.
When Gastonish began revealing Verticus to me, my volk body began going through many changes. Late at night, I would get extremely painful muscle cramps and I noticed I was getting taller more rapidly, like I was sprouting. Not only was I growing up fast, but my musculature was filling out even faster.
Everyday at school in the afternoon, I would need a shower because my pores had matured, bringing about a distinct body odour. The odour was like ammonia and I could not wash it off no matter how hard I scrubbed. I also was developing bad acne, the size of quarters on my head, upper back, shoulders, and thighs. Another symptom was an irritating itchy sensation of my grey thick skin. My voice began to crack and deepen even further. Lastly, I began experiencing a certain need for companionship. I became very interested in girls. Of course I felt an attraction to volk females, but the human/volk similarities were close enough. Besides, I grew up with humans so I wondered if I would ever feel an attraction for a female volk. The changes taking place were not a mystery, I was experiencing volk puberty. 
Though puberty did not last long for me, I was aware how I was developing my psychic sensitivity or awareness. It was not easy, but I was getting better reading into the shadow of other peoples emotions through strict, focused concentration.
It was harder for me to meet humans at their level and befriend them. As my moody affects of puberty wound down, I managed them and became more patient and at ease with people. Evon never gave up on me through my stubborn changes and attitude. Our sessions of subconscious therapy really paid off. I grew to become so satisfied with our progress, I stuck with it to the end. It turned out to not only be useful but enjoyable, I didnt want it to stop. 
My core consciousness was soon completely balanced once again and I returned to my old, happy-go-lucky self. Still, with many instances, as soon as I would make new friends, I would struggle to keep them around. Deep down I became repulsed at most true natures of the human kind. A great deal of effort was needed as Evon coached me at tolerating human behaviour. My new calm composure and coolness was my tool to developing better skills at keeping friends. 
My most memorable childhood friend was a native boy from town. He treated me like a human being, or rather, a decent being. His name was Kinta Beukemwa. When I first started to find out what kind of person he was, he told me briefly the story of what the circumstances were which brought him to the Island.
Dawning a black head band, Kinta Beukemwa dressed like everyone else. Usually Kinta wore a thin sleeveless jean jacket over a T-shirt which usually advertised 'AC/DC'. His clothes hung loosely over his thin lanky frame. Long jet black hair complimented his dark skin, eyes and eye brows. Kinta seemed to always wear a dazzling white smile which attracted many young friends to his equally young complexion.
The only ties to his native background was found in his simple necklace of earthy beads of green, rusty reddish browns and greys. On his right wrist Kinta wore an assortment of leather bracelets, while on his left wrist a wide brown leather band was fashioned with a watch set into it and he had it held together with a large brass belt buckle.
Kinta had no knowledge of his childhood. All he remembered was being cared for by military personnel at a base in Canada. His past was a mystery. Was foul play involved on the militarys part? Most likely there was, Kinta speculated. The strangest part of his situation was how he was found on the military complex hiding in the boiler room. Upon the discovery of Kinta, his body was infected with a rare but deadly complex virus. Kintas body was thin, bruised and lifeless, but since the time he was discovered by the military, our nation's efforts were successful at containing the virus so it was no longer lethal or contagious, though it had never been neutralized or extracted. Kinta was still expected to take countless medications to fight off the viruss affects. If any symptoms of the virus were to resurface, Kinta would immediately be quarantined again. Just recently Kinta was re-evaluated and released from his sterile confinements. The consequences brought him to this Knolix Island to protect, treat and cure his secret.

As the busy year continued on, marching past with no concerns to our current situation, my mother and I worked obscurely and relentlessly, behind the scenes. Our efforts, within the cave, developed with every visit. We were unable to properly preserve the dismembered anatomy of the original Zandith Crockmior L/X. This became a problem because the salvaged parts were meant to be used as food stuff for the growing larva life boat. Without a proper method to keep the spare parts frozen, they were spoiled. 70% of the synthetic insect meat had to be discarded and thrown out. 
However, as difficult as this obstacle was, Gastonish found a way around it. Throughout Gastonishs endless studies using the romstrunn, she learned how insects of earth were chemically denied a chromosome which would allow them to grow substantially larger. The romstrunn contained detailed complex instructions for how to emit the restrictive chemical and free the dormant chromosome. Within a sterile laboratory section of the cave, Gastonish performed the operation on the newly conceived insect eggs of various bugs. The tools she used were identical to the ones documented in the instructions of the romstrunn and created by the metal manipulative power of my lintin. Evidently, contrast to all of the problems, Gastonish and I shared, we began to realize it would not be long before we would complete the end stages of our work and finally be on our way home.

It wasn't clear how, but some ants, flies, mice and lizards were able to find their way into the cave on occasion. We weren't sure who our next unexpected guest would be.
On one occasion a gecko appeared near the cocoon of the Zandith Crockmior life boat. Neither of us noticed it until it moved because it had blended into the surrounding crystals and rocks so perfectly. Gastonishs eyes grew wide as she looked upon the gecko. The small lizard, with bulbous eyes lashed out it's long tongue and plucked an insect from Gastonish's collection displayed on a table. 
Gastonish didn't flinch, nor did she show any signs of frustration. Looking at the gecko for the longest time, Gastonish finally revealed her thoughts as she said, There are a large variety of reptiles on this world. Do you know, I could mend aspects of DNA like human, frog and lizard to create a new species of intelligent reptiles? They could be humanoid in appearance with your choice of variables like size, scales, horns or your choice of wings. In fact, I could easily cross link insect DNA or better yet combine mammal, reptile and insect. The possibilities for the results are endless and all the choices could be yours to make. With all of the variety of life, I could contrive any number of new subspecies. So many already use frequency as communication like chirping birds, barking dogs or buzzing insects. I could give them whatever level of intelligence we wish.
Arent you worried you will also create a God complex for yourself as a result? Feeling as comfortable as I was in the presence of my mother, I often spoke my mind.
All people mimic God in one form or another everyday. Gastonish reminded me.
I think we should just keep true to our mandate and concentrate on the insects since the creation of some reptilian sub species will not contribute to our plans of returning to the Ide era. Any deviation from what we need to do will just slow us down. I tried to be sensitive as I explained though it was apparent I was less than successful.
Dropping the idea of medaling with the DNA of earthen creatures, Gastonish never spoke about it again.

On the verge of celebration, at the age of eight, which was equal to the human age of eighteen or nineteen, I was beginning to feel more daring. I still felt a strange feeling every time I was near Sally Coppler. She was my first crush. To me, Sally was like venturing into a hidden valley filled with natural beauty, a paradise, unspoiled by human hands. It had always been there, waiting for me to discover. I didn't feel like I was a whole person unless I was near Sally. In those instances, I had a very difficult time expressing my feelings. If I were to act, my choices were endless, but the consequences were usually the same, and not all were positive. It was like Evon would have to start its emotional therapy on me from the beginning. Over analyzing the situation prevented me from having the confidence to ask Sally out. Even though I had a hard time expressing my feelings to her, I decided to put all of my feelings aside, and simply focus on asking Sally out on a date, no matter the outcome. I had to leave it up to fate, if fate were possible.
All day at school, I was looking for the right moment. Every time I thought the moment was golden, I would either pause too long or some other distraction would take place and interfere; a loud noise, or a fellow student would show up or some other diversion of the like. 
Whether a phobia or not, I had a good idea the government was keeping a close watch on me, so I searched for opportunities to play inconspicuous games. Mr. Dalton would have guest speakers come to our schoolhouse classroom like NICAP scientists with peculiar theories, high ranking military air-force and infantry men suggesting battle tactics and astronauts from NASA, whom I would take a special interest in talking to. 
Domin had some very curious comments about strategies, especially the ones concerning the military. It was as though he had experience in the matter.
If I disapproved with the ideas or intentions of our guests, I would miss lead them with interlaced variations of truthful possibilities or misguided viewpoints. But usually, I would provide pages of information for them to consider. Like the time I almost gave away the mathematic solution to create a controlled chrystalic electro-magnetic field. What it would do, was create an impenetrable field to any size, shape and form. Though they were super interested, I could never give away any information of the device which would be needed to direct the encrypted computer command information and electro-magnetic currents through the crystals. 
I was always careful not to give too much information. My mother and I were worried about unknowingly causing change to the future. However, I always believed we began altering the future the moment we came out of the Genation nebula and co-existed with this present past. I believed, if we altered the course of a single photon of light, the future would forever after be changed.

The lunch bell rang and I felt it was my big chance to win the love of my teen age dream girl. I followed her outside. I would have walked with her, but she was with her friends. I watched her all lunch hour, almost spying, waiting for a chance to talk to her alone, but of course she stuck with her friends all lunch hour. In the classroom I felt very confident I could ask her out right then and there. I stood up out of my desk and walked over to her. She looked up to me with her dreamy innocent green eyes. I drew a blank and asked, Is your pen leaking?
No, She replied with a slight giggle.
You can borrow mine if it does. I offered awkwardly.
I never felt so stupid in my entire life. I went back to my desk while everyone was snickering and laughing at me. I sat with my head down and felt like it was over. She would never go out with me now. I thought, Not only does she see an ugly, lumpy, grey kid, but he makes stupid comments too. With my head down on the desk, I let out a deep breath to clear my mind so I could relax.
Eddy? Whispered a female voice. I jerked my head, snapping it to the right and fixed my eyes on Sally. She was smiling at me and sent electricity through my twin spines. She looked at me, before she whispered, My pen is broken, could you fix it?
My heart skipped a beat. She tossed me her pen and I tossed her mine. When I examined her pen, I found the ball point was missing. It seemed strange the pen wasn't leaking ink. I opened the pen where it was threaded together at the center to examine the ink cylinder inside, but the pen was stuffed with paper, and the ink cylinder was missing. I unfolded the paper, and found a note addressed to me, which read;        
                                 
Eddy,

Thanks for the offer, it was really sweet, 
but next time you want to ask me something, 
don't hesitate. 
No need to beat around the bush.

P.S. Do you think you can help me with the ten questions for chapter five?    
          
Truly yours, 

Sally C.

That powerful feeling surged through the fibers of my body again, where I felt like I could change the world. My smile stretched from ear to ear. I had a very noticeable blue blush. The embarrassment of my facial expression was uncomfortable for the last half hour of class but I was not capable of wiping the grin off my face.
Domin looked around the room at the laughing students. Unable to figure out what everyone was laughing at, Domin said, What? What're all you goofballs laughing at? Between looking around at each of the laughing students, Domin would pause and stare at me suspiciously.
A very good question, Domin. I missed the joke. Would one of you care to let me in on it? When Mr. Dalton addressed the students, everyone tried to snuff out their laughter with awkward giggles and smirks. Impatient with the silliness, Mr. Dalton resumed his lesson.
Kinta was the only one who did nothing to conceal his smile, but a bright display of teeth was common for him. 
Though the other students didnt know what prompted the smirk on my face, they continued to inconspicuously laugh behind Mr. Daltons back. 
After school, I engaged my secret plan to woo Sally into being my girl. Following Sally as she walked home, I waited until she was out of the schools sight so not to have anyone start rumours. I purposely missed my ride for this reason. Doubt began to enter my mind like an intruder and I started to feel like I couldn't go through with it. That was when I pushed myself into running up to her and starting a conversation.
H-hi Sally, I quivered as I noticed I startled her a little. 
Oh, hi Eddy, do you live down here? Sally spoke with such innocence in her voice.
No, -ah- I live the other way. I pointed behind me with my thumb. 
Eddy, are you walking me home? Was it that obvious? I wondered.
What?... Me? Nnnnooo. I-um, well-ya, I mean, yes. I thought I could help you with those ten questions of chapter five.
Oh, thank you, Eddy, this is great. Her eyes gleamed and her face seemed to glow like the sun. We walked for a long while as I babbled about the home work questions. At a glance, I realized she wasn't really paying attention to me.
You have a long way to walk each day. I noticed, trying to be sincere.
Ya, it seems no matter where I live its never close to the school. Sally told me.
I rubbed the back of my neck uncomfortably when I asked, Sally, I often wondered what it was that brought you and your family to this Island? A moment of silence made me regret asking the question. You don't have to answer if you feel the question is too personal.
Well, it is personal.
I'm sorry. I dropped my head to find a quick topic to redeem the conversation.
Its okay, I guess. she giggled uncomfortably, I'm a hacker. One day I was following up on a rumour I over heard through a highly secured Internet chat-line. It took me into secure government files. It was just for fun. I mean, all I wanted to do was to see just how far I could get. I was just about to give it up when I found a small opening through a back file. I was in. I found myself in forbidden territory. I began to down-load as many files as I could. Some information was about this Island. Something is going on here. Something more than you and I can see and Im not sure what it is... yet.
I agree. I too have a bad feeling about this place. Looking around suspiciously, I found nothing out of the ordinary. 
Anyway, the hack was totally exciting, until a warning began to flash on my monitor. An immaculate government picture, like a flag filled my screen. A small framed picture appeared at the top left corner of the screen. It was of a decorated general or someone of the sort, and it moved in video. It said, You have violated government protective files. You are under arrest. I was shocked and didn't remember exactly but the general on the screen began talking about how it was impossible to escape and how I was in big trouble. I jumped back from my computer and called my parents in the hopes they could miraculously set things right again. Evidently, we were all arrested and interrogated. Somehow, they knew exactly what files I breached, despite my efforts to lie and cover up my tracks. Ironically, the consequences of my actions led us here to this strange Island, the very Island I was hacking into. I don't believe my parents will ever forgive me. She turned her head away from me shamefully. So why are you here? Her voice cracked under the question.
I am a government secret. I said, though it seemed rather obvious to me. Are you okay? Concerned, I placed my hand on her shoulder.
She turned quickly and my hand dropped. Of course. Sally threw her arms around me.
What government files did you stumble into anyway?
Chuckling slightly Sally slid away, You've got some nerve. On the defense Sally wiped her eyes with her fingers. You think I'm going to disrupt my parole this way?
How can you affect your parole when it is only the two of us here?
Only the two of us, Eddy? Ya, right. She obviously believed we were surrounded with surveillance equipment with numerous spies among us. Only, I didn't believe there were people hiding in the bushes. However, I couldn't rule out the means of monitoring us through other ways. I didn't want to worry about it.
How well do you think you know me? I can detect when others are watching us. Be sure, you are safe with me. I told her straight up and there was another moment of silence. Friends? she turned and glanced at me. Her face was stern and cold. What had I done? Was I at a dead end or a turning point? I decided to throw in all of my chips. I stopped and bent down, before I picked a four leaf clover. I asked Sally to stop and open her hand. Delicately, I pulled the four leaf clover apart, placing the petals into the palm of Sallys hand.
This one is for your loyalty, this one is for your innocence, this one is for your trust, and this one is for your... love.
She looked up at me and for a moment we studied each others eyes. Oddly, she said, Your shoe laces are untied.
I glanced down and sure enough she was right. Bending down to tie my steel toed boot, Sally kissed me on the cheek. My cheeks blushed in a baby blue color. I could feel a shadow of her love for me, and I knew it was real. Her eyes locked me in. I couldnt break free, nor did I want to. Sunlight smote through the trees and lit her hair like an aura. Such a memory will stay with me forever. The moment was perfect and fresh. Even the wind delicately blew passed us bringing more life to her dancing sun lit hair.
We walked around a turn in the road. The heavy forest of growth created a domed hallway over our path. 
We came to an old bridge built of stone. It was very solid under our feet and the ivy vines which grew upon it from the brook below couldnt have been more beautiful in my dreams. She stopped and we leaned over the edge and looked down at the small trickling creek. The tranquility of the babbling water was relaxing to us both. Examining the vines, I followed their climb up the stones and over the edge of the arches below us.
Watch this. She said. She opened her hand with the clover petals, and in a deep breath, she blew the clovers away into the stream. I thought she was trying to be a little poetic, but I felt there was something wrong with this poetry. I gave her a questioning look, and she smiled in delight, so I figured I misunderstood her intentions. I shamefully thought she was blowing away her loyalty, innocence, love, and trust.
She seemed happy to be with me, but I began to bring my own feelings into question. I felt as though I didn't belong. Mostly, I didn't know how to describe my feelings, but I was uncomfortable. Was it because she was a human and I was a volk? I walked her to her house and said good-bye. I thought I could feel her emotions switch from love, to disgust, to hiding secrets and wishing she was somewhere else. My added confusion only fueled my frustration. I believe I concealed my discomforts well, however it was not easy to know if my intuitions were correct. I was such a beginner at reading peoples emotions without the assistance of my sertz, I couldnt be sure if my senses were attuned enough.

When the weekend arrived, I slept all day Saturday though thoughts of Sally made it difficult for me to go to sleep at first. I was still bothered as to what she may have meant by blowing away the four-leaf clover. I tried to shake it from my mind but my thoughts would relentlessly come back to it time after time. I struggled with whether or not I should pursue Sally. I was a volk with plans to cross a great distance through space and time. Most likely, I would never return. Yet could she be reason enough for me to stay? I went over and over the possibilities coming to no viable solution. Finally, Evon helped me nod off and I slipped away into my full day of dreams. 
Sunday morning awoke with a scent of mystery in the air. I observed from our living room window how every morning dew drop had captured the light of the young golden sun. Gastonish invited me to sit outside with her while we enjoyed a hot cup of tea and welcomed the new day. The dew drops were losing their twinkle, while Gastonish and I continued talking and relaxing on the front porch. In the distance, the sound of horse hooves came clomping lazily through a nearby path. Both, Gastonish and I honed in on the muffled echo, perking up simultaneously. Before the sound of the trotting horse passed us by, it distinctly became louder. Surely, the rider was coming our way, when sure enough, through the thick forest two horses appeared. Sally, was surprisingly riding a brown horse with a white mark on its nose. She was holding the leather reins attached to the harness of a black horse which was close behind her. I stood up on the porch when she approached.     
The black horse neighed.
Hi Sally, what brings you all the way over here and with an extra horse? The sight of Sally made me so happy inside.
I was just passing through. Sally went on, How would you like to go riding? She asked with a shy smile. 
A horse? I've never rode a horse before.
Its easy, I'll lead.
I walked near to the horse and it backed away slightly. Sally threw me an apple. I caught it and offered it out to the horse with an open palm. It was the first time I fed a horse and it felt great. When the horse trusted me, I climbed onto its silky, black, muscular hide. The horse stumbled a little as it tried to get used to my weight. I was heavy, but the strong steed proved it could handle me, though Im sure I maxed out its load capacity. I waved to Gastonish, and she smiled and waved back to me. I saw approval in my mother's eyes. 
Sally and I rode very high along the steep mountain side on a very narrow path. We traveled up the cone shaped mountain, further than the trail. From our height, I could see for miles. We had been riding for about an hour.
Sally? I asked patiently, How far do you plan on taking me?
Well, She started, I've brought a pack with me loaded with food. I was hoping you wouldn't mind if we made a whole day of this.
I stopped the horse, climbed off, and walked to the edge of a cliff and gazed out at the view below.
Somehow, I didn't feel right. I was very uncomfortable like a chill ran through my body, penetrating right to my bones. I turned to her to say something, when Sally's smile changed to concern. I could see how happy she was, thinking we could have some sort of relationship. It was a crazy idea though. We were just too different. I was futuristic and from that point of view, Sally was prehistoric.
Sally dismounted from her horse and walked toward me. When Sally opened her arms to give me a hug, I pushed her away, gently.
Sally, I began, I hope you aren't trying to start something here between us. I like you, a lot, but just as a friend. You would probably be better off with someone who is more human. You would probably be happier too. You see, I feel like I am trapped within a costume and I just want to take it off for you and be the human boyfriend you deserve. I would be a volk-friend and that just doesnt sound right. Does it sound right to you? Sally dropped her head for a moment but when she looked back up at me her eyes were welling up. I explained further, I am lost. I'm at a cross roads of my life and I need to make some very important decisions. I am sorry, Sally, it just can't work between us.
Sally was about to say something, but before she could, I reached up and took her hand in my own. Her hand was so much smaller than mine and the pink color of it really stood out against my greyish blue hue. I looked at our hands, before I covered her hand with my other. My gaze lifted and met Sally's sad eyes before I said. Good-bye.
Sally's hand slipped out of mine, before I turned and jumped off the cliff. I was only about ten feet away from the rocks of a small pit below. I leapt down another ten feet to the next step, and onward to another. Landing safely on a sloping base of stones, I ran with wide strides across the boulder tops disappearing into the woods. Watching Sally from a safe distance, I made sure she was able to walk the two horses back down the mountain to where it was safe. Moving like a race car at full throttle, I didn't stop running like a thunder through the jungle until I was home again.

I know, leaving the way I did was not cool, but I had to stop the relationship before it started. It was simply for the best. I began to regret how insensitive I was to Sallys feelings when I saw how hurt she was the next day at school. I did everything I could to avoid her. Rumor reached my ears how she gave some story to my buddy Kinta. Kinta felt sorry for Sally. He comforted her, before he fell head over heels for her. Sally was happy all over again. Well, she must have really wanted a boyfriend for her to snag Kinta as quickly as she did. I sure hoped volk girls were different.
Kinta and Sally believed I had no idea about their secret relationship for about two days. They were kissing in the class when we were celebrating a students fourteenth birthday.
I learned, trust was a rare fruit. What I knew in my mind began to conflict with what I felt in my heart. My eyes found it hard to look at Sally and Kinta, yet it was harder still to look away.
