Trust was the most important basis for a standing long lasting relationship. Though I was the one who put an end to a relationship with Sally, I couldn't shake the feeling how she had betrayed me somehow. Jealousy revealed so much of myself to myself. Love cannot survive if trust begins to weaken, for love and trust go hand in hand. I was the problem. Not only did I not trust Sally, I didnt trust myself. If trust could not be strengthened, how was love to survive? How could I have been so blind?
'Perhaps I was in love with her.'

I didn't know how much she meant to me until she was gone...

Chapter 7

As the young night grew into the first hour of morning, Darkness surrounded us and strange sounds of the sleeping forest broke the silence continually. Gastonish and I quietly crept out of our home and followed our sertz into the woods. By the lights of the eyes of our little sertz we were led through a path to the hiding place where we kept our gear. Branches of trees, tropical leaves and vines appeared from the darkness in the red glowing eyes of the small sertz.
Xonox led Gastonish and I to where we hid our gear. It was their in a six foot deep cavern of sheer rock walls where it was obvious a great rock had split in two. The cavern took us between the wide expanse of rock. Gastonish had to move some sizable stones to get at the items hidden within. The romstrunn, lintin, boots and hickoop disks. We let our uniforms slink and dress onto us. Gastonish and I had to move quickly because our volk suits gave too much light in the extreme darkness. We proceeded to use our hickoop transports. With these devices of compact energy spheres, we traveled through the sky so fast, it was like a flash of lightning lit the sky from one end to the other. Though we could fool the naked eye, it was a growing concern which the military and air force might investigate. We were transported in a flash to the cave once again.
My hickoop bubble of energy disappeared like the pop of a bubble. Gastonishs pink hickoop also disappeared when the power was shut off. We folded up the hickoop frames into their disk forms. The available moonlight was adequate for us. The air was cooler at the cave with a wind strong enough to be unpleasant for human standards. Gastonish and I rolled the boulder to the side so we could enter the caves corridor. Closing the entrance behind us, the corridor led us to the main inner sanctum. We set out on our regular routine. This routine consisted of surveying the progress of the Zandith Crockmior life-boat. I checked its growth for any visual defects, listened for a pulse by placing my ear against the outer wall of the cocoon. Next, I had to physically and visually inspect the integrity of the cocoons structure. Temperature, smell and color were all in normal healthy ranges. Everything checked out fine.
Meanwhile, Gastonish checked on the insects we were growing. She prepared to feed them. We had Mosquitoes, honey-bees, male and female red and black ants, caterpillars, beetles, an assortment of spiders, cockroaches and cicadas. Each species was kept separate and enclosed within the twelve smaller chambers which surrounded the base of the spacious main inner area of the crystal lit cave where the cocoon for the life-boat stood tall and ominous. Between the main room and each of the separate smaller rooms were access hallways about six feet in length. Over the course of time Gastonish and I collected junk metal pieces, construction tools, and other related scrap metal items. We piled items inside the cave. When we needed to build something, we would carry the items inside to the main chasm. Applying the power of the lintin, we melted and forged large solid doors. In order to enter one of the separate bug chambers, one had to pass through two sets of doors which were at either end of the short hallway. The two sets of doors served as a means to keep the insects from escaping its chamber. The sertz were quite capable of herding the insects back into their chamber if ever they managed to escape.

During several routine check-ups, I couldn't stop thinking about Sally. I snapped out of my dream state when Gastonish needed my attention. Gastonish was the strongest person I knew. I approached my mother.
I want to find a job tomorrow. I suggested, but Gastonish did not look up from the romstrunn. This way we will have more money than the government gives us. What do you think?
This idea of yours, to find a job? I don't think it agrees with the governments plan for you. Where are you going to look?
Well, I will try the lumber yard in town, Lugger Lumber. A hearty answer came forth with confidence. Though Gastonish wondered if I was attempting to be humorous.
Oh, don't be silly, Eddy. You're too young. They won't hire a child.
I am seven years old and stronger than anyone there. All I have to do is convince them to give me a chance. Besides if you convert my volk age to a humans age, I am old enough to drive.
Gastonish shook her head and turned away from me as she cleared her throat. After a moment of silence, we just left the conversation the way it was, and called it a night.

With no written application, or any such previous preparation, I entered the office of the Lugger Lumber yard. The door chimed when it opened before it closed heavily behind me. The office was filled with tools and other artifacts of the trade. To my left was a man digging through various bins of nails. He was the last to look up and notice me. Standing at the front desk were two men who decided not to continue their conversation at the sound of the closing door. The youngest fellow of the men stood behind the counter with his eyes and mouth wide open. It was like I was standing within a snap shot with everyone frozen in place. All eyes were locked and focused on me. 
Ah, hi I'm Eddy, I would like to apply for a job. I stated with a wave of my hand. The men began to laugh. 
What is this? asked the man on the left who pointed and chuckled, A joke?
The man in the middle approached me. Ahh, hi, uh, my name is Jack. Did you get authorization to apply for a job here by one of the Islands officials?
No. I answered awkwardly.
I don't know if you wanted a laugh out of us or if you are serious, but, ah, we don't need any help at the moment. He spoke very slow and slurred most of his words. You should leave your resume with us before you go. Thanks for stopping by.
Is there someone I can talk to who is in charge? I was persistent, I am very serious.
Oh, well, I am the uh, manager. Jack said with a slight quiver in his  voice.
I hope you haven't decided to not hire me because of my appearance.
Whoa, whoa, whoa, now slow down before you start making a speech. We do not discriminate. He put one hand on my shoulder, smiled and gave a slight squeeze to my shoulder plate.
What is that? Jack squeezed my shoulder plates in several places as he examined me. It sure ain't no muscle.
I am not exactly human, by your standards, but when it comes to muscle, I'm the real deal.
Well, I was not ready for this encounter at all. If you don't mind, I need to make a quick phone call. Jack approached the counter, Why dont you guys get to know one another a little bit? And be courteous. Jack dropped his voice to a whisper. He didnt think I could hear him but I could. Be very courteous. I dont want any trouble. Jack turned back to me for a moment and smiled smugly. He went into a small office and closed the door. No doubt, he had standard operating protocol and procedures in place to report strange and unusual sightings, especially when it came to volks. Likely, he had to contact the Island officials for something as simple as administration clearance. When Jack returned he smiled and took me on a tour of the yard. I was asked some questions about their stock of lumber products. I was surprised at how limited my knowledge was as I could not answer all of the questions. Regardless of my lack of knowledge, I was hired on the spot.
My second day at Lugger Lumber yard was my first full day of work. I started at entry level for the job, though I was offered more I insisted to not only be fair but to be treated fairly. I emptied garbage and kept the yard neat. While I was picking up metal bands from wood stacks and straightening up any mess the military contractors left behind, I memorized the different kinds of wood and their measurements. Casually, I worked around the other employees and spoke to each one. Usually, they wanted to see something of my strength in action, so I would lift something heavy until Jack came out and pointed his finger at us, warning us not to use excessive force which might be unsafe. He did not want to see anyone get hurt. 
As I was cleaning in the office, small talk allowed me to get to know Claire, the secretary. She was a very well mannered lady who always had a story to tell no matter who walked into her office. 

I had a special ability to sense a persons talent even if the person couldnt see it for themself. When I spoke to the people, they felt I was really speaking to them on their level, connecting to them as I authentically cared for each one. On the Knolix Island the citizens began to shine with their own special abilities. I built a stage where I could lead people to find their talent. The citizens of the Knolix Island's small town of Scamp discovered they were writers, directors, comedians, actors, public speakers, singers, DJs, dancers. All sorts of talents were discovered, encouraged and shared. 
One of my other passions was the development of beautiful landscapes for people where I easily worked all night. When property owners woke up in the morning, they were surprised to find inspiring landscapes of art which were customarily unique for the specific person I was working for. In most cases, the Island folk found the new paths and sitting areas in places where it was too steep, over grown, rocky or otherwise unusable. The people told me I was a creative genius.
The Island people seemed to love me, because my presence had a way of making everyones life better, but I knew, not everyone was happy with me. For example, Sally wasn't speaking to me though I redid the yard of her parents home with priority. Even Domin had a grudge, but Gastonish told me I would never be able to make people like me.

After my first day of entry level work at Lugger Lumber, Jack decided he wanted to see more of me, out in the yard. I was sent out to find Pete, the forklift driver who wasn't in the day before.
Jack? I asked, There must be about four fork-lifts out in the yard, how will I know who Pete is?
Oh, heh, heh. Chuckled Jack under his breath, Just go out and listen. Whoever is yelling and cursing the most is Pete.
Not a very dependable description, regardless, I set out to find its accuracy. I quickly put on some custom fit work gloves and shy as I was, slowly walked out into the yard. To my left I saw a young boy on a forklift, dormant, and tapping a calculator. I didn't know if he was working out a problem or wasting time, but I was positive his name was not 'Pete.'
I looked far to the left of the yard where I could hear a very loud voice, but it was not cursing. The man behind the voice was older than the others and much happier. He was singing very loud opera songs. I walked over to him through the dusty yard and asked, Could you tell me where Pete is? I guess he did not hear me, so I asked again yelling in an attempt to throw my voice over the noise of both the fork-lifts powerful diesel engines and the cranked music of his radio.
Excuse me, could you tell me where Pete is?!!! I hollard. The forklift was in need of a new muffler.
He jerked his head toward me, raised his eye brow above his widened eye, and studied me for a moment. He spoke, Go look over by the 2 by 6 number 3 piles. I could hardly hear what he said over the motors unending burp.
What?!!! I yelled. He began yelling words at me as he revved up his engines so I could not hear. He pointed to the end of the yard. As he drove away, he began to laugh in an animated cartoon sort of way.
I was surprised when I arrived at the back of the yard and met Pete. I knew it was him right away. Blast marak lan arashted san flanken merl blank lanken! He was yelling and cursing as he rammed the forklift into a pile of wood and spun the tires. The forks were not going to go in any further. The gravel and dirt were quickly being removed from under the front tires as they spun. A snap was heard, and the pile collapsed onto his forks nice and neat. He turned and looked at me through his shades and said, I'm awesome.
His beard made up for the bald spot on his head and he seemed well built for a human, except his beer belly kinda clashed.
I am looking for Pete. I took a step toward him.
Pete just held me in his gaze for a moment before he answered, Thats me.
With a dirty under shirt and a worn yellow hard hat, Pete looked like he was likely a biker when he wasn't at work. I wasn't sure if I intimidated him because his mind was somewhat scattered despite his calm composure.
Pete just stared at me like he was trying to figure me out. What kinda Island is this? He spoke very low.
I cocked my head slightly in response to his question, Pardon me? my black eyes called for a response and I knew he was beginning to feel uncomfortable.
Pete quickly snapped to attention, Oh, um, Whats your name? He smiled brightly and asked politely.
Eddy, Eddy Evon.
Well Eddy, I guess I should tell you a little bit about the yard. He snorted with a smirk. Jack is an idiot! Trent doesn't think! Darren only knows numbers! Burl is the owners son, so you can expect him to act like one. The only ones you should ever trust or listen to is either me or Charley.
Just take it easy, Pete. I can decide who I can trust all by myself. Pete needed to know I was not about to be controlled by him or anyone else.
Once again, Pete smiled with a toothy grin which seemed to hurt his face because when all his facial muscles bunched up, wrinkles and creases caused his eyes to close tightly. Just stick with me, you'll be all right.
The way Pete was talking made me wonder just how much I could trust him. One thing I learned was if a human told you to trust them, raise a red flag.
Eddy, Pete moved a pile of papers away from beside him. Hop on! The empty room beside him was not very big. Come on, Spot! Hop, hop. Called Pete, when I hesitated.
I hopped on beside him and asked. Did you just call me, Spot?
Ya. He replied as we drove off along the back piles. We bounced over deep pot holes and I thought I was going to be thrown from the machine. Maybe later you can fill in some of those holes I've left. Pete said before we continued bouncing over more large holes.
We came around a corner of the last row and at the end of the isle was the teenager, still plucking his calculator as if in a daze.
Trent! Pete shouted at the boy. Trent raised his head slowly to respond. Can't you figure out simple math? How many lineal feet are you looking for? 
Trent was very young, just barely out of school. He had mussed up sandy blond hair and bucked teeth. The look in Trent's eyes was like he really wanted to be somewhere else, anywhere else.
Sixty eight. With tired mannerism Trent answered Pete.
Well, you have seventy in that pile in front of you. Hurry up, you should have been finished an hour ago. Pete was not the boss, but he sure liked to act like one. Loser! I heard him breathe under the noise of his forklift. Thats Trent, Pete reminded me, Other people suffer from normal things like drinking problems. Trent suffers from math problems.
We pulled up to an open bundle of 2 by 6s. So, do you plan on working in the yard for the rest of your life? Pete asked me.
I'm not sure, maybe. I replied with uncertainty. How about you, Pete? Do you have a unique idea or venture you wish to chase?
Actually, ya, I've been trying to invent a way to strip bark off logs, right after they fall. I could end up with a lot of bucks if I pulled it off. Pete held up his wrist to see the time. He wiped away the mud from the watch face and said, Its time to feed Rex.
We parked the forklift in front of the office. Give me a second. Pete spat.
He went into the office for a moment. When he came back he was carrying a very large bag labeled Kibblies. The dried dog food bag seemed too awkward for him to carry so I swiftly plucked it out of his arms. Pete had no objections when I assisted him. He led me around the corner beside the office to a dog house. Pete said, Stay here.
He proceeded cautiously to the dog dish. When he started to fill the bowl, the noise of dried dog food on plastic woke up the dog. Silently and forcefully, Rex burst out of the dog house. When it realized it was Pete feeding him, he opened his mouth to pant and it wagged its tail. When Rex looked beyond Pete and noticed me, I guess he could sense my fear, because he began hacking and waving his head around vigorously. 
Rex had the appearance of a real old dog, but as sickly as it looked, it still had a fierceness about it. With dark fur, some grey patches were growing through. Even I was scared at Rex in part because he was such a large dog. 
In response to the strange coughing Rex seemed to be doing, I asked. What is he doing?
Hes barking at you. Pete humorously explained. He got into some cleaning chemicals from the bathroom one day, almost killed him. Luckily he only lost his voice. We kept him because he makes a great guard dog, like a shy fart, he's silent but deadly.
We watched for a moment while the rugged guard dog chomped on its dinner. For the rest of the day I helped Pete fill orders.

Later that day, Gastonish and I made our way back to the cave where I looked up at the tall cocoon built for the Zandith Crockmior life-boat. It looks like the life-boat is about to break out of its cocoon any moment. Are you sure we have to wait as long as you predict? I mean, is there any possibility it can be ready in the next few days? An anxious wave came over me as I wasn't sure if I wanted to leave my home on earth.
It'll be ready very soon, but there's still more progress to be made. The blond Gastonish answered. Besides, after the life-boat has broken out of its cocoon, it must eat all of the insects I've prepared for it. If we rush ahead, or miss a step it might jeopardize our mission. I want to start out as strong as possible or we will lessen our chances of returning to Verticus successfully. She walked over to a cluttered work table and sat down on a stool. As she tinkered with the insect growth stimulating equipment, it was obvious she was in deep thought. She would perform an attempt to go home and she would orchestrate it all to perfection.
I wanted to tell her about the progress I made with regards to my new job, but she was just too busy and focused on the goal of returning home. My good news would just have to wait.
For all intents and purposes, the Zandith Crockmior still looked like a monstrous wasp to me. I found it fascinating how growing this insect would lead to our space craft and our means of taking us to our home world crossing an unbelievable expanse of space and time.
                                
The school week went by quickly. I worked at the lumber yard every day after class. When the weekend came, I could devote myself to a full day of work. I planned to start my day of sleep immediately after work so I could awaken sometime late Sunday. I walked into the office of the lumber yard and punched in. Darren was the only one there. We said our good mornings to start the day as I tried on the new boots which the company designed for me. They seemed like strong and sturdy boots, except they seemed more military somehow rather than the regular work wear style everyone else wore.
Once again, we're in for another slow weekend. Darren started in a mumble. Lately business has been very slow, so I had to find my own entertainment to keep me awake. Come on, Darren waved his hand for me to follow. 
We walked outside, just as a pigeon swooped down and dive bombed Darrens head. I tried to wave it away, as Darren went into a jerk like fit waving his arms in defense as though a flock was attacking him. The pigeon flew back up onto the beams of the ceiling and cooed. The other pigeons who were perched on the beams joined in with the mocking symphony of pigeon song, or was it an audience of laughing fans.
I hate those little varmints. Darren was more than frustrated as he tried to wipe the white pigeon poop out of his bushy brown hair with his hand. Darren shook his head. He bent down and picked up a small piece of metal, perfectly square, Four by four inches. He looked at me and began to talk like a teacher. I tried not to focus on the white that still remained in his hair. These are used on the corners of each wood bundle to protect it when they strap it down for transport. When we receive our product, these metal things collect on the ground and become nothing but useless junk; unless you use your imagination.
He threw it, snapping his wrist like the metal was a small throwing star. It spun through the air like a deadly weapon. As it spun it tilted and swerved to the left. By the centrifical force, all its own, it tilted back and swerved to the right. Gaining speed it quickly burrowed its sharp edged corner into a bundle of 2 by 8s.
See? Darren motioned with his hand, They're like throwing stars! He bent down and picked up a handful more of the little metal square sheets. I was impressed how he switched character. I thought for sure he was angry and wanted to throw the metal at the birds but now it seemed the birds were the last things on his mind.
You know, thats a pretty good shot. You've got a lot of kick in your arm. I complimented Darren as I curled my own arm tight and slapping it. 
Well, here. Darren persisted, holding out a metal square for me. Take a swing.
He handed me a couple of the metal plates. I don't know about this, Darren. I-I mean won't somebody love to wrap our knuckles for this?
No, don't worry about it. One of your jobs today will be to pull them out with a pair of pliers. Darren had a point. Saturdays do not have a reputation for being busy. I gave into the temptation and threw one of the small metal squares with a giant swing of my arm. The power and driving effort I put into my pitch wafted a powerful amount of wind at Darren; and messed up his hair.
Pete and Trent skidded their vehicles into the dusty parking lot. They had been speeding. Trent fell out of the cab of his truck laughing hysterically. Pete, on the other hand, was quite calm and stepped out of his rusty pinto with a very large smile on his face. The way the sun reflected off his cheek bones sure brightened my day.
Darren walked over to the bundle of 2X4s and examined it by wiping his hand over the surface. His metal throwing star had one corner stuck into the wood. He missed entirely. Darren spoke quietly, before something sharp caught his open palm and cut his skin. Ouch! He said as he pulled his hand away. Darren took a closer look, and found a thin line in the bundle, like a slot. Sure enough, the square metal plate had been driven entirely into the wood, except for a little sharp corner. He pushed on his cut and looked at me curiously.
 
Pete glanced down the road, before he shot a terrifying look at Darren and I. Customer!!! Pete shouted.
Quick! Darren said. Make like you're busy. with a wave of his hand, Darren quickly darted off to the office.
Trent headed straight for the forklift and booted the engine into gear. Pete grabbed his lunch pale out of his truck and walked into the yard calmly. I picked up nine twelve foot two by ten firs, hefted them onto my shoulder, and started walking like I had a purpose.

In under twenty minutes, Pete and I collected a lumber order and loaded it up on the companys one ton truck. I am impressed. Pete said. I have never seen an order of this size completed so quickly before. He smiled and I felt rewarded. I rode with Pete on the forklift and when we came around a corner we found Trent and Darren throwing metal squares at the piles.

Pete's words were cut short as a sweet little pigeon decided to defecate on his bald spot. The stunned look in Pete's eyes were full of disbelief before his eyes rolled upward as though he'd be able to confirm the worst. Pete swung the door open holding a very large and powerful nail gun. Trent followed behind him with a pellet gun. What do you think you are going to do with that? Darren asked skeptically. Pete had just finished attaching the air hose assembly to the nail gun. Together they began shooting at the birds in the rafters. Trent was laughing, and enjoying himself while shooting. Pete, wearing a Lugger Lumber yard hard hat and safety goggles, wore a very violent expression on his face.

No one could help, they wanted to, but it was too dangerous for them to get close to me. When I finally did get my boot off, the blood was spilling out of it.
Water. clearly I called.
Trent, get him some water. Pete ordered.
I'm not getting a thing! Trent defiantly retaliated.
I'll get it. Darren complied as he wiped some dust off his sleeve. The look in his eye was of energized fear. Quickly turning the valve on maximum, Darren stood by and watched with the intent to do whatever else was needed.

Leaning toward my foot, I began examining it. Luckily the nail missed the bone. Darren approached me and said, Eddy, take it easy and let me put this bandage on?

I was trying to get the nail out of your boot and you knocked me about six feet into the air. The heat of attitude steamed off his words. He pointed to the ground behind him with his thumb.

Pete brought the truck with a large cloud of dry dust. Darren and Pete held onto a shoulder each, and Trent held me by the ankles. Man, Darren mumbled, This guy weighs a ton.
Yeah? Well come down here and give it a try. Trent said, stumbling under the pressure of my ankles.
They scuffed their feet and jerked about until we were about halfway to the truck. Put me down. I said. They helped me onto my back. They were grunting and breathing more than I was. I began to wonder who needed medical attention more.
I rolled over onto my stomach and asked, Hey, how about helping a friend to get back onto his feet, huh?
They began to make more absurd noises than before, and they werent even lifting yet. When they did finally lift me up, I placed my left foot down to help support my weight. We jostled our way toward the pick up and they rolled me into the company flat bed truck.
I tuned into a sense of confusion amongst the crew in the cab. As we pulled out, I heard a tone in their voices which confirmed something else was bothering them.
Should we call someone in charge of this Island to come and get Eddy? Trent asked.
No! Pete told Trent. We will be blamed for this for sure, but if we do something to help it will be better than asking for help.
I had no idea who was driving, except who ever it was, he drove very fast with seemingly little control. I was in the back of a racing pick-up truck again, only this time I was going to hang on a lot tighter. The roads in these parts were rarely paved, so we mostly traveled over dirt and pot holes. My right foot bounced and jerked around. I screamed out in pain. It felt as though a solid ball was expanding within my wound. I looked down at my foot and noticed the swelling and dark purple bruise had a hole in the middle of it. I called to Evon, keeping my voice low enough so no one else could hear me. My foot hurts so much, Evon, is there anything you can do to relieve the pain?
I heard Evon speak to me from within my ear. AS YOU WISH LORD, I WILL RELIEVE YOUR PAIN AND SPEED THE HEALING. Slowly, the puncture wound continuously trickled blood all over the deck until my whole foot had a coating of smeared dried blood.
Pete quickly stopped the pick up outside the doctors office. The office was located right in the center of the little town. Scamp was situated within a long narrow of tall cliffs. Within this little pocket, no one could see the town from the sea. Even in the brightest summer days, Scamp seemed dark and the days shorter than they needed to be. Somehow I always detected a musty smell from the tight enclosure of rock when I went to town. The little town of Scamp always reminded me of an old western town only the buildings on either side of the street were built right up against the sheer rock walls. The street lights were always lit with tall street lamps and the windows were softly lit with a cozy orange glow. The front of all the stores were boxy, old and run down. Pete ran in before he quickly ran back out with a man and a stretcher, then Pete jumped up to me on the flat deck. Dr. Evon came out with his eyes wide. He seemed as concerned over me as a father would be over his child who was on his death bed. The doctor handed Pete the end of the stretcher. The two of them slid the stretcher under me. I looked down and noticed at my feet was my old friend, Doctor Evon. I smiled at him and his teeth glistened right back at me.
They carried me directly to a room, grunting, groaning and scuffing their feet in a small but quick rhythm. The men made their way over the wooden front walks which ran down the length of the town on either side of the street. The outside of the doctors office looked like a run down convenient store. The back of the small store was also built against a solid rock cliff. I was carried through the door where I was amazed to see a fancy sterile white medical center. There was much more space within the complex than the run down store outside let on. I was told the Island wanted to preserve its heritage, but I knew the building styles were nothing more than a front. Obviously the medical center was built vastly into the rock cliff and it was loaded with the latest cutting-edge technology of the age.
A nurse entered the room holding a small blue plastic pan containing a yellow transparent liquid. Here, she spoke calmly, Soak your foot in this, it will cleanse your foot from any dirt, bacteria or diseases. Do you know if the nail was rusty?
No, it wasn't. The nail was brand new. Pete answered quickly. A couple of soldiers came out of a door and immediately escorted my work-mates outside. Pete was sweating and had a strange look in his eye, like he was worried about more than just my foot. I hoped he did not feel too responsible for the accident.
Dr. Evon entered with some friends and the nurse left. The doctor quickly began asking me questions. Eddy, how are you doing? Its been a long time.
I'm doing all right, I guess. I paused, Well, except for the recent incident. We both looked down at my foot.
I have already told the nurse to contact your mother, so she should be here within the hour. In the mean time would you mind if I give you a check up? Dr. Evon asked.
Don't you mean a test? Sure, why not? tests were common place for me. People often felt they should ask my permission for things.
Doctor Evon listened to my heart, examined my eyes, ears, nose and throat. He took my blood pressure, a small skin sample and five vials of blood. After taking my measurements with a small tape measure, he did a lot of poking and prodding before he started again with more questions.
Have you been sick at all lately?
No! I answered.
Any broken bones, sprains or deep cuts?
No! I glanced past him and noticed we were not alone. Dr. Evon had a couple of new faces with him. Who are your friends? I asked.
Oh, this is Dr. Steenberg and this is Dr. Hollobuff. They are very interested in meeting with you. I told them you might be interested in discussing some medical barriers with them.
I would be happy to. Lucky for you men I happen to have this little inconvenience just as you were passing through. they were specifically interested in finding some way for my blood to become adapted to human cells so humans might gain in my special abilities. I explained to them how there were some techniques they could try. If no progress was made in the early stages of their tests, it would prove how volk DNA was vastly different from that of a human. The Doctors left both inspired and frustrated.
The door opened and my mother walked in. She looked at me with worried eyes, but when she noticed Dr. Evon, her face lit-up with joy and she welcomed him with a hug.
Doctor Evon. Gastonish said, Its been so long, how are you?
I'm fine, Gastonish. Dr. Evon spoke with a sudden positive mood swing. I have given Eddy a complete examination while his foot was soaking in the anti-bacterial solution. Lets take a look now. Doctor Evon held my foot by the ankle and lifted it out of the solution. My foot was very swollen and bruised with purple and blue shades.
The Doctor remarked on how well the hole in my foot was healing. He never witnessed such rapid results before. The bleeding stopped and Doctor Evon re-bandaged my foot. I was given a large metal crutch to get around on.
Gastonish, if you have a moment I would like to see you in my examination room. Dr. Evon politely gestured with his hand. His tone and influence of professionalism allowed him to get his way with humans many times in the past. But under the pink skin, Gastonish was no human.
If it can wait, perhaps next time. I would like to take Eddy home and look after him. she was determined to protect me instinctively even though no threat was present.
Sorry Gastonish, this can not wait. Gastonish surrendered to the doctors wish. She realized in the past how Dr. Evon out ranked the other doctors. If he wanted you to do something, he would ask. If you didn't do as Dr. Evon asked he would use his military power of influence and he would have you do his bidding anyway. So Gastonish swallowed her fear and followed him into the room.

The next day was Sunday, my day of sleep. My mother used the romstrunn and futuristic suit to completely heal my foot. I was supposed to sleep for the entire day, but at noon, Pete drove into my driveway with Darren and Trent in the back of his pick-up truck. They all hopped out of the truck and pressured my red wigged mother to wake me up. When I got to the door all three of them were there to greet me. They were sincerely concerned for my well-being. Especially Pete, because he felt responsible for shooting me in the foot.
Hi, ya, Eddy. Darren said with a shy wave of his hand.
Eddy, hows the foot? asked Pete with a grin.
Ya, greeted Trent with a tip of his cowboy hat, howre you feeling?
I'm doing all right. I replied, You guys sure are rugged to come down to my place to see how I'm doing.
Thats not the only reason, Eddy. said Darren. We're wondering if you wanna, Murmur murmur Darrens voice became softer and softer until no one could understand a word.
Eddy. Pete began, I think what Darrens trying to ask is if you feel up to joining us for a little fishing. You see, we're gonna take a boat and if you're sitting down most of the time, it won't hurt you're limp.
I don't know, guys. I said sleepily. I really should go back to bed.
Ya, but we've brought something for you to help you feel better faster. Trent said, pointing at the truck.
I leaned over putting my weight into my crutch and wobbled out the front door. I limped over to the truck in a convincing fashion to lead them to believe I was still in pain. I did not want them to ask questions about my rapid recovery. They followed me to the truck before they gathered around. Pete reached into the back of the truck and pulled out a very large fishing pole, with heavy metal fishing line wound onto a bulky spool.
What kind of fish do you plan on catching? I asked with wonderment. They began to laugh at my surprise.
Shark, the largest and most deadliest fish to inhabit this Islands shore. We have been going out every Sunday to catch one for the past month. We catch them before we let them go. So? Pete asked. Are you game?
Well. I considered the offer. I did wanted them to accept me. Okay, I'm in. Darren, Pete and Trent smiled and congratulated me for my decision. I certainly was not about to mention a word about a shark to my mother though.
After waving good-bye to Gastonish, we drove for twenty minutes on a dirt road. I sat in the back, half asleep, with Trent, who was also half asleep, while Pete drove with Darren beside him. While we drove Trent managed to say, Pete sure was worried about you.
There is really no need to be worried especially now. I reassured him, The puncture wound isnt bad, besides it was an accident.
It wasnt your foot that scared him but the fact it was him who hurt you. There are rumours on this Island how if someone hurts you in anyway, they are liable to disappear off the face of the earth. Even still, Pete thinks his life is in danger. You know, Eddy, this whole Island exists just for you. You are the government's pride and joy, their baby. No one else on the Island is as important as you.
Thats not true Trent, and you know it. I retaliated, Everyone is here for some reason or another.
You might believe people are here for a reason, and Ill bet thats what they want you to believe, but no one needs to be on this Island. There are lots of other places for these people to go, but where else could you go?
I just cant believe you dont trust the Island officials. This Island exists to protect the governments people, the governments secrets and the governments favourites. I told him.
The three of us from the lumber yard? Trent questioned, Government's favourites? We dont even hold a candle to you. Finally, we stopped on the sandy beach at the oceans shore. The slight cool salty breeze was unbeatably refreshing. We took a moment to absorb the view of the wide open ocean before us.
Everyone was quite excited. Pete and Darren came around to the back of the truck, You guys arent going to believe this, but Eddy believes we are just as important to the government and this Island as he is. Trent blurted as he handed them their fishing rods and tackle boxes.
Grab a clue, Eddy. Huffed Darren.
Pete reached up to take some tackle boxes, What exactly were the two of you talking about? Petes face was tight with suspicion as he pulled his sunglasses down to the end of his nose.
Trent mentioned you were worried for your life after the incident with the nail gun. I said, getting right to the point.
Pete took a deep breath before he breathed it out shaking his head. He was clearly aggravated. Trent, you just dont know when to keep your big mouth shut. Pete glared at Trent over the gold rim of his sunglasses.
We were all worried how the Island officials were going to react. Darren added quickly. I'm sure if they were going to do something they would have by now.
Listen you guys, I said, You are making this whole thing out to be much bigger than it is. My foot is practically back to normal already, and everyone understands it was all just an accident. Besides, Darren is right, if they were upset with you at all, you would not be here ready to go fishing right now. Everyone agreed and went back to preparations for the trip. Trent quickly helped me out of the truck before he raced off to help the others inflate and carry the raft.
Shark fishing in an inflatable raft? I asked, You guys have done this before, and thought this through, right?
They started laughing. There havent been any shark sightings in these waters, Eddy. We were just pulln your leg. We might catch something large but we wont be going too far from the shore. Darren explained.
Well, youre the expert fishermen. This stuff is out of my league. I told them as I plugged in the air pump to the cigarette lighter.
When we were ready, we all boarded the rubber inflatable and started out on our way. The strength of the waves picked up right away. Darren crawled to the rear of the raft where he began navigating with the small electric motor. Trent passed out life jackets which everyone quickly put on, except I could not fit into even the largest one, so I stuffed two of them under my shirt. Pete quickly tied a hook onto my fishing line because my nail capped finger tips were awkward to work with when dealing with needles and thread. Pete hooked some bloody raw pork onto our lines while Trent was scooping raw flesh and entrails out of a bucket into the sea. Soon enough, we all began to cast out our lines. Trent washed his blood stained hands off in the sea. 
I hope a shark doesn't swim up and chomp your hands off. Darren remarked. Trent pulled his hand out of the water right away.
I would be more worried about a shark chomping a hole into this raft. Trent said, Besides, I only want to attract them to look at them.
You watch too many movies. Pete said back at them. There are no sharks in these waters, but if there were we would be heading back to shore, like right now. Pete huffed and half smiled shaking his head lazily from side to side. Other than the smell of salty raw pig flesh, the ride was very pleasant, a little turbulent at times, but I was really glad I came along.
Thirty minutes passed, and Trent decided if he wore a flipper on his foot and slapped the surface of the water he could attract the sharks faster. We all seemed to be running out of things to say. We were so relaxed we were almost sleeping. I, for one, definitely needed sleep. The wind was picking up and as it tickled over my face I began to drift off to dream land. It was as though heavy weights were pulling at my eye lids and I was unable to fight it and unwilling. We all sat reclined in the raft and Trent was still slapping the surface of the water with his flipper, before Pete said, The weather is getting rough, maybe we better make a U turn and get back. We could go around to the other side of the Island and see if it is any different. Trent was sitting in front of me holding his rod and slapping the ocean when, a high wave lifted the nose of the raft and Trent flipped off the edge and plunged into the ocean. His fishing rod handle flung against my chest. I fumbled, before I grabbed the rod quickly and found there was something caught on the hook. The hook was not snagged on a rock or reef because the object at the end of the line was being dragged behind us. It tugged at the line with a great violent strength. At first, I thought the object was Trent, before I realized it was a fish, a very big fish. Meanwhile, Pete grabbed some ski rope and threw it out to Trent. The wind swooped in fast and carried the rope a short distance away from Trent, however he stretched to take hold of it and with some effort he did.
While Pete was trying to pull Trent to the raft and I was fighting to reel in the fish, Darren noticed the waves were moving in more quickly building up and gaining strength. Pete took over the motor from Darren because Darren was trying to give me a hand reeling in the fish. I saw Trent still making his way to the raft. I told Darren to help Trent. He nodded and went for the ski rope.
Darren and I were standing when the raft moved into a great dip between the waves. Darren fell to the floor of the raft and I flipped over the back end, where I hung half off the raft. I saw the head of the fish and its jaws were unmistakably those of a shark. I was scared for Trent and this made me seize a tighter hold of the rod. I heard Darren behind me yell, Bring it in closer!!!
Trent let go of the rope when we moved close to the shore line. I kept reeling in the line, while I kept my eyes on Trent. When I saw Trent safely climb onto the sandy shore, I glanced around at the others. To my surprise, Darren was aiming a rifle in the general direction of our catch. I was frozen holding the rod, my eyes quivered. Darren fired a shot at the fish. He sat down to re-load his rifle, and I quickly tried to situate myself more safely in the raft. I reeled in some more fishing line. In the back of my mind I wanted to keep from getting my foot, or any other limb, shot off. Darren was re-loaded when he stood up again and aimed. Pete yelled to him, Get down!
Darren did not respond in time. A huge wave curled in at us and the raft was forced against a giant rock. Darren was thrown to his left clumsily. The rifle went off and the raft was punctured by the shot. Escaping air was whistling away, the raft deflated quickly. The ocean seemed to calm a little when Pete said, We'll have to swim for shore!
What about the shark? I panicked.
Forget it, lets go!!! Pete answered.
It's only attracted to the scent of blood! Darren added, before both Pete and Darren jumped raft and swam for their lives.
I didn't let go of the fishing rod as the raft sagged and sunk under my feet into the ocean. Under-water, my jean jacket decided to unsnap, and my life jackets floated out from under my shirt. I could feel my legs being tugged by the undertow. Somehow, I came up for a breath of air, and before I went back under, I noticed a high narrow reef. Blindly, I swam in that direction. I grabbed hold of some of the brittle driftwood. My feet scraped against the surface of a coral reef.
I was still holding Trents fishing rod and I figured the shark escaped, until I felt that persistent tug once again. The shark must have been bigger than I thought because it was able to pull me from the powerful grip I had on the barnacle covered reef. I was impressed by the strength and integrity of the fishing rod and line. I was swept further out to sea, much further. I lifted my head out of the water for a gasp of air and noticed a black metal pipe sticking straight up out of the waters surface. It appeared just before I slammed into it. I held onto the pipe for leverage and pulled the fishing rod closer to me. The pipe continued to rise out of the water.
I heard someone on shore ask, What did he catch? A whale?
A closer look at the pipe revealed it was indeed a periscope of a submarine. The sub broke out of the oceans surface and my co-workers were in awe. The periscope retracted into the sub before the top hatch opened. The captain came out carrying a harpoon gun. He looked at me with a comical expression on his face. My orders are to keep a close eye on you and to keep you from leaving the Island. also, I am to step in if your life is endangered. I did not know you would be such a reckless chap. The captain had an English accent. He aimed his harpoon at the shark and killed it with his first shot. He turned back to look at me. You could have just let go of the rod.
Now, wheres the sport in that? I replied.
The captain hiccupped a strange sort of chuckle. He climbed back down into the hatch. Shortly, two marines came out carrying an inflatable yellow raft. They pulled the cord to inflate it instantly before they threw the raft in the water. I climbed onto the raft and reeled in some of the line to the dead shark. I paddled to shore with a gleaming broad smile on my face as the submarine submerged and disappeared under the water's surface behind me.
After Pete, Darren, Trent and I were reunited on shore, we laughed and cheered as we patted each other on the back for evading death. We recollected what was left of the raft. A huge bright beach fire was made and we cooked the shark over it. We were having a real good time and it made an interesting story to tell, but no one ever believed it because we didn't have any pictures of proof. However, I did keep the bottom jaw bone of the shark.

Something did not feel right to me when I went to work the next day. I punched in and went to work without speaking to anyone. I was picking up odd emotions from the other workers. Little time passed before Burl came out of the office and approached me.
Burl was Harley's son, and Harley was the owner of Lugger Lumber. Not only was Burl a young healthy looking man, but he was very handsome as well. I didn't have to be a mind reader to see Burl had a spoiled upbringing. He was used to getting what he wanted and it showed not only in the way he walked, but in the way he talked and dressed. Burl's job was to build orders and make deliveries running the one ton truck, but he came to work wearing high end expensive clothes. He kind of stuck out like a sore thumb, in his mirrored sunglasses and preppy hair-do.
Eddy. Burl began, Lets take a little walk, Okay? We walked throughout the warehouse. Hey. Burl remarked, There doesn't seem to be any pigeons today. I smiled. We walked down the isles of wood in the yard. I glanced back at the shed and noticed Jack and Harley were talking together and looking my way. I felt uncomfortable.
You are very strong. Burl began, And you're sure getting a good name around the yard as the one to call when help is needed. You are kind of like the forklift-man, or Mr. Lifter. I smiled at the humor. Do you feel like the work you offer here is worth your while?
Yes, I answered.
Well, I know of some lumber hauling work that will be coming to this Island tomorrow. They are contracted to clear up some hectares of this Island for new development and they will also be doing some simpler duties to maintain the Islands agriculture. I bet your strength would be more helpful if it were to assist them. Now, I've been talking to my father, you know, Harley? He really supports the idea. All day today my dad has been discussing this with Jack. Jack would rather have you stay with us, but because my dad is his boss, Jack will agree. Of course, he always does. I think, very soon it will be up to you if you go on or not.
I stood there for a moment, just wondering what was going on. Was this a way to fire me? Drive me away? Or was it an opportunity for something better?
Burl!!! Announced Harley, waving for Burl to go to him.
Hey. Burl said, Could you just wait here, he might want to talk to me alone.
I nodded to him and he ran to his father. Harley put his hand on Jack and Burls shoulders. He said something to them, nodded his head assuredly, and walked out to me. 
Harley was a burly old man with a thick beard with grey patches. His wavy hair was likely very dark in his youth, but now it was completely grey. He dressed in a clean checkered red and grey shirt with suspenders and a black tie. With his belly hanging over his tight pants, a large golden belt buckle along with many gold rings were the greatest hint that he was a man of some importance.
Hi, Eddy. He said, holding out his hand. I took his hand and shook it firmly. We were both smiling as we shook. Harley bent down onto his knees, and his face tightened up as if my grip was inflicting serious pain on him. I quickly released my hand and pulled it away. Harley looked up at me and started smiling through his beard. He chuckled and said, How are you doing? I looked at him with no expression. I looked around. Other people who were watching from a distance seemed concerned. Hey, He said, That was just a joke!
Whoa, I breathed with relief. You shouldn't do that to me, I thought I was really hurting you. 
Harleys smile slowly vanished and with a deep exhale his features became stone cold and serious. I don't feel it's wise for you to work here anymore. There it was, I knew I was going to be fired. How much are you making anyway? Harley persisted. 
Five dollars an hour.
Is that fair to you?
Considering I am only seven years old, or sixteen in human standards, I think its very fair.
But your capabilities outweigh any other sixteen year olds. Unless, of course, there are others like you?
No, sir. To the best of my knowledge I am the only one. Eddy answered quickly.
All right, Harley shook his head and composed himself professionally. Lets think for a moment. Instead of being paid five dollars an hour, how about twenty-five dollars an hour. You can have it if you just work under my supervision up at a logging camp. You see, I own this yard, youre working for me and you can continue working for me if you agree to the new conditions. He expected to find an ambitious response on my face of some sort. 
I want to work with loggers, Harley, but I'm sixteen and you're talking about a camp. My mother would never go for it. I explained.
Okay, Harley replied, thirty dollars an hour full time. Discuss it with your mother and give me your decision tomorrow morning.
I worked the rest of the day in concentration. I considered all of my options and the results of different choices.

At the end of the day, I ran swiftly through the woods to my home. I forced the front door open and flew into the cabin, where I broke the news to Gastonish. 
Mom! I called and she came out from the kitchen.
Yes? She answered. Her auburn hair was pinned up at the back. 
We have to talk. We sat down and discussed everything to do with how I could soon be making thirty dollars an hour as a lumber jack. At first she hated the idea of me being forced into such a problem and I wouldn't be able to help with routine check-ups on the Zandith Crockmior life-boat. But as we debated, we were able to find some very good uses for the money. Also, I was a volk and hard work was challenging and more like fun. I would love the exercise. I may never get the opportunity to experience a hard labor working environment amongst humans ever again if my mother and I manage to get back to where we belonged. You just never know, we may not be able to return to our world. If thats the case, we will need money to survive here.
I am more concerned with your safety. Eddy, we are so close now, why must you complicate things? My mother did not like the idea at all, but she tried to put herself in my place and understand. Ultimately, she let me make the final call.

At the break of day, I went straight to the lumber yard with my decision. Harley was there as though he was expecting me. Everyone said good morning to each other as they came through the door and in no time Harley was ready to talk business. Do you go to school Eddy? Harley asked.
Yes, but I will be going in today to let them know yesterday was my last day. I said.
Good idea. He smoothed his hand over his beard as his eyes tightened in thought. Ask the school if they will give you a week or two before you give them your final decision. Tell them, you don't intend to return, but it is wise to keep your options open if this new job doesn't work out for you. 
Thats a great idea, Harley. Thanks. Many times I felt like I had very few choices in my life. With my situation on this secluded Island, it really felt great to know the decision makers truly cared.
Listen Eddy, if you can work out everything with your school and be here at the yard packed with what you need by five o'clock this evening, I can have one of my truckers take you up to the camp tonight with a delivery.
Five o'clock. I repeated silently to myself. Sure, that shouldn't be a problem. Thanks again Harley. When I left I felt like I was going to burst with excitement. I really had things working out well for myself.
Mom went with me to the school, where I told them I was 'moving on' and they told me I was 'dropping out.' I hated the word, 'dropping out.' It's just as bad as the word, 'quit.' The school was run by only two people and one of them was the janitor. They decided giving me two weeks to decide if the job was right for me was a good idea.
After we returned home from the school, Gastonish and I packed my bags and had a small celebrational dinner, but it turned into a sad going away party between the two of us.
Later, at Luggers Lumber yard, everyone was congratulating me and saying good-bye. When I climbed into the Logging truck and looked out of the window, I felt as though I was being sent off to war. I waved to my friends, before I waved to Gastonish. It was all very sad, but I was with Lumber jacks, men built of iron and people like them don't cry.
The trucker started the engine, and the cab shook in the power of the diesel roar. We drove up a very narrow and bumpy dirt road; neither of us knew what to say to the other. The C.B. Radio crackled and I could hear voices but I couldn't understand the words.
The trucker picked up the receiver and said, Truck two, mile sixteen up fifth.
The C.B. Crackled with a voice responding with what sounded like a warning. Still I couldn't understand a word.
The road widened around a bend when the trucker pulled over and stopped. A fully loaded logging truck came around the corner and I thought it was going to hit us. I gripped the seat and the glove compartment and failed to contain myself. Aaaahh!!
The trucker beside me jumped in his seat and looked at me in surprise when I yelled, he had quite a large belly and he wore dirty old clothes. He relaxed his fuzzy bearded face and gave me a glare with cold dark eyes.
What is your name? He asked as he began to breathe easy again.
Eddy Evon. I replied, also settling down.
Well, Eddy, dont yell while I'm staged again. I nodded in reverence before silence followed like an awkward chill. The trucker asked me a question. Is this part of a school project? A journal or something? He started to drive again.
No. I am the new guy. my response was met with silence. Looking ahead as the truck climbed through the gears, I decided to contribute to more conversation with a question. How do you know if there is another truck coming or not?
We contact each other over the radio, haven't you been listening? He sighed.
So what is your name? I asked politely.
Chuck. he told me bluntly. This would be an easy name for someone to remember as it rhymed with truck.
The remainder of the ride was quiet. Soon, we parked inside the logging block. I hopped out of the massive truck. I took a good long look at the activity around me while Chuck released the compression air brakes.
I saw many rugged woodland men busy at work. Everyone had a job they were doing, cutting and hauling logs. Some workers drove very heavy machinery which could strip, cut and haul massive amounts of tree trunks.
I saw Harley was already there at the site. Before long, Harley noticed me and was waving me in from the foremans office. When I entered the room, people looked with amazement and stepped back. Harley on the other hand greeted me with a smile. He asked me to leave my bag in the office while he showed me around the camp and introduced me to some workers.
Outside the office, as we were walking, Harley began telling me a little bit about the logging history, You know Eddy, A long time ago loggers, or lumber jacks would go into the woods on horse. One guy took the food, another took the blankets, and others took medical supplies, one wash tub and hand tools. Everything was done by hand, look around you now, we are surrounded by machines that do everything for you, and people still complain. I hate it when people complain. Especially my men. He examined me up and down. Long ago, timber men had to spend the first day marking the measurements for a block and build cabins to sleep in by sundown. There were cabins all over and each one was inspected. He stopped talking and we turned toward the office before he continued. Now we have a bulldozer and blasters who can make a road in no time letting timber cruisers go in before we do. They use their compasses, topographer and other devices to provide accurate land surveys. They also measure the lengths and widths of trees. When we come in and bring our heavy equipment, everything is already more or less done for us. So why do we have so many accidents still? He paused for a moment. It's dangerous!!! He answered in a hard voice. Don't ever think you are safe, always be on your toes, or you might lose them. Sure you don't have to build a tent to sleep in each night, instead we have portables driven up and attached together. It's like a home away from home. When you are talking with your buddy, don't think you are talking to the same man who you worked with that day. I don't care who you are on the inside and you'll find hardly anyone else does either. All people really want to see around here is hard work. Work hard and you'll get lots of friends and respect. 
We walked up beside a vehicle which grabbed some trees and cut them with an extending circular saw. The trees were cut in two seconds. 
Eddy, say hi to Willie. We waved at the driver and he nodded to us and went back to work. Well, he is busy, by the way, thats a feller buncher, it grabs the trees and cuts them at the base. 
We didn't walk far until we came to a different machine. This, Eddy, is a tree limber. Its arm encloses the trees trunk at the peak. It slides down the trunk and shears all of the branches off of it. Trees which are in places too hard for the feller buncher or the tree limber to reach, get special handling by a feller or a bucker and a faller. The faller is a man who cuts the tree down, like Robertson over here who seems to be taking care of the buckers job also. Robertson was about a half a mile from where we were standing. Harley took two quick steps away from me toward Robertson. Cupping his hands around his mouth to amplify his voice, Harley shouted. Robertson, wheres your bucker?
Robertson answered sincerely. He quit, sir. Robertson's skin was as dark as skin could get. Compared to the other workers, Robertson was the most developed and I wondered if he had any background as a bodybuilder. His plaid shirt was unbuttoned at the chest and his sleeves were rolled up. His skin glistened with the sweet of hard work.
Harley rubbed his chest, as he turned to face me, he rubbed his neck to his forehead with his hand. He was in deep thought looking at me. Can you handle being his bucker? It would only be until we can find a replacement, then I will bump you up.
Yes sir, Ill take care of that, no problem. I answered my boss with excitement and determination.
Harley swung around on his heels and yelled, Robertson, I want you to take five and meet your new bucker. Turning to me Harley spoke in a softer voice, Consider your orientation over. Welcome to your first day on the job, Eddy.
I shook Harley's hand and made certain my handshake was firm but not strong enough to inflict pain.
As we walked toward Robertson, Harley began to tell me more. After trees are stripped of their branches and cut down, a skidder will come by and grab five or six of the trees and drag them to the landing. He pointed to a skidder in the distance to show me, It's a four wheel drive with big balloon tires and articulate steering. If you notice, we like to try to drag the wood downhill, it's easier on fuel and the vehicles themselves. Just remember, we want to stay away from dragging up hill, we hate adverse hauling. Once the logs are taken to the landing area, the bucker, you, cuts the logs to lengths. The loader operator will come driving a front end loader and load the logs onto the trailer of the truck. The logs are tagged and sent off to the saw mill. Harley and I stepped up close behind Robertson. Robertson was bent down facing away from us fiddling with the mechanics of his chain saw.
Robertson, Harley announced, startling Robertson, meet, Eddy.
Robertson turned and looked up at me with black eyes which stood out from his dark brown skin. He had a wide nose and large lips, and his hair was short, curly and grey all over. He was sweaty and dirty and his clothes were so stained, they probably wouldn't look much better even after a wash. He stood up and looked me in the eyes, he must have been six and a half feet tall, but I was seven and a half and still growing. Up close, Robertson's body was still quite muscle toned and impressive, for a twenty first century human.
He was not saying a word, just giving me an eye. Nice to meet you Robertson. I said and shook his hand.
Robertson began to laugh impressively loud and clear with his deep Negro voice. I don't know what made him start laughing but I took it as a good sign.
Eddy, Harley began, Tomorrow you'll get up at the crack of dawn as a feller and Robertson will show you what to do. He said it in a way which didn't seem to give Robertson much of a choice.
Excuse me, sir. Robertson added. Since the last bucker left, my cabin has had an extra bunk.
Thank you, Robertson, responded Harley in a belittling management sort of way, I'll consider that.
Harley and I walked back to the office and on our way I met some workers named John, Marvin, Jake, Tom, Steve, and Daryl. When Harley and I finally reached the office, Harley began telling me more about the portables.
All of the portables are attached. Harley began, They were hauled up here like trailer homes and connected together, forming this maze of a camp. The foremans office is a recreation room. Also attached to this portable camp is the power house generator, and the cook house, which includes an eating area. The rest are all sleep areas, everyone will refer to them as cabins. We stepped inside the office where I retrieved my bag and Harley gave me a key to my cabin. As I was leaving, Harley called me.
Eh, some people might call you a feller, its just a temporary name for bucker, just don't get it mixed up with a faller like Robertson, who cuts trees down. See ya in the morning, Eddy.
Sure, Harley. See ya. I replied with a wave and a smile. 
I walked out of the office into the recreation room, it was smoky and old as if it had been used a lot. I saw many empty tables and chairs, a dart board, ping-pong table, shuffle board, a small T.V. and one radio phone. I moved directly to the phone and tried to call home, but Gastonish wouldn't answer it for some reason. 
I went to my cabin and headed straight for the bed, but before I slipped into the covers, I opened the window a crack and punctured a small hole into the screen. I told Evon, to locate Gastonish and warn me if she was in any danger. My sertz zipped out of my ear and darted through the hole of the screen. When Evon left, I began counting and it only took it eighteen seconds to find Gastonish and make a quick survey. I closed the window and slid into the only unoccupied bed of six in the room which seemed unused. The room had three bunk beds and I was not going to sleep on a top bunk, for fear the top bunk might collapse.
EDDY. Evon began in a soft, quiet synthetic voice, GASTONISH IS WORKING ON THE ZANDITH CROCKMIOR L/X. I GAVE XONOX YOUR LOCATION. XONOX WILL CHECK ON YOU FOR NOW ON, AT GASTONISHS DISCRETION. Evon was still hidden from sight. I knew he was close because its little red lights still lit up in the shadows. 
Evon! I said, you must turn off your lights. Evon entered my ear. The red hue of its lights went out. One of the fellow jacks turned over and asked, Whats going on?
Nothing. I told him, Just having problems with my radio head set. Because I only require one day of the week for sleep, I was prepared to keep myself occupied while the others slept. I ducked my head under the covers and read manuals concerning the standard operating procedures and how to operate heavy equipment, then I would read the owner's manuals for each piece of equipment. I also had textbooks about astronomy and I would read these by the red lights of Evons eyes. Evon attempted to help me sleep by singing softly in my ear.
LULA BYE - - AND GOOD NIGHT. unfortunately, this never helped me much.
Its singing had no effect, so Evon would teach me about such things as how to exercise my telepathic emotions. When I looked into the minds of my fellow bunk roommates, I found all sorts of strange things. I learned the hard way not to look into people's minds when they were sleeping. 
Evon also taught me how to better understand the system of Lornels direction and much more. I found it hard to keep my muscles dormant until day break, however, the little sertz was very strict and worked me brutally to learn. It was not easy to adjust to the little teacher who had a big attitude. At first it was cute, but that wore thin quickly however Evon's discipline did help the time pass quickly.
Chapter 8

Mornings always came swiftly and I remember a specific morning where I saw Robertson getting dressed. I was up all night learning about the connections and intricacies of the micro-verse and how it relates to the universe. I certainly was taught well but by the morning, my heart just wasnt in it. I had tried to explain this to Harley to find some way to keep working through the night. Harley was going to look into it but it would not be easy to change human standardized practices, like labour laws. 
The springs creaked as the mattress above me began to move. Three other beds were shuffling as three other workers awoke and rose out of their beds also. I wasn't introduced to these other new guys earlier. I arose from my bed also and told them who I was. A couple of the guys were shocked when they fixed their drowsy eyes on me.
Oh, ya, now Im awake. One of them commented. With all six of us standing in the room, we were quickly aware there was not very much space for us all to get dressed and ready for the day. The silence of conversation mixed with the grumblings of trying to get ready without touching one another made a bad situation worse. They were still half asleep and nobody seemed to be much of a morning person. I followed the others out, half dressed. After I was completely dressed, Robertson escorted the rest of us to the cook house. As usual, everyone had a tin tray and walked in single file along the cafeteria counter, grabbing fruit and drinks.
The cook was very large. His belly and triple chins made his face seem very small and sunken. He plopped a heap of lumpy thick mushy cereal onto my tray. I frowned at the goop and took notice of his name tag, Chuckles Billadoe.
What is this? I asked as I screwed up my face looking at the goop.
Its good. The cook said. Real good. The kinda porridge that sticks to yer bones. he smiled with yellow, coffee stained teeth.
I could eat practically anything, and it was a good thing too because I did not want to eat that slop. I tried a little with my finger. It was surprisingly good, in fact it was real good porridge. This was good because at the sight of it I was about ready to just eat my wooden chair. Chuckles Billadoe and I exchanged smiles before I continued on.

At the end of the day, Robertson was chopping his last tree down. I was standing behind him admiring his skill. I noticed a branch had broken away from the tree from about twenty feet above, and it was heading for Robertsons head. I ran up behind him to catch the branch. Robertson saw me coming at him and he panicked. He held his axe in a defensive stance. I grabbed his axe and looked up. Robertson looked up as well, and he watched as I saved him from a falling branch. I caught the branch quickly and heaved it away. 
After Robertson's eyes relaxed from being bugged out, he told me, You saved my life. A branch can pick up enough speed to paralyze a man from the neck down for life. he patted my shoulder with a bright smile of white teeth which seemed to glow from his dark complexion.

At supper time, Chuckles Billadoe prepared some grub for us to eat. Chuckles? I called when I passed near him. Chuckles perked his head up from the soup which he was stirring. I know I am the new guy and all, but is it possible for you to make something other than soup and porridge?
Chuckles eyes widened in amazement. I wasn't sure if I said something of an insult but I was sure getting a reaction out of him. You. What is your name?
Eddy. I told him without backing down.
Think youre a big man, eh? Think just cause you have big muscles you can just go around saying anything you wish, huh? Chuckles tried to work me up.
Not at all. I retaliated with my hands up, signaling him to ease down.
Do you think you are bigger than me?
What kind of question had Chuckles asked me? Was he trying to trap me? He was waiting for an answer, but if I backed down and said he was bigger than me, he would say I insulted him for being over weight. If I stood up and said I was bigger, I would be playing right into his hands. I am up for any challenge you are willing to dish out. Come on, let's prove who is bigger.
Oh, ho, ho, ho, Give me your tray, Eddy. he was making quite the spectacle of us. I handed my tray to Chuckles and he snatched it from me. My tray was quite loaded with food and Im sure I was the hungriest in the room. I blurted out a laugh in disbelief. 'He took my food!' I couldnt laugh any further and frowned down at my empty hands. A few of the men around me chuckled. 
Now take a seat, I have something special planned for you. Chuckles was smiling at me from over the counter. I gave him a stare that would turn most men to stone, but Chuckles was obviously not like most men. Reluctantly, I retired to a place at a table without anything to eat. The room was filled with slurps, sucking chews, and burps. Chuckles was busier than ever in the kitchen. Every so often I could hear Chuckles bursting in fits of laughter. 
'What was he planning?' 
Hee-hee-hee! Another fit of evil laughter. He was up to something and the suspense made me very curious. My curiosity was contagious as others looked on in wonderment as well. I wanted to get up and go into the back to see what Chuckles was doing, but it wasn't worth it. I had no fear of the meddlings of a human. Even if he went as far as trying to poison me, I wouldn't go down without a fight. All I knew was I was getting hungrier by the second.
Chuckles came out from behind the counter with two large pizza trays. One in each hand. On the trays were the largest ham burgers I had ever seen. The buns and patties had a diameter slightly bigger than the large pizza trays. Each burger oozed with cheese and secret sauce plus an entire head of shredded lettuce was sandwiched between two of the widest thickest patties I had ever seen in my life. 
Chuckles lifted the two trays of burger up over his head and yelled like a barbarian. UNGA-BUNGA!!! Beef Steak Bronco Burgers! The noise of the other lumber jacks halted at once. He stepped toward me and placed the two trays on my table. They smelled delicious. My eyes bulged with delight and my mouth drooled. I reached out for the burgers of a perfect dream come true.
Don't touch! He commanded, before he stepped back to the counter and returned with a pot of gravy.
He lifted my impossibly huge sesame seed bun. A waft of the most heavenly aroma hit me in the form of steam. I looked in under the bun and saw bacon, eggs, mushrooms and fried onions tantalizing my senses. He poured the gravy over it and closed the bun with a slap.
The other lumber jacks gathered around, and I noticed I was not the only one drooling.
The rules are simple. Chuckles said. Eat it! All of it! The first one done, wins. The first one done is truly the biggest.
The biggest what? A voice called out from the crowd. Laughter encircled me.
No utensils, Chuckles? I asked, looking around my burger not to find a knife or fork anywhere.
He huffed at my ridiculous question.
Lets go! He said.
We both dived into our Bronco burgers at the same time. Chuckles was, no doubt, eating to win. He chomped off huge mouthfuls and swallowed again and again. He didn't even bother to chew.
I gripped my burger at the front and worked my jaws around it. It was two times thicker than my mouth could open. Sauce, grease, and delectable gravy dribbled out the sides of our burgers and ran off the table and onto the floor. I had to squeeze it down with a firm grip in order to fit it into my mouth.
Chuckles had obviously done this before. He was a pro. So content and focused. He stopped with Bronco burger hanging out of his mouth and he just stared at me. I was still trying desperately to catch up to him, when I noticed his eyes were bulging out at me.
I did a double take before I stopped to see if something was wrong. A little bit of air squeaked out of Chuckles full open mouth.
Chuckles is choking! Someone called out.
Chuckles hacked twice and through his wheeze of air he said, Beer!
A jack quickly put a full and frothy beer pitcher on the table. Chuckles took it and chugged it back. When he put the mug back on the table, he didn't even stop for a breath before he began chomping on his burger again. The on-looking jacks cheered and I jumped back into the race. 
I reached for the pitcher of beer, but Chuckles slapped my hand, That's mine! He spoke with his mouth right full as something fell from the corner.
Before I knew it someone placed an equal pitcher of beer before me. We slopped and gulped. Our faces and hands were covered in the sloppy Bronco burger. I felt like a child playing with my food. Three quarters of the way through the burgers, we started slowing down. I had never before experienced eating to be such a chore and the final part of the burger seemed to last forever.
The competition seemed to slide into slow motion. Every heart beat, like a drum pushing me to the next bite. 'No Vacancy'. My stomach, a full load. How was Chuckles handling this challenge?
He was definitely in the lead, but how? I was a volk and for as long as I could remember I have always been the hungriest. If my meals were not enough, I would go outside our home and eat some vegetation of leaves or branches or bark. How unexpected, to have this human confront me with a larger appetite. How insulting. No, it wouldn't happen. I couldn't live with myself if a human out ate me. It was humiliating. I didn't have a particular plan, so I did what anyone would have done out of desperation, and bubbled out a noise from deep within. The guttural sound gripped the attention of everyone in the room. Chuckles stopped eating and looked up at me from across the table. I put my hands down on the greasy table-top. My eyes locked with his. I stood and bent over the table, getting in his face with my mouth a gape. With burger grub on the verge of falling out, I waved my upper body toward him and burped long and hard. My breath wafting his hair. I sat down and continued to eat my burger as fast as I could. My plan had immediately taken some form of effect because, Chuckles was no longer eating. His Bronco burger diminished to the size of two or three bites, yet it still remained on his plate.
I didn't care. All I wanted to do was win and put all of this behind me. At the corner of my sight, I saw Chuckles cup his mouth and stand.
From the crowd, a voice shouted. Hes gonna barf his Bronco burger!
I decided Chuckles would not distract me with my own tactics. I would not stop to look up. I would not stop for anything unless he really did throw-up on me. I was catching-up to the same size burger portion as Chuckles had. Chuckles made some digestive noises. The people around us backed away a fair distance. I would not be moved. I just ate.
No! Chuckles said, I won't give you the satisfaction. He sat back down and frantically scarfed down half of what he had left. Everyone started cheering. Chuckles glanced at me, before he took a double take followed by a good long look. I was smiling at him with my greasy smile. I held up my plate for him to observe. I wiped it clean with the remainder of my bun.
Chuckles stare seemed to burn into me. I wondered if he was gonna be a sore loser. He stood up and walked, I mean waddled, behind the kitchen counter. He turned on the radio, and cranked up the volume. Music broke out in the mess hall, but no one got into it. Everyone was still very quiet. Chuckles became very upset, he pulled off his apron and threw it on the floor.
Boom, Boom, Chucka-Chucka-Chucka-Chucka-Boom, Boom!!! The music was very loud.
Chuckles came dancing around from behind the counter, singing and shouting. His belly was bouncing and moving about with every step. It was the Hungry-Man song. Chuckles began singing along with the music and the room burst out into laughter.

Stomach grumbles,
Give me food.
Must eat now,
Im in a bad mood.
Im a hungry, hungry, hungry-man!
You can not satisfy a hungry-man.
Oh, ya!
Ill eat till I drop,
I certainly wont stop.
Cause Im a hungry-man,
A hungry-man! Belly flop!
