Chew it up! - Spit it out!
Im a hungry-man - Look out!
I eat more than any mutt.
I have a garbage, garbage gut!
Are you a hungry, hungry, hungry-man?
I know I am a hungry, hungry, hungry-man!

--(BURP!!!)--

He put on quite the show. Chuckles was a good sport about it after all.

After supper, everyone gathered in the recreation room. There, people played cards, threw darts, played ping-pong, or watched the movie channel on a small black and white T.V.
I was gathering a large crowd again, where I challenged whoever had the guts, to an arm wrestle. Everyone was very strong but not one was strong enough. Even un-defeated Robertson challenged me. We began and I felt perhaps my arm was being overworked, but actually, Robertson was just very strong. I liked Robertson, so I made it seem as though he was beating me to add a little suspense. Many people watching made remarks like, Oooow!!! Thats gotta hurt. I heaved his arm down; Victory.
Robertson took a liking to me and I couldn't be sure if it was because of my strength. Maybe the grey tone of my skin, which set me apart from the others, reflected on his own relative emotions.
Chuckles and I stayed up late at night teasing each other about not only our stomach cramps but the strange noises our bodies were making. After a little competition to see who could fart the loudest, Chuckles got messy and ran off to find an out-house. Everyone had to vacate the mess hall because not even I was prepared for the rancid stench of my volk gas. 

After everyone returned to their cabins, I walked over to the shed. I brought my romstrunn and lintin with me in a pack. I gathered up all of the tools I accidentally broke earlier in the day when working with Robertson. I made a pile with them. I wandered about inside the shed gathering as many stainless steel metal scraps as possible. I found the hull of an old auger  which was dented and twisted but did not show any signs of rust. It was part of the bone yard and had been tagged to be shipped out as scrap.
Evon. I called, and my sertz appeared from out of my ear and flew before me. Through my romstrunn, design for me an axe which is made specifically for me, which I can use without breaking it.
Evon flew into the romstrunn which was attached to my right forearm. The romstrunn opened like a book and an image formed on the inside surface. The small forming shape became an ax.
Widen the blade. I said, and the blade widened. Evon disconnected itself from the Romstrunn, and hovered at eye level to me.
I HAVE SCANNED YOUR WEIGHT, STRENGTH, AND ENDURANCE, MASTER. THIS axe, AS SHOWN, IS DESIGNED SPECIFICALLY FOR YOU. Evon reported.
The available stainless steal is piled here for you and marked. I told the little sertz.
STAND BACK, LORD.
I stepped back four feet. Evon attached itself to the lintin wrist band on my left hand wrist. I pointed my fist at the scrap metal hull. Two blue beams were emitted from Evons eyes the size of thread. The thin beams struck and covered over the metal. With waves of energy the metal began to rise off the ground until it was suspended in the air. Next, the metal began turning red hot as it melted, molding together into a solid sphere of red hot dross. The dirty unwanted dark globs of oil, dirt and grease dripped to the ground and made a small hot steaming puddle. Still floating in air, the bigger mass of red hot glowing liquidated metal began to form and change shape. Quickly, the axe was formed before it cooled from its red hot stage to a natural silvery solid stage. Slowly the axe descended, landing softly until it touched ground. I was surprised at how perfect it turned out. Like a new toy, I couldn't wait to try it out. The axe was so shiny, even in the low light, the axe gleamed and shimmered. When it was cool enough to hold, I took the axe away to conceal it for the time being.

With the rise of the next day, Robertson and I were in the woods once again. I wore a yellow baseball cap, an old flannel shirt, jeans, and heavy widened steel toed boots. They were the same boots from the lumber yard with the same nail sized puncture hole in the top of my right foot. Here, put this on. Robertson said, holding ankle straps with boot spikes. This will be a little different for you. I'll bet you haven't tried this before. 
I shook my head in agreement. I strapped the spikes to my boots. Robertson helped me chain the heavy power saw to my shoulders. I climbed up the tree at no extraordinary speed. Step by step, I did not trust any branches and persisted on a vise-like grip at the stock of the tree.
Near the peak, I reached behind me and took hold of the power saw. I swung it around to my front and the momentum shifted my weight back, bending the tree also. It creaked and I heard a crack from the tree's trunk down below. I jerked my weight forward and the tree trunk snapped and crackled again. I could feel the momentum swing. I knew I was going to go down with the tree.
Before the tree had broken free from the ground, I began remembering about last night. From that height I could see where I buried my new axe, so it could be discovered at a later date.
The tree only seemed to bend so far but it held. I breathed out an exhausting gust of relief. 
Snap!!! The whole tree jerked downwards, and I was on my way, free falling. Timber!!! Yelled Robertson.
AAAHHH!!! I screamed, the tree cracked and broke into splinters under the tight pressure of my left hand. With my other hand, I was trying to get the power saw as far away from me as possible. As the tree was falling, with me near the top of it, I ripped through branches of neighboring trees in my path.
The impact of my fall shook the Earth. I just laid there in the mess of pine needles and branches, not moving a muscle. How severe were my injuries? I could hear Robertson running to my aid. I wiggled my fingers, then my toes, and I knew I wouldn't be paralyzed. As I bent my knees and elbows, I could feel a strong burning sting all over my arms and legs.
Before Robertson reached my position, I hammered my hand onto a rock beside me and began climbing out from under the tree.
Robertson was still running as I stood up with my ripped plaid shirt and pants shredded and dangling off me. The junked power saw was also still connected. The impact of the machine smashing against the massive rock made the power saw seem like a bundle of broken parts.
Robertson leaped over a log and his spiked boots made a sound like metal on metal. He tripped and fell to the ground. Robertson crawled back up to see what hed stepped on and found a large metal rod, half buried in the dirt. He was exhausted.
Eddy! Robertson cried. Speak to me! Are you okay?
I'll be fine. How about you?
Come here, we have to move this thing so it doesn't damage the skidder, when it comes.
I knew exactly what he found. I approached him.
You are a mess, man. Robertson said when he took a good look at me. You junked another power saw? Harley's gonna be choked. I guess you should take the rest of the day off.
I gave him a nudge to the side as I paused, and picked up the ax. No, I said. I don't think I'll be taking the day off yet. Robertson and I marveled at the beauty and magnificence of the giant gleaming ax.
Whoo, man, I wonder what kind of guy would forget an axe like that? He looked at me for a moment. The thing must belong to someone like you, man!
I am the only one of my kind. I reminded Robertson.
Well, with an axe like that, you won't have to break any more of our tools.
Lets see how this beast cuts trees. I said changing the subject. I swung the axe from left to right. The blade whistled through the air. Stepping close to a marked tree I swooping the blade slightly up to give a diagonal cut to the base of the trunk.
Timber!!! Yelled Robertson.
I was able to chop the tree away from its base with a single swipe. I stepped toward the next tree and cut it down in the same way as the first.
Timber!!! Robertson announced again.
I glanced at Robertson with an annoyed eye. I proceeded to chop down about ten trees within the area. All trees fell with only a single stroke each. Cutting the ten trees took about six seconds.
Timb-tim - t-t- AHG!!! Robertson panicked. He wanted to keep up with me but he was forced to stay behind or else dodge the falling trees. I was cutting the trees down so fast it soon became a dangerous area even for me.
When I finished chopping down the wild, I retrieved my yellow baseball cap. I took off my ripped plaid shirt leaving myself in my dirty undershirt. My pants were also in bad shape so I belted them up with the chain which was previously used to strap the power-saw to my shoulders. The first log I began carrying on my shoulder was the biggest. I would carry the logs to a clearing, so to make work easier for the skidder, who hauled the trees to a landing. As I carried the first log through the thick bush I noticed a small doe fleeing from my sight. It was so tiny in comparison to my shadow.
I could feel the fibers of my body work the immense power and thrust of my strained muscles. It felt great. My left bulky arm glistened with beads of sweat while it firmly wrapped around the rough bark of the log. I concentrated on keeping the log stabilized on my left shoulder. My right hand clinched my hefty axe below my statue stiffened arm. The small trees and rocks within the perimeter of my path shook with each heavy step I took. The log had a four foot diameter and was eighteen feet of fresh juicy wood. Robertson and I must have cut close to five thousand trees by the end of the day.
When the other lumber jacks of the crew heard about how many trees I dropped, they demanded to see me in action. Harley also had a great personal interest in my work. They devised a test amongst themselves to see how many strokes of my axe it took to bring down The Old Wise One.
The Old Wise One was the oldest and largest coniferous birds eye maple tree of those parts and the tallest. The diameter of its base measured twelve feet and it had grown ninety-six feet into the air. It sucked twenty gallons of water per day.
Every single lumber jack was there to join the hike out to The Old Wise One. One hundred men and it was getting late. When we reached the mighty tree we had to light the area with flares. Chuckles Billadoe also arrived. He was the last to arrive, sweating from head to toe and panting like a dog. I gave him a side long glance and cocked an eye brow muscle. He smiled between puffs of air and motioned for me to continue all the while unable to speak. I approached the challenge and spit into my palms, I lifted my axe to swing, before I paused for a moment and faced the crowd, Stand back! I told them. Some men laughed because they did not believe I could chop it down, but others were optimistic and took the step back.
I wound back, before I lashed forth with the drive of a semi-truck and drove my axe deep into the base of The Old Wise One. I heard a reaction from the crowds amazement. My axe was so deep in the tree only half of the handle could be seen. Robertson said, Let it go, Eddy, you have proven your point. But I could not bring myself to leaving it. I grabbed the handle of the axe and worked it loose. I began chopping the tree with all I had. After twenty chops, the final flare winked out, The Old Wise One made a sound before it loudly cracked. Everyone was running for their lives in the blinding darkness of the woods. The Old Wise One broke away from its base and teetered over with both the sound of a great thunder storm and an eerie moan which we would take with us to our graves. I stepped back and looked up. Straining my eyes, I tried to determine the angle to which the tree would fall by the silhouette of the top branches in the moon light. Sure enough the tree slumped toward my left as it moved out from the halo of the large blue full moon. All hearts were pumping as no one knew if they would soon be under the old giant. It crashed to the ground and the vibration of the impact rippled throughout the earth, and into the hearts of all of the lumber jacks. A gust of dust and leaves brushed over my face as a result of the heavy fall. Everyone was shaken up with fear, including me.
I am not sure what bothered me the most, the sheer panic of the devastation or the darkness of the near death situation. We all returned to our cabins silently.
Looking back at how I put an entire mountain side of that Island to death, I felt a very strong sense of low self-esteem. Gazing up at the lone mountain of the Island, I would often imagine the fir trees which still remained were very old and very wise pointy green heads who looked down upon me in judgment. Their faces stern and never satisfied. Thank God for reforestation.
 
With the rising of a new day came stiffness and pain. I was up all night with Robertson, aching. Although the men believed I did most of the work, Robertson had the endless clean-up job of stacking the fallen trees. My usual night time studies had to be put off because of my relentless pain, stiffness and Robertsons moaning.
I peeked out from between the curtains which glowed from the golden rays of first morning light. I heard the familiar sound of birds waking up with cheerful song as they bathed in the morning dew. The sun was crawling around the Island, stretching out long arms of light. I was being welcomed to the new day, but as the rays of sunlight retracted and the mountain was more clearly lit, my eyes beheld a sight which stopped my breath and I no longer felt welcome anywhere. I saw the big picture, I surely did put an entire mountain side to death. With the sight, a huge wave of muscle cramps surged through my body. I turned away from the curtains and rolled back into my bed.
We asked someone to give a message to Harley, explaining we were having muscle pains and could be reached in the medical room.
At the medical room, Robertson and I were applying a muscle relaxing paste to our skin. The door opened and Harley stepped in.
Ouch! Exclaimed Harley. You guys look terrible.
It feels worse. Robertson replied. It is nothing worse than muscle cramps, but we won't be able to do any serious work today, sir.
I am very impressed with you two. He wiped the sweat from his forehead. Almost five thousand trees, forget the light duty, you two can have the day off. Harley placed his hands on his hips. I will pay you guys an extra day, but only this once. By doing this I can prove a point to the other men but I don't want to be accused of favouritism. He paused, You see, today is my sons first day on the job. It would be nice if I could find a good man to show him around while we prepare to move to the next logging block. So, one of you will give my son a grand tour and the other will relax, unless you want to be real dedicated troopers. I could have you do some general duties like clean-up or help the mechanic tinker with a broken piece of machinery.
Eddy? Robertson called to me. You should show the lad around. I have to discuss something here with Harley.
All right! I nodded in agreement. Sounds easy enough.
Hes just outside, Eddy. Harley nodded before he turned to Robertson.
I stepped out from the muggy medical room and into the fresh morning air. I expected to find Burl standing there as he was the only son I knew Harley had, but I found a young boy, about seventeen or eighteen years old. I knew him from the school house. He was a quiet boy named Hal. He was Domin's roommate if I remembered correctly. I smiled to him and figured since there was nobody else around, he must be Harleys son. He carried a small duffel bag over his shoulder. He was short and thin with a blond boyish hair style. When he looked at me as I came out of the door, his jaw dropped open and his eyes almost popped out of his head.
Hello Hal, you wouldn't happen to be Harleys son, would you? I asked cheerfully, biting back the pain.
Yeah, Eddy. Do you remember me from school? he gulped at the shock of my presence up close. I'm Hal.
Of course I remember you. We haven't gotten to know one another very well but I've always wanted to meet you. I shook his hand. I was careful not to squeeze too hard and hurt him in case he wanted to pull the same trick as his father did. Your father asked me to show you around the lumber block.
Oh, this again. Hal said quietly under his breath.
As we walked along the dirt road, Hal said. You know, I have heard a lot about you. You sure are big.
And where did you hear about me? I asked,
My father and my brother, Burl, were talking about you. They were saying how cool it is to watch you work. You can do impossible jobs with ease, supposedly. He smiled. You remind me of Grizz. He shook as he heard himself speak out loud, before he looked at me with a slight quiver in his eyes. No offense. He offered shyly.
None taken. I replied dryly. Who is Grizz?
Grizz also lives here on the Island, you must have met him.
I didn't know it at the time but Hal was referring to Domin. I haven't met Grizz yet but if I remind you of him, then I can't wait to meet him.
Hal laughed, Ya, right, you know who I'm talking about.
You mean, Domin? I asked.
No, Grizz. Hal persisted. 
I didn't want to continue running around the issue any longer though we were talking about the same person all along. I gently took Hal's duffle bag and placed it next to the steps of the office. Hal gestured he wanted to keep a smaller shoulder pack slung over his left shoulder. We began walking as I started a fresh topic of small talk, I haven't really worked at the lumber yard long enough to become close friends with Harley and Burl, but who knows, maybe you and I will get a chance to really get to know one another.
Uh, hu. said Hal. You never know.
What is your focus in the logging field, Hal?
I want to get into the feller's position for starters. I can hardly wait.
Hey, thats cool. I told him as I carefully patted his shoulder. I just happen to be a feller, maybe someday we can be working together. I've been doing a lot of work as a feller yesterday, thats why I'm in such bad shape today.
If youre in bad shape, then whats in store for me? Hal had a good question.
Don't worry little buddy, I don't think you will be expected to work as hard as I did.
We walked up into the forest from the road. I was discussing adverse hauling when Hal cut in.
Eddy, gear down for a moment. My father is the manager and I am his son. I know all about adverse hauling and everything else. Why don't you tell me something about yourself?
Like what? I asked, surprised to find he wasn't really listening to me.
Well, what do you expect to accomplish here? The question struck me as so odd. Did this boy just slip-up and reveal how others maybe onto my plans of returning to my world? Could he know of the cave and the secrets within it? The questions flashed through my mind in a second before they were lost at what he said next. I mean, you don't want to be a lumberjack all of your life, do you? Hals voice was harmless and unhesitating. I checked into his thoughts delicately and found no deceit.
Hal placed his hand to his head as he detected a slight discomfort of my telepathy. For him it would be like a small head ache was coming on. I ceased the connection of my mind and his head ache disappeared instantly.
No, I answered with relief for his question was so carefree, pure and unsuspecting. I hope to become an astronomer and prove life exists on other planets.
I dont think you need a telescope for that. How exactly do you plan to prove it? Hal asked as though he was not sure if he was in danger for asking.
Can you see me alright? I asked with sarcasm, I'm only joking, they will not look like me, if thats what youre wondering. Hal seemed tense as though he thought I was about to chew his head off and blow a bubble with it. They will have large heads and eyes, standing only half my size and thinly framed with a small convexed nose and no mouths and they will not wear any clothing.
How is it you think you know so much about aliens? Hal asked suspiciously.
I have detailed studies on past recorded encounters. Out of all of the reported alien encounters, certain facts seem to remain the same. I mean you dont really think I am an alien do you?
Hal looked at me funny and shrugged his shoulders as he looked away. If you're sure, Im sure. I had to be careful not to talk too much and reveal my own close encounter experience. Besides, what is it you want to do with your life?
Me? Hal looked at the ground and began to answer softly. I want people to realize there is a higher power which is far bigger than any of us, a power that is in control. As much as people would like to believe they have control, they really don't. Just look at the bigger picture, each of us don't live long enough to make a significant difference. Only with positive thinking, a patience to attain peace and a respectful faith in God, our father in Heaven, can we move forward. When we understand this, we will have harmony amongst the nations of the world. People should also recognize our government is not forever. Everything rises from the Earth, passes through and returns to the Earth. Only God is everlasting.
Interesting. Very vague, but interesting. It sounds like you have a good head on your shoulders, but are you capable of working your way deep enough into today's politics to deliver your righteous point of view with the integrity and drive to actually obtain and maintain it. If you could achieve this in a powerful way, you would also need to deliver some instruction to keep such a balance. Back-up procedures to maintain peace, and possibly restructuring ideas because perfection always meets with opposition.
I am no different from anyone else. Hal looked me up and down as though he was sizing me up. Well, I maybe different from you of course.
Of course. I sent back.
I remember how smart you were in class, but sometimes your thunder was just so loud the rest of us were never heard. he looked at me and the message was received loud and clear. Hal had something to say and it would be my turn to be silent, if I could manage it. If I could finally get to that place where the whole world would stop and listen to me, I am not sure if my message would take. I may feel very moved by what I believe and for what I might say, but no matter how much I believe in my idea of changes and good intentions, I cannot convince everyone else to share in my belief with mere words alone.
Hal pulled out a book from his small shoulder bag, and began flipping through the pages, as if he was looking for something.
Is that a bible you have there? I asked, though I was ninety-five percent sure it was.
Yes, don't you have one?
No. I answered with respect.
Oh, did you forget it in your cabin, or maybe it slipped your mind when you were packing before you arrived here?
No, No, I haven't seen a bible in a long time. I cannot get into it. Maybe it's just because it is too deep for me.
Maybe it was an old king James version. This one is very easy to understand. Here! Hal said and passed me his bible. I want you to have mine, I mean, this book does contain Gods instructions on how to live your life. Did you know the word 'bible' means 'The Book?' It's the most important book in the world and it will always be the most important. It has sixty six historical records and it took roughly fifteen hundred years for the whole bible to be written.
Look, Hal, you are a nice kid, I didn't realize you were the religious type though. I like you and I don't want you to take this the wrong way, but I just don't have time to read this. I am too busy all the time.
Why do you make excuses? Hal asked in a calm voice. I could read some passages to you but I am afraid you'll have to find your own time to read them all. I huffed in discouragement, before he continued. Can't you feel there is something out there? Something very powerful? You must be able to feel it inside of you or else you would be without a soul.
I know all about this stuff, and the way you people try to cram it down my throat. Besides, I would believe in aliens before I would believe in spirits and divine holiness. I am a magician, and I know how powerful the use of illusions can be. I held out the bible for him to take it.
Hals eyes began to burn with frustration. I would not lie to you. Hal said. I will only tell you the truth. The truth is sometimes hard to believe, but if there was a void of darkness with one light which people were to run to in this world, the light would be the holy scriptures of the bible, because the bible was written to expose the truth of salvation. Trust God, not man. The entire bible is true because when Jesus walked on earth there were thousands of people who witnessed his Godly teachings. His message was pure and without fault, containing powerful miracles and signs which proved the existence of all that is holy. If I were given instructions by God to enter the politics of not only our nation but our entire world with proof of the existence of God, I would accept such a job in a heartbeat, but I do not have the power to prove anything. When Jesus would go to churches, he did not tell people the bible was wrong in any way. If there was something in the Old Testament which troubled the father, Jesus would have pointed it out and warned us about a certain scripture. He did not bring warnings, he brought acceptance. Please give my bible a second chance. It is my gift to you. Hal looked up at me and said, I don't want it back, it would be an insult to me if you returned it. His eyes sizzled in a burning heat. He turned and walked away, with a huff. He went back down the hillside to the road. I looked down at the old ratty bible in my hand. Opening it, I quickly flipped through the pages. I found loose sheets of written notes and statements scribbled in the margins with underlined phrases. When Hal was out of sight, I tossed the book into the underbrush. The mood was bitter and we walked with a little distance between us for a short while until Hal waited up for me. He wasnt aggravated for long. Like someone waved a magic wand and everything was forgotten.

At the end of a long day of walking, talking and surveying the land, Hal and I returned to the foremans office, Harley told me Robertson packed-up and left the business to retire. He was on the first helicopter out. It was unfortunate he had to go but when I inquired of what his reasons were for choosing that particular time to leave, all Harley would tell me was. He was not specific as to why he wanted to retire. I know he had been thinking about it a lot these past few months. He did mention a comment, something like, Now, Ive seen it all.'
I was to take over his position as a faller and Hal was to be my feller and new room-mate. I was aggravated by the news so I returned to my cabin for the evening. I found it difficult to remain focused on my studies. The rain started to fall outside and I couldn't get Hals bible out of my mind. It was getting soaked. Hal spoke about his book with such enthusiasm I became interested at some deep level. I wanted to go out and retrieve it but my logic told me it was best to just let it go. I did not sleep, I did not study, I did not go out and get the book. I battled my thoughts all night. Trying to think about other things but always going back to Hals bible.

The next day was a long day and the rain never let up. Huge drops fell everywhere soaking everything. I had orders to train Hal and the weather was not looking good. A rolling storm carried high winds over us and the heavy rains just became heavier.
Hal and I suited up in our yellow rain gear. Oddly enough, my rain suit was a perfect fit.
You probably believe you are an evolved version of what man is to become. Hal said. Evolution was not how you or I were created because evolution is the natural growth stages of living organisms from one generation to the next. Biology will tell you humans are one of the slowest evolving creatures of the earth. So explain to me, why are we the most advanced? Also, if a puddle of green goop can evolve into life on earth, then how does green goop naturally become so radically advanced? Does all green goop have an instructing mother goop, or genetic code to follow? Where did the first living goop come from? And who or what designed the evolutionary genetic code? In fact, green goop has nothing to do with life because we did not evolve. Scientists can break things down to a mathematical formula. This is not perfect. Mathematical formulas have more wrong answers attached to them than correct ones. Yet perfection has been found. So if things can be perfect and complicated, there must be an intelligence behind it, a God and he must be the all powerful creator. The very God people have spoken of since the beginning. This isn't complicated, its simple, but because people find it unbelievable, they won't believe. Miracles happen to people everyday. It is only by our own arrogance that we turn a blind eye when God blesses us. He touches us, even you, Eddy. Somehow, before we recognize God's hand has moved in our lives, so often we immediately disassociate the blessing because it is either too unbelievable or we feel a sense of unworthiness. Like God couldn't possibly love us that much, but he does. That's the cool part. There is a great power in charge of the development of this world, right down to the most microscopic detail. This power is also responsible for our stable eco-system, food chains, the variety within each living species, and even the weather. Nothing can be naturally formed without a plan but everything follows the predetermined plan of God. There is evidence all around us and even within ourselves of masterful governing thoughts, preparations and preset instructions in motion. With the guiding hand of God there is stability and peace, without God there is confusion and conflict where everything would be mixed up to the point that nothing would exist. Atoms and particles would float around loosely.
A very interesting point of view. I stated crossing my arms. It gives me a lot to think about. Now consider this. You are no different from anyone else. You talk like you have all the answers. A scientist talks like they have the answers and when it all comes down to it, we all just have theories and our own opinions which best suit our own specific needs.
Who or what is God? One might argue he is simply a higher power. But an alien culture could also fit the bill as a higher power could it not? With a technology which is far beyond that of earth's, would we not agree they are the creators if they claimed to be? I am not saying you are wrong. I am just saying it is hard to preach peace when you are preaching indifference. I hoped that would be the end of it.
Hal looked at me with wide young innocent eyes. I think I spooked him a little when I mentioned 'alien culture.' I'm sure it wouldn't have sounded quite so powerful if it had been said by a human. Hal noticed my ax. Wow! Incredible! He said enthusiastically. Nice axe, it looks very heavy, is it hard to work with?
It does the job. I said bluntly. I looked up expecting to see God frowning down at me, but rather it seemed like the entire ocean filled the sky above and was draining upon us. I could see we were near our job.
We hiked our way up to the assigned area. Stand back! I said firmly. I began chopping down the trees. When I was finished, I joined Hal who was stripping branches off fallen trees. I observed and gave him some pointers. I noticed a quiet ripping noise from behind us through the rain. Usually I wouldn't respond to such a slight sound, but instinctively I did.   
I turned just as a tree had uprooted from the ground and began falling toward us. I dropped my axe and raised my arms in defense. As the tree landed into my hands, all of the muscles in my body became tense to support its weight. For a moment, it looked like the tree was going to overpower me. I shifted my body toward Hal and pushed the tree the opposite way. Hal was yelling in shock. The tree fell to the ground with a heavy impact and settled in its place. 
I knelt down by Hals side to calm him.
Its okay, little buddy. The tree fell down, and youre going to be fine. I rubbed his shoulders carefully in order to comfort him but I didn't want to hurt him since I was quite shaken, making it hard for me to be altogether gentle.
Y-you saved my life. Hal said with a shaken voice.
Look, little buddy, you're welcome, but I would have done it for anyone.
You are truly blessed. Hal commended.
Now, wait a minute, don't start with your piety again. You know how I feel about it, and I don't want to hear you telling anyone about what happened because you will change it into some kind of spiritual glory thing.
Everyone should know what you did. Stop covering up what you do, and rather, let the Eddy inside shine like a blazing light for all to see. Hal began quoting Mark 4:36 from the bible. Do you bring in a lamp to put it under a bowl or a bed? Instead, don't you put it on its stand? For whatever is hidden is meant to be brought out into the open. Hal went on despite the great drops of rain spilling down his face. With measure you use, it will be measured to you - and ever more. Whoever has, will be given more; whoever does not have, even what he has will be taken away from him.
Thunder cracked and following it, the rain began to fall even harder and it came all at once. The ground was very muddy, so I signaled for a feller buncher to climb a hillside, just as Robertson had done before. The motor revved high as it crawled closer.
Eddy? Hal asked.
Aren't you finished yet? I snapped. Save it for later, we have work to do.
Why must you rebuke me, criticize me, and condemn me for my beliefs, while I continue to care about you? The wind began to pick up. Tell me, Eddy, would you commit yourself to a stranger forever just because that person does good things? Or would you get to know the person first? I noticed another tree rip from the muddy soil. God wants to get to know you through a relationship. People want to get to know you because of what you look like. I began to raise a red flag on a pole as a marker for the feller buncher. They don't really care, they only want to examine you. Let the Lord come into your life, your heart and your soul. I signaled the driver of the feller buncher so he knew exactly what tree he was supposed to go after. You cannot go to Heaven until you get to know the Lord and begin living your life through adding faith to your good works!
I grabbed his shoulders. Listen to me, and shut up! The ground is becoming unstable. Quickly, run down the hill and over to the other side of this feller buncher. Finally, I would be rid of his annoyances.
Hal climbed down the hill clumsily. He slid a short distance on his butt and began crossing behind the path of the feller buncher when a log was loosened from under the tire of the machine and began rolling down the hill toward Hal. 
Hal!!! I shouted to alert the boy.
The log moved so fast. A mere couple of seconds passed before the log was right there upon him. Hal stopped and turned in response to me as the log rolled onto him. I leaped from where I was standing, moving through the air down the hillside to Hals aid. I splashed down into the mud heavily. I lifted the log off Hal from one end. His chest was crushed. The mud was coming down the slope and covering him. I glanced up at the feller buncher. It was gripped to a large tree. The massive tires spun in the muddy slope. It cut the tree, leaving a stump. Without the tree to anchor the machine any longer it began sliding down the hill toward us. I shouted for the driver to stop, before I noticed the wheels were locked up. Each second was like a strenuous hour and yet there was no time at all.
The machine came down the hill and slid onto the log I was holding. My hands slipped from it and it fell back onto Hal. My feet began to slip in the mud. The driver of the machine was leaning out of the window, waving for me to get out of the way. The machine slid right over the log which had Hal pinned. I moved away from behind the feller buncher and grabbed it as it was moving past. The feller buncher was too heavy. I dug my boots into the ground until I was knee deep in mud. I tried in vain to move it but I knew it was too late. I couldnt breathe. My eyes welled up with tears and my strength drained out of me completely. I felt so useless and guilty, but I hadnt quite realized how serious the accident was. It seemed so dream-like at the time. It was like a heavy hand had pushed a rolling pin across some dough, and Hal was the dough. Even with all of my strength, I could not influence the forces of the situation. This sort of thing wasnt supposed to happen in the real world, but it did.
I needed Evon to help me to deal with the feelings and emotions which surrounded the guilt I felt for Hals death. Through the relentless rain, men worked all around me to retrieve Hals body. They seemed to ignore me like I was a ghost or something. Before I left the area, I took time to wearily hike up into the forest, just off the dirt road. I was light headed and in shock. I came to a familiar place where Hal and I talked on his first day.
I ripped the bush out of the ground, where I had thrown his bible. I could not see the book anywhere. I shook the bush, and sure enough, the bible fell out. I wanted to give the bible to Harley, since he would be feeling a sense of obsession for anything that was his sons, but Hal wanted me to have the bible. It was wet and small in my hands. I pressed it against my cheek and my tears ran over it. I looked up to the storm clouds in puzzlement. Take care of him. I said to God. He is one of the good guys. He will be missed. I looked back down at the ratty little book and slid it into the chest of my rain coat. I would keep it safe. It was his will to give it to me in the first place.

	Dragging my feet, I walked to head office carrying my axe by the tip of the handle in the rain. The blade dug a groove into the mud behind me. All work for the day had come to a complete halt. There were people everywhere and Harley was standing just outside the office door at the top of the stairs addressing the workers. He called a meeting but Harley's face was not the same. He looked pale like all the blood had drained out of him. When I approached the meeting and the people noticed me, they parted to let me near Harley. Oddly, the circle of men closed up behind me. Drop that weapon. Harley said, staring me down. 
I let go of the axe and it had a muffled, heavy splash when it struck the wet ground. I heard what the people were saying about the accident and the terrible damage to Hals body. I could see the body bag and I knew the remains of Hal were in it. I tried to explain how it was an accident but everyone had already made up their minds and it was as though they expected me to defend myself, like a guilty person would. Everyone wanted to blame someone for Hals death so it was no surprise when the fingers began to point at me, for even I blamed myself.
A long while passed where Harley just stared at me saying nothing. I could see the hate brewing, his eyes pink and puffy from crying and the building of emotional pressure. Without breaking eye contact with me, Harley stepped down from the office steps. He walked right up to me and glared up into my eyes. Finally, he vented his stress. You killed my son!!! Harley shouted spittle in my face. Murderer!!! Go to hell!!! His fist flew up at me and I let him tag my jaw.
I wished Harley's fist could have hurt me as I looked through the crowd scanning each face. As I swept my sight all around, I paused briefly at Chuckles Billadoe. He had tears welling up in his eyes. I sensed confusion and pain, before he looked down and away in shame. I locked gazes with a few others. It was only a moment ago when I was arm wrestling and having a great time with these guys. I wished Robertson was there, then again, I was relieved he wasnt. I expected a more definite form of my employment termination to take place next.
Harley did not fire me because he wanted to make sure I got what I deserved. Therefore, I told Harley, I quit. Still out front in the muddy lot of head office, all of the men from the camp, loyal to Harley, remained standing around us. I saw a look in their eyes like they were looking for a reason to kill me. They must have thought I let it happen. I was too strong in their eyes to let a tragedy like this happen. I went from hero to murderer in mere minutes.
The rain was still falling hard, Tie him up. Harley ordered pointing his finger at me. His face twisted into a snarl.
Harley, I quit. Let me just grab my stuff and I will get outa here. I stared deep into his eyes for a moment as I let out a breath. I leaned forward and picked up my ax.
Ive already told you once. Put that weapon down.
This is not a weapon in my hands. Its a tool, and I'm no criminal. I tried to save Hal. I tried to save your son.
If you think you are just going to walk away from me, you are wrong. I wont let you escape. Harleys eyes were like sharp slits that shot blood red hate at me. I will have justice, even if it has to a little small town justice. I saw an evil in Harley's eyes, the like of which I didn't imagine was possible. There was a brief stand-off as we were waiting for one another to make the first move.
I heard a military convoy approaching from the road and I knew it was best to surrender and let them tie me up. My only worry was they would try to do more than hurt me as a last attempt at revenge.
Thankfully, the military arrived in good timing and no one else had to get hurt.

I was blind folded and taken to a room somewhere on the Island. I was instructed to sit in a chair. When I did sit in the cold metal chair, straps were fastened to my wrists, waist and ankles. It was a room I hadnt been in before and I hoped I would never be there again. The blind fold was removed and a man was assembling a chart metering machine of some sort. At first glance it seemed to resemble an earthquake rector scale. Lights were lit at the far end of the room and a row of people were sitting behind a long table.
Eddy, back so soon? announced a voice.
Who? I squinted my eyes and focused, before I recognized the panel of men. I smiled at them. I was wondering how you guys were doing. I said.
We are fine, Eddy, but it seems youve gotten yourself into a little bit of trouble. Dr. Evon said.
That depends on how you want to look at it. I gave a questioning look to two men who cautiously approached me with scissors and cut my T-shirt off.
Could you explain this little episode to us so we can know how to look at it? The doctor asked in a coy manner.
Id be more than happy to explain everything to you in great detail but first youve got to tell me what this thing here is and what this guy is doing with it. The operator at the machine began to place adhesive stickers to my head, arms and chest. The sticky sensors had a thin wire connecting each one of them to the machine.
This is a polygraph, or a lie detector machine, Eddy. We are going to use it on all of your co-workers from the logging company. From these results we will be able to determine what really happened out there.
A wired clip was fastened to my finger. I let out a slow breath and tried to relax. I made a mental note for Evon to not interfere. I wanted to use the power of the truth for this one.
I was never allowed to see the results of any of the lie detector tests but I think they were pleased with the story I gave them. As long as no one came to hunt me down, I felt Harley must have quit gunning for me.

Luckily, the school board had given me two weeks to decide if I could make it at the job in the lumber yard. I re-enlisted and continued my education. One night, I was feeling a deep pit of guilt for Hals death. I opened Hal's bible and read every word. I even took the time to read his many water smudged notes in the margins. Even though Hal's writing was barely readable, made up of chicken scratch hand writing and half thoughts, I was able to follow his own personal spiritual growth. I found a sense of comfort where if there was a heaven, Hal would be there.
Gastonish was delighted to have me back home with her, and I was just as satisfied as she was to be home. The loggers fell behind in their clear-cutting contract deal. 
Harley, his wife and Burl organized a funeral on the beach of the Knolix Island. It was a big event as countless military personnel were present, as were everyone under Harley's employment and the entire population of the town of Scamp. Flowers, musicians and lots of food was provided. Everything said had to pass a code of conduct. The Island officials had a way of controlling everything. No one was permitted to say anything about me or relate my involvement with the incident or incidents leading up to Hal's death. From everything that was said at the funeral, I felt a strong focus on not only the value of life but Hal's great faith. The short time I spent with Hal not only rubbed off on me, but it changed my life for the better. I believed, because God could not be proven or disproven, the Lord deserved the benefit of the doubt. I would need to be humble. After the eulogy, when everyone was to pray in a moment of silent at Hals funeral, I prayed silently to myself, Lord, please assist me in finding my way. Should I stay or should I go? As I trust you in your ways, I trust you to help me now. You are the God who is most powerful, thank you for leading me.

With the aid of the polygraph, it was discovered Harley and Burl were obsessed in bringing their own brand of justice to me. They tried to come to my cabin and they were looking for me at my school. The military officials were always right on top of Harley and his little logging crew of followers. I heard, as a rumor, that Harley was planning to kill me one night but one of his loyal logging crew members was a paid off Knolix Island spy who turned him in. After Harley was betrayed, he and his entire crew was immediately banished from the Island. Through the whole time the events were unfolding around me, I was resting comfortably in my home. In the end, the logging agreement was canceled and no one ever returned to finish the next phase of the project.
Gastonish felt very sorry about the accident with Hal. She, along with Dr. Evon, the Islands authorities and my teacher Mr. Dalton, tried very hard to help relieve the guilt I put on myself. I kept wondering if there was something more I could have done to prevent Hal's death, but it was Evon, my little sertz who really shinned as a counselor. He was able to read my thoughts and feelings and use them to help me draw strength from them. Yet, despite Evons ability to help me, the experience still managed to haunt my dreams. I wondered if I would ever fully recover from it.

At the end of October, the pumpkins came out and the colors orange and black became popular. Halloween was a typical human holiday. Everyone dressed up to be spooky, before they scared others. Hal would probably think playing games with evil was no different than playing with fire, an eternal fire.
My mother did not like the idea or the history behind Halloween either. In our home it was life as usual, except there was this Halloween dance at the school. I knew Sally would be there, and I didn't want to miss seeing her in a funny costume and how could I possibly pass up a dance.
I spent a whole day creating my costume with Evon. We programmed it into the Romstrunn. The finished product was perfection. We created a shiny metal suit of armor with a comic book like super hero look. The under suit was black and the metal was quite intricately designed. The helmet was derived from an early Roman style with a single raised strip of metal which ran from the fore-head over the helmet to the back. I wore Light blue tinted bubble goggles over my eyes. The metal was altered to be super light and made out of soup tins and other scrap aluminum. I used my lintin to shape the metal and added a few hidden lights for extra special effects. As a final touch I draped a cape over my back which hung down to my knees.
Finally, I was ready for the dance. I walked to the school where the dance was to be held, but I wanted to fly there as Super Eddy and his side kick Evon. My mother told me strictly not to be tempted to use any volk technology, because it would devastate the future.
Everyone arrived at the school in their costumes, except me. A huge blue tent had been erected on the school field. I approached the lineup of school mates waiting to get in. When they saw me, they began to laugh. Hey, look! One said, Eddys costume is the best, and he isn't even wearing one.
I shook off anything they said because I knew my costume would be a hit. You guys look great. I said gleefully. I walked around the tent to the back, it was there, in one of the nearby bushes where I stripped off my outer clothes down to my black long underwear and clipped on the aluminum armor which covered my body with the heroic image of an 'E' in front of a large 'V'. The 'E' stood for; Eddy and the 'V' stood for; Volk. Within the tent, loud music started up with an alluring beat. The Halloween party was on. When I returned, the lineup of children and teens disappeared. They all entered the tent. I presented my school ticket dance pass and walked into the tent as-well.
I walked in through the opening and straight onto the wooden dance floor where I indulged myself in the part. I did my best to mimic street dancers who I had seen on TV. I stopped in the center of the dance floor, where I danced along with the loud music. Everyone stood back giving me a lot of room on the dance floor. I smiled and eyed the classmates in the crowd. Raising my hands above my head, I flexed and the blue glow of my little hidden blue lights rapidly pulsed to the beat of the music. I lowered my arms to a new position and flexed my muscles again. I flexed one last time as the music was winding up to end in its climax. As the final beats burst forth, I placed my fists on my hips, straightened my back and parted my feet in a heros stance. Everyone cheered and applauded. They were very interested in my costume. They could not understand how it worked, but I explained it was really very simple.
The girls crowded the dance floor and danced in groups. The few couples were also dancing, including Sally and Kinta. Most of the guys stood up along the wall of the tent, but not my portion of the tents wall. I made them stand in front of me in hopes they would start to dance first. After many songs, I began to wonder why I was even there. I was only interested in one girl, and she was taken.
A slow song began, the first waltz of the night. I couldn't let this chance pass me by. I nudged my way through the barricade of kids who stood around me. I gently placed my hand on Sally's shoulder and they both stopped to look at me. She was dressed like a princess.
May I have this dance? I tried to charm her.
No! said Kinta forcefully. His costume was that of an Indian warrior with a head-dress full of feathers. I stared him down and he backed away a little. 
Kinta knew he was no match for my strength, so he stood between Sally and I. He looked at her and asked. Sally, do you want to dance with him?
The feathers of Kinta's head-dress tickled my face and irritated my nose.
Kinta. Sally told him. I'll give him just this one dance.
She tried to raise her arms up high enough to put them around my neck, but I was too tall. I couldn't get my hands down low enough to place them on her waist, so she suggested we improvise, and I lifted her so she was in my arms as we danced.
The song was very nice, and slow, I felt as though I was in a dream and I did not want to stop dancing. When the song ended, I gave Sally a big warm hug. I was careful not to squeeze. When I set her back on the ground, she began to blush. She smiled and looked up at me, tilting her head slightly to one side. She looked so cute I couldn't resist. I leaned forward to give her a kiss on the cheek, but before I could, Kinta budded in our way.
What do you two think you're going to do? Kiss? Did you happen to notice I was standing right here? Or the hundreds of witnesses who go to our school? Kinta had us pinned in the spotlight. I was beginning to feel guilty.
What are you saying, Kinta! Sally said in defense. Kinta began to look worried and backed away. All we did was dance! We didn't kiss!
He was going to kiss you! Kinta was irate as he pointed out what was all too obvious.
No he wasn't, were you, Eddy. You weren't going to kiss me, were you?
If I lied, I could have gotten into a lot of trouble. If I told the truth, I would be in even more trouble. Many people were waiting to hear my answer, so I filled my lungs and made my voice much deeper than it already was and said, Great party Kinta. Maybe you should calm down. Im leaving anyway. I turned on my heels and left the dance.

A couple of days after the night of the dance, I was able to find a part-time job which paid minimum wage at Bigwheels. Bigwheels was a scrap metal car lot at the edge of the town. 
Bigwheel was overweight, but he was slim in comparison to Chuckles Billadoe. Every day I knew Bigwheels, he was dressed in dirty clothes. I asked him why he doesn't wear clean clothes and he said his clothes are all so stained with used oil and grease, even his clean clothes look dirty. Shoes never seemed to agree with his feet as he always wore sandals for every occasion. I'm not sure what Bigwheels eyes looked like as he always wore sunglasses, even in the dark. His hair was long and in need of a combing but that was Bigwheels. He was happy and that alone made him the kind of person who was not only approachable but likable as well.
What I admired about Bigwheels the most was how he lived his life to the beat of a drum that was all his own. He could care less what anyone else thought of him. In that respect I wanted to be like him.
I remember Mr. Bigwheel, primarily as a very large and dirty mechanic. He named the business after himself. The military would deliver old beat up vehicles to the lot where we stripped them and fixed them back up for the people of the Island to use. A special working relationship developed between Bigwheel and I. He liked the way I kept his junk yard tidy, and he was quite intrigued by many of the vehicle modifications I had in mind. Bigwheel would once in a while give me parts when I asked for them. I kept every part I could. Soon I began to draft up a little blue print of a car.
While I was in the process of actually building the car, my mother came down to Bigwheels garage to pay me a visit, and see what my new job and responsibilities consisted of.
Building a car? Gastonish asked when she found me under one in the garage. Gastonish despised the time I put into my hobby car because the way she saw it, I wasn't putting in enough time with her at the cave with the Zandith Crockmior lifeboat.
Ya, there is no terrain this little baby won't be able to handle. I'm gonna build her to handle the roughest landscape conditions you can imagine. I always referred to my home made car as a female.
Who is going to drive it I mean her. Gastonish asked. I knew she wasn't going to entertain my fancying the hobby car for much longer.
I'll drive her, shes mine after all.
You can't drive this, you don't have a license.
I rolled out from under the car laying on the creeper. Who cares about a license, cops don't spend their time waiting to catch speeding drivers on this Island.
Is it necessary for you to put so much time and energy into this project? Gastonish finally came to it as I knew she would.
I think so. Why? I pressed.
Bending down and pulling me close, Gastonish whispered. Because, I thought our primary concern was to grow the life-boat Zandith Crockmior and go home. Gastonish's words were like daggers and they cut deep. I did not want to let her down, but how was I supposed to let her know? I was liking this world. I had plans of winning over the love of Sally, finishing my car, perhaps even getting married and growing old. I had so many plans, and this world was becoming my home with the more time I spent there.
 I often wondered what it would be like to live in a world without peace. Peace was something our world was rich with. Gastonish surprised me with her statement.
Verticus? I asked to confirm this was what she referred to as our world.
Yes, I feel it was a greater power which brought us here and the same power that is allowing us to survive. I thought about it for a moment and it seemed like a possibility. It was an awakening to the real problem at hand. The Zandith Crockmior is almost ready. You keep on making money and going to school and I will finish the final preparations for the Zandith Crockmior. Remember, there are no guarantees the Zandith Crockmior life-boat will take us home. I support your efforts, Eddy, but if it doesn't work, we must be prepared to stay here. This is why we need money and you need an education. You know you can be what you want to be, but you cannot change the course of your destiny. I just don't want you to get so caught up with your life here, you end up neglecting our efforts to go home.
You're absolutely right, mom. It has never been my intention to neglect the Z.C. It's just, the longer we live here the more I seem to like it. I confessed.
Choose your lifes course, Eddy, and see it through. We walked over to a cluttered bench of motor parts and tools. There we sat on the stools. I have come a long way. Gastonish told me. Pretend for a moment youre a human and you have gone back in time to the age of the cavemen. Your accumulated knowledge would be so much greater than all others. You would seem to be a God in their eyes. You could make a wheel and travel fast, or everyones favorite, fire. If you created fire, you would be looked up to by even the greatest leader of that ancient age.
Why haven't you tried anything like that, mom? This is an ancient age to you.
I have, and it has been what has been keeping us alive here for all of these years. I will continue to be clever and unpredictable by revealing some secrets of volk technology. Gastonish paused for a moment and looked down at my rough blueprints. Its unfortunate I must keep from exposing too much information.
When I first arrived to this world, I was not welcome. I was shot at by defensive Americans who severely burned me and took me captive. I birthed life to you, a story I must have told you a thousand times. I smiled and nodded my head. You were considered different in this world but not to me. To me you are the only piece of normal I have left to hold onto. If it wasn't for you, I would have given up long ago.
Is this supposed to be a good story? I asked in search of hearing something a little more positive and not so sad.
Yes, now let me finish. After we encountered the Ornocks and after the other incident where you were abducted, I felt like the end was very near, but we always managed to make it. Now, I don't want to get by on mere luck, alone. I have a secret, a plan I have been polishing up for a long time. I want you to be a part of it. You have been making part-time money after school and I support your efforts. We must prepare for the possibility we may never find a way back home. If we find we are left stranded here, I don't want to continue living like we are, locked under the leash of the human Government. The humans have chosen this Island for us, so I have decided to accept it as our own. If we have to stay, I do not want us to trouble this world. We will live quietly and secluded, we will rule this little Island.
I support this idea for now, as back up, but we must talk about it in greater depth. There are a lot of details for us to cover and we should make certain we dont leave any loose ends. We discussed the idea even further, while I tinkered around with a motor.
When Gastonish and I were preparing to go home and I was cleaning my work-space, a thought occurred to me. Mom, have you realized how since we had these tracking chips put in our teeth, all shipping of supplies to and from the Island have come to a halt? Gastonish passed a tool to me. She paused to consider my thought.
It is strange, no cargo ships, no ferries or any sea worthy vessels for that matter, yet fresh supplies are never in need. We pursued the matter until we could pursue it no more. It just became another one of the odd mysteries of the Knolix Island. 

I almost finished my car after about one month from the time I designed the blue prints. Some parts were hard to find, but Bigwheels was nice enough to make special orders for me from across the ocean at Metro City. I worked closely with Bigwheels as I created a motor which was fueled by air and also exhausted air. I saw a great change in Bigwheels as I earned his respect and we devised a new form of transportation which had never been conceived of before.
After I created such a new and intricate project, as this motor Bigwheels and I devised, I had a strong sense to do the same for the Zandith Crockmior. By the silver crest of the moon at midnight, I went to the cave of the Zandith Crockmior L/X life boat. I pushed the touch activated boulder away from the caves mouth. I stepped inside and the boulder sealed up behind me. I walked down the long narrow tunnel. It led to the opening where I saw the giant hexagon shaped cocoon. It was transparent enough for me to see the life-boat wasp staring up at me from inside. Within the beautiful cave of glowing crystal walls, the growing synthetic larva seemed to be fully functional. The immense cocoon of the Zandith Crockmior life-boat was supported by thick cables and giant chains.
I walked along the platform to the top of the cocoon and peered down at it. I saw no movement and the only sound I could hear was a soft breathing from the life-boat which was just barely audible. It was as though it was sleeping like a child. According to the romstrunn, the respiratory system was functioning perfectly.
From the platform at the top of the cocoon, I climbed down adjoining trestles to the floor below. I worked very hard tending to the insects we were growing for an abundant food supply. I also took other bio experiments to their next stages. Gastonish would show up and see all I accomplished and she would be proud.

Chapter 9

The way the sun rose over the horizon of the ocean and woke life upon the Island gave me a deep inner sense of satisfaction and peace. Still there was something strange in the wind. I could feel it. Maybe the whole feel of life on the Island was just creeping me out. Work was slow like most days, so Bigwheels and I coped as usual. He started working on some of his cars. I quietly tinkered on my own car as well. Soon after, I finished spray painting the body a poppy red color in the shed. 
The car, if you can call it a car, was designed like no other. It was meant for off road or no road use. The roof and hood were salvaged from a Volks Wagon Bug. The rest of the automobiles body was formed from a compressed metal alloy, specially concentrated and shaped to my specifications by the lintin. In order for me to fit inside, I was forced to raise the roof and redesign the front seat. I made the tires out of old used tires stacked up around the lot. I retreaded extra layers of tire rubber to thicken my tires with a special home recipe of hot rubber glue which Bigwheel would formulate right there in the shop. 
The hot black rubber glue slightly melted and fused the tire strips and pieces together with help from a specially designed iron. It stunk like burning rubber, but the tires ended up looking brand new when I was finished. And with test after test we found the tires were amazingly strong.
The front tires were a foot and a half wide and were made of six inches of solid rubber. I designed the treads to grip the road as a tractor would. The back four tires had simple truck treads for traction on paved roads. In order for it to climb over rugged landscapes, I installed a special feature into the rear fenders to add to the traction.
First, the emergency breaks extended two hydraulic pillars down onto the road, elevating the rear of the car. By flipping a couple of switches some tracks dropped down from the fender. The tracks were much like those of military tanks, only smaller in design. The tracks hooked onto some clamps which were bolted onto the reinforced side walls. After the tracks were locked to the clamps, the tires would rotate and carry the tracks around the two pairs of rear tires. After the tracks completed their circle, the tire tracks gave the vehicle an added grip and control of the terrain. I released the emergency breaks and the rear hydraulic pillars hissed as the car lowered to the ground.
The entire frame of the car was strengthened and supported with roll bars. I also added four spotlights to the front, two on the bumper and two above the windshield. A radio antenna was mounted on the rear for the C.B. The minimal attention needed for the motor's design was due in part to how self sufficient it was, as were most things from the year 26,864,789 AD. Besides a few switches to control the rear hydraulics and wheel treads, I spared nothing to keep the design simple.

As soon as I finished my car, I began driving it to school. All of the kids were interested in the car. At lunch hour, everyone would gather around it and ask a lot of questions. I let kids take turns as I took them for rides. Sally lost interest in Kinta and found some sort of new appreciation for me. She would constantly snuggle and cuddle up to me as to show ownership over me to everyone else. She also sat on my shoulders and I liked the attention.
In class Kinta sat in front of Sally and kept a close eye on her, but not close enough. During class, my business minded teacher, Mr. Dalton, began another day with a boring story about some long exotic vacation trip he experienced. Again he went to some place in the world which I didn't think existed. While everyone in the class patiently listened, Sally and I were up to our own plans. I began writing notes and flicking them to her desk-top.
The first note read, Do you have any plans for tonight?
Sally shook her head, no.
I flicked her a second note. How about a friendly dinner at around eight o'clock? I wrote.
Sally nodded a yes.

Later, when school was out, I decided to cruise around the Island for a while. The wind blew in through my open window and I wore sunglasses to shade my eyes from the sun. The beat of the moment had a music all its own. I waved to a few of the citizens who were strolling along the wooden sidewalk of Scamp town. They smiled and waved back like tourists enjoying the Island. I rarely, if ever, saw any new faces anymore. There were far less motorists to wave to on the Island. Anytime I passed a military jeep or truck, I would wave but they would never wave back to me or even make eye contact for that matter. 
As I was motoring along the dirt road, making my way through the little town to the out-skirts, I decided to take a detour back to the site of Luggers Lumber yard. I took the off road which led me right to it. I slowly crawled along side the chain-link fence and peered in. To my surprise, the entire lumber yard was abandoned. All of the lumber had been removed. Even the forklifts had been taken. I stepped out of my car and hooked my fingers through the fence and recalled where everything had once been. Rex, the security dog came charging out from the shed. As always he was trying to bark to no avail. When Rex recognized me he stopped trying to bark and began wagging his tail. He was a great rottweiler. The friendliest four legged pack of tight muscle I knew. Hey, Rex. How are you doing? I asked him playfully. Does anyone even check on you anymore? I tried to scratch him behind the ear and he pushed his head against the fence hard. I bet theyve forgotten about you. He looked hungry and there was no way he was happy being locked-up all by himself. It just reminded me of how much I hated being locked-up and controlled.
I went to my car and looked around for something I could give Rex. I noticed my hickoop disk was still stashed under my back seat. I stood up out side my car again and surveyed my surroundings carefully. I noticed multiple surveillance cameras positioned in high places around the lot. Who knows how long they had been there, I certainly never noticed them before.
I decided to do something for the freedom of a very good dog. I scrounged up a hand full of the small metal squares Darren had shown me and I threw them out spinning with a dreadful force. My targets were the cameras of the lumber yard. It was not long before they were all disabled. When I was satisfied all of the cameras were hit at least twice, I retrieved the hickoop from my back seat. I held it out to Rex and waved it in front of his nose. He was quite excited and ready to play. I took a few steps back before I swung the hickoop over the fence and into the yard. Rex went after it right away. As the hickoop came down Rex snatched it out of the air. As Rex was carrying the hickoop in his mouth proudly to return it to me, I sent Evon out to it with instructions to activate the hickoop.
The center of the hickoop irised open and Rex seemed fine with that. He was still prancing to me with the hickoop in his mouth. It wasnt until Evon flew into the opening of the hickoop when Rex stopped in his tracks and perked up one ear. Rex saw the sertz go inside and he wasnt taking his eyes off the opening. Gently, Rex set the hickoop down and the opening irised shut. Rex tried to bark at it. The hickoop opened up and a bubble of energy formed around Rex. Rex was scared but the gravity inside the hickoop kept Rex at the center within the hickoop energy field. Though he found it difficult to keep his balance on the hickoop seat he did not fall or touch the sides. Evon steered the hickoop quickly lifting Rex out of the lumber yard and to the ground at my feet. Evon, release him. I said. The energy bubble disappeared, the hickoop folded up to its Frisbee form again and Rex was free.
Slightly dazed, Rex quickly realized he was no longer locked up. I rubbed Rex around his neck and let him know he was all right. I picked up the hickoop and he tried to bark again. He hated Frisbees after that. I opened the door to my car and let Rex sit in the passenger seat. I took Rex to Bigwheels and they hit it off perfectly. It was obvious with how happy they were how much they needed each other. Rex had a new home and master.

At precisely eight o'clock in the evening, I was knocking at Sallys door. When the door opened, a stocky built, grumpy-looking man came out.
Yes? He said bluntly. 
I-is Sally here? I asked, trying not to be sheepish. 
No! Shes busy! Sally's father grunted. 
Is that him? I heard Sally say in the distance. She popped her head out from around the corner. Eep! Sally said in a high squeaky voice. She wasnt ready for me to show up yet. I was early and I could hear Sally thumping around upstairs.
The grumpy man began to close the door on me, so I spread my hand out on it and held it open. Sally jumped from around the corner. She was beautiful. Sally wore a pink and white country style dress with a pink ribbon around her waist and a matching one in her hair to keep her hair back. White stockings, pink shoes, pink nail polish and pink strawberry lipstick. It was a wonderful feeling knowing she was trying to look attractive for me. 
Eddy. Sally said excitedly. Come on in. I would like you to meet my family.
I obliged her, Oh sure. But I meant, Oh no!
I believe you have met my father. Sally referred to the plump, grump at the door. I smiled back at him and he snorted at me in disapproval.
Come upstairs, my mother is in the kitchen. She took me by the hand and directed me to the stairs. I entered the kitchen where I saw Sallys mother sitting at the table in a bath robe, looking as if she just woke up from a tomb. Sally's mother's hair was a mess and she was puffing away at a cigarette. She slowly looked up at me with red puffy eyes and just stared at me.
Hello. I said cheerfully. I am Eddy Evon, a volk.
She blew a gust of thick choking smoke in my face. A volk? What is a volk, exactly. You look so, well so, big. Sally, are you sure he is not dangerous? Bill, Bill! Sallys mother called. I don't know. What do you think? Couldn't this be dangerous? I mean if he touches Sally he could hurt her or even kill her! She simply stared at me as she sucked back a long drag waiting to hear the reply from Sally's father. Only a miracle kept the hanging branch of ash from falling from the tip of Sally's mother's cigarette.
Whats wrong with your eyes, Sally? Are you blind? Just look at him. Her father spat. No offense Mister Eddivon, or volk, or whatever you are, but I need to speak to my daughter alone. Sally's father took her by the arm, a little too forcefully for my liking. They went around the corner leaving me alone with Sallys mother. She continued to smoke and look me over again and again. Sallys father was speaking to her but his words were not beyond detection from my ears. I heard him say, He is a weapon. Some kind of top secret military weapon, like a machine. Now, I don't want to see you get hurt so please stay away from that thing.
He is not a thing. Sally told her father, He is kind and gentle.
Kind and gentle? Have you seen the size of his arms? He could bump into you accidentally and leave you as a scarlet smudge on the wall. Now, I don't know where he came from but if there are more like him, they are all dangerous killers with the power to dominate human kind.
Dad, will you just listen to yourself for a moment. You are paranoid and you don't understand anything. If the government trusts him enough to let him attend school and interact with other kids then you should trust him enough to let me go on a date with him. Now let go of me. This is my life! When will you learn, you can't control me.
He's even worse than the last boy you brought home, what was his name? Domin? Now there was a boy with a temper.
And he is long gone, but Eddy has been around much longer and he is just fine. Just trust me for once. Sally insisted.
You always have to go after the freaks don't you! Sally's father spoke heartlessly. He could see Sally was about to get her back up. All right, you heard me out. But just remember, I don't want to be responsible if you get hurt.
Sally flatly answered, Fine. and ended the conversation with a rustle of clothing before she bounced around the corner with a wide happy grin. She took my hand and held it tightly. I took that as a sign she wanted to go. 
There is no need to worry, mam, sir, try to envision me as more of a protector or body guard. neither of Sallys parents commented, but Sally giggled excitedly. Sally tugged at my hand as she moved behind me. I took a step back.
Sallys mother did not say a word. I spun around to Sally and said, Well, I guess we should get going. It is eight o'clock. We walked down the stairs and her father was nice enough to open the door for us as we left. I walked her to my car and opened the door for her with a smile as she climbed in.
Kinta always made me sit in the back seat. Sally recalled. I started the car and it began to hum.
While we drove, she giggled and said. The sound of your car reminds me of humming birds.
Im sure glad youre here with me right now. I think we are going to have a lot of fun. I told her with a smile.
You sure are a lot different from Kinta. Kinta is not so thoughtful.
Please stop thinking about Kinta.
I am just comparing the two of you. 
Well, could you stop comparing us? You should accept us for who we are. He was a good friend of mine too you know.
Thats why I like comparing you. We drove for a while, Sally seemed fidgety turning her head from side to side looking in all directions before she said, So, what have you got in the back seat?
Its a surprise. I answered. On an old logging road, I drove us all of the way up to the peak of the Island. I tried to avoid the area where I recently clear-cut. It was a trip I had taken many times before.
At the private bald spot on top of the mountain, I began setting up my telescope and arranging a small picnic area on a blanket. The evening sky was filled with stars. I felt it was hardly necessary to have brought my telescope. Lower to the horizon, the sky melted from blue to purple then to pink. A full light blue moon shone behind us like a spot-light. The light of the moon was captured in the flowing strands of Sallys hair as it swayed in the warm breeze. Sally sat down on the blanket and began to nibble on some snacks I packed, while I built a fire. 
First, I snapped some trees down, folding them over and over until I had a large stack of wood. Next I rubbed two large rocks together which caused a shower of sparks. Within the matter of a few seconds, the fire ignited. I carved some sticks so we could toast marshmallows and wieners over the camp fire.
While I was busy, I noticed sally was also at work. Whenever she thought I wasnt looking, she would secretively pull out her blackberry or ipod and her thumbs would dance all over them. What is she doing to keep herself so busy? I wondered. She was an extreme computer hacker. It was just what she did.
Faster than a lightning strike, I plucked the blackberry out of her hand and began typing into it.
Hey, Eddy, come on. Sally reached for her little devise, but I didnt let her have it.
Dont worry. You were just writing an e-mail. Ive saved it so I can write an e-mail to you. My thumbs were drumming the blackberry quickly as I typed. It was a challenge because my thumbs were so big for the little buttons, but I managed to finish my message.
I handed the blackberry back to Sally and she read it. She looked at me and said, This doesnt make any sense. Its just a bunch of ones and zeros.
Indeed Sally was correct. I had sent her a digital message. I smiled at Sally and she looked back down at the blackberry. With a frown, Sally was able to figure out what the message said. Using only ones and zeros, the message read, 1110110110010111100110110111100. Only someone who understood such communication would be able to understand, someone like an expert computer hacker.
Sally smiled back up at me and cuddled in close as she said, I love you too.
The fire snapped and crackled with a brilliant dance of tranquil life. While we were roasting marshmallows over the fire, we began talking about food. Sally asked me what some of my favourite foods were and I reminded her how I could eat virtually anything, but as far as a favourite, I didnt think I had one. The suggestion did trigger a thought or possible recipe I might really enjoy. I thought about a boiling sauce of honey, garlic, onions, fir tree sap, rose pedals, jalapenos, pineapple juice, slightly roasted black ants and a pinch of salt. I would dip some washed maple tree roots into it and chew with delight. 
Her marshmallow caught on fire. She blew out the flame and held her stick out to my direction with the charred black remains of her marshmallow smoking at the tip of the point. She crinkled up her nose and said, If you can eat virtually anything, then eat this. I leaned forward and chomped off her marshmallow along with the tip of her stick. She became strangely upset in a teasing fashion and began hitting me. She smiled like her hitting me was a big joke. I turned away to finish swallowing the snack. Sally continued to hit my back.
