My outfit of energy gel covered my body entirely. The energy manipulated light just as I wanted it to, before it created an exterior field imbalance which affected visual perception of my form, thus I was invisible. From my height, as I floated over the commotion on the ground, the sound of the events could be heard clearly. I heard the rapid fire of a machine gun and more yelling from around the corner of a tall tower which took me to Oak-ridge. Fifty-sixth was not far. My energy gel suit pulsated with a surge of light. Perhaps the origin of my suits light was not seen but as the evening grew darker I was sure people would wonder where the strange blue highlights of the surrounding buildings came from.
Cautiously, I descended from above and floated over the rioters heads. The people were huddled in a circle in the middle of the road. Whatever was in the middle was very important because the people were jumping on top of one another with tools and sticks in order to hit whatever or whoever it was. They were so set on attacking the man at the center of the crowd, they paid little attention to the police officers who were trying to break up the crowd with clubs. Above the crowd I saw exactly who the people were so angry at.
The crowd was hitting a man dressed in a black armored gladiator outfit. The man was about six feet tall and two men wide. With an impossibly massive body, the man fought the angry crowd. This was the Blackguard with obvious human features including fair skin and no bony volk plates. He could quite possibly be the missing link between human and volk. I would have believed it too, if I did not already know volks were an entirely separate species.
Agile, and able to move his muscle toned power housed body with ease, he fended off the clumsy humans. He wore a gun metal gladiator helmet and large metal shoulder pads. I felt compelled to do something about the fighting. It was unfair. A crowd of one hundred men or more against one. The odds were not in the Blackguard's favor but there was really no reason for me to get involved. The Blackguard was on an overpowering rampage and maybe he was a criminal and deserved it. As I peeked into the mind of the Blackguard, I saw something familiar which surprised me.
Fast and in his physical prime, for his age, but there was something wrong with the Blackguard. He was far too muscular. Not even the finest body builders packed this much beef, of course he was not quite as big as me, but the Blackguard was far too big for a human. I wondered if he had some problems with steroid usage or something. As I watched him fight, it was obvious the Blackguard had been specially trained. The Blackguard was not just big, he was very fast and strong too.
He wore black gloves with spiked brass knuckles and metal forearm gauntlets with six double layered razors along its edge, also a long pointed metal blade protruded out from the bottom ends of his gauntlets and passed his elbows. To protect his elbow from the metal spikes the Blackguard wore elbow pads, with many little sharp studs covering the surfaces.
Swinging his heavy arms about, the Blackguard threw punched which launched people off their feet and shattered noses. It took less than a second for him to tap a punk rocker's shoulder causing him to collapse to the ground helplessly. The crowd did not move the raging warrior from his place. Courageously the Blackguard stood up to the opposing multitude.
I did not know what to do. I was not a fighter, not like him, not like that. This kind of evil, I never dreamed of. How could the Blackguard be so violent and so young. Every muscle in his arms would tighten up with the potential of an industrial spring, before it lashed out. I saw the Blackguard grab a mans arm as it swung to hit him with a pipe. The mans arm was easily injured in the Blackguard's powerful grip. He used a mans body to beat the crowd. Whatever it took to break him was not within the ability of the rioters.
The people didn't stop beating the Blackguard, and he seemed impervious to pain. I noticed he was smart as well as strong, because when he purposely chopped a person with his hand, extremely quick to the nerve cluster in his deltoid, it rendered the mans arm totally useless.
The police vehicles that blocked off the street at either end of the block were shredded as heavy artillery from a new source opened up. A multiple amount of abused vehicles came charging in. They demolished the barricade and drove right into the area with no regard to the police who tried to stop them. With armor and weapons fitted to the brutal trucks, they surrounded the group of people. The Blackguard noticed the vehicles, and he must have recognized them also, because he pulled out two long thin swords and proceeded to wildly carve a path through the people to the door of a twenty story building. As the Blackguard displayed strict professional swords play, the people in his path tried desperately to get out of the way of the slashing samurai blades. Yelling and screaming, men tried jumping over each other with insane panic. Destiny met those who were too slow.
Three black pickup trucks pulled up and took positions under the street lights at the outskirts of the crowd. Rebellious teenagers were in the trucks with tattered leather clothing, colored hair and Mohawks. Before the Blackguard entered the building, the gang of punks arose from out of the trucks with a variety of powerful fire-arms. The Blackguard put away his swords, and turned to face the punks at the entrance of the building.
Invisible from where I was floating, I could see the Blackguard easier. Across his chest were two straps which criss-crossed at the center. One strap was full of grenades, the other held small throwing stars. Below the stars, also attached to the strap, were long narrow pockets containing explosives.
On the Blackguard's back, I saw a bow and a quiver full of arrows. Tucked in the back of his belt were a pair of nun-chucks.
Strapped to the outer side of the Blackguard's left metal boot was a small gun. The opposite boot contained a knife. The boots looked very heavy, and it amazed me how well he moved around in them. At the front of the rim, near his knee, the metal of the boot pointed upwards into a long spike. Metal plates protected his thighs. Also, his utility belt was made up of many small weapons; a pouch of ball bearings for his sling shot, darts, a large unique yo-yo, swords, rope and mechanical grappler hook.
I was reminded of old western show-downs when I saw the punks lined up, pointing their guns at the Blackguard. I became nervous in the presence of all the guns, so I floated into a second story window above the Blackguard who was slowly backing into the main entrance. 
We made you!!! shouted the female leader of the punks.
You will not destroy me!!! The Blackguard shouted back defiantly.
The female punk leader shouted, Fire!!!
--RATATATATATAT!!!-- Heavy ammunition was massed against the Blackguard and the citizens of the angry crowd scattered. The punks targeted the Blackguard alone. A couple of bullets sparked off the Blackguard's thick body armor. As the Blackguard fell backwards through the main doors, his arms raised to protect his head, he landed on his back and rolled around the corner. Pulling his strangely designed sling-shot from his utility belt, he loaded it. 
The sling-shot was equipped with a supporting wrist brace and the main forks were extended forward ten inches from his hand grip. When the Blackguard stretched back the elastic strap, it expanded across his chest, six feet long. He released a tiny ball bearing from the sling-shots amazing elastic energy, and it shot out in a perfect straight trajectory across the road. It whistled over the heads of the stunned punks and into an adjacent building. The entire building across the street from me exploded and crumbled to the ground in a great mass of thick dust and smoke. The Blackguards diversion was a success and he quickly escaped, disappearing in through the main doors.
I left the room feeling a strong sense of danger. I hoped to glance down the stairwell for a chance to see what the Blackguard was going to do next. He peeked my curiosity. The Blackguard was the most interesting person I ever met and the most frightening. 'Was he really as evil as he wanted people to believe? Or was he fighting for a greater purpose as I was?'
Bullets came streaming into the dirty room as I stepped out of it into the main hall. Glass at the face of the building shattered unceasingly under the relentless shower of bullets. The Blackguard made the punks outside very upset. I went to the stairwell and when I arrived, I heard the Blackguards heavy footsteps charging up the stairs. The footsteps hammered louder and louder. To my surprise, he busted up the stairs as he made his way to where I was. I could hear his muffled heavy breathing through his black knight helmet. He stopped, just before he ran into my chest. Accidentally, he came too close to me and entered the frontier of my cloaking field. His eyes met my chest first, before traveling up to my head. He would have only been able to see the energy gel waves melting over my facial features. I lurched backwards a few paces so the Blackguard was again beyond my field parameter. I knew I had disappeared from his vision when he stretched out his hands to try and touch what he could not see. After shaking his head from left to right, he turned back toward a support beam connected to the stairs. He reached to his side and unclipped a large yo-yo. He threw it and it split the support beam. The yo-yo rewound up the metallic nylon string to his connected hand strap. The stair well creaked and a punk launched himself around the corner and opened fire, with a small gun. He came within millimeters of having the Blackguard square in his sights.
The Blackguard used some fancy yo-yo tricks to first glance the bullets away, second, to knock the punks gun out of his hand, and third, to smash the punk in the face. After so much abuse, the yo-yo still reclined up to his palm obediently. As the Blackguard began to turn and continue up the stairs to the next floor, the stairs began to collapse and fall out from under him. The Blackguard hurtled his yo-yo toward my direction as he fell in hopes it would catch onto something.
I instinctively reached out and grabbed a hold of the yo-yo with one hand. With my other hand, I grabbed the second floor door frame for support. The Blackguards weight jolted me toward him. My hand crushed the gyp-rock wall next to the bending frame. I thought the metal door frame was going to break.
I pulled the Blackguard up to the second floor with all of my strength and the strength enforcement of my invisible suit. When he was high enough to get a firm footing, I released his large white yo-yo and from the Blackguards perspective, it seemed as if the yo-yo fell from mid-air. I could tell he was very confused, even though his helmet disguised all facial expression. Nevertheless, he stood up straight and gave his yo-yo a flick with his toe and it recoiled up to his hand.
The Blackguard connected the yo-yo to his belt before he pulled off his rope and mechanical grappler hook. Before he used the rope, he took one last suspicious glance behind himself. The Blackguard threw his mechanical grappler hook with a powerful under-hand toss. I heard it snap a hold onto the remaining stairs above. After giving two strong tugs to test the grapplers hold, he swung into the stairwell and began to strenuously pull his way up the rope. He did very well considering how much weight he must have been carrying.
The punks only waited for the dust to settle when they began to flood into the bottom of the stairwell. They did not even cock their guns before they showered bullets up at the Blackguard. Most of the bullets glanced off his cast iron boots. 
The Blackguard dropped a grenade and the punks scrambled. I didn't want to be toasted when the grenade went off, so I put my suit into action and floated up the stair well. The Blackguard was above me and there was not enough room for me to pass him. I pushed him up the rest of the way so we were able to scale what was left of the stair case.
The grenade blew up below us as I followed the Blackguard up the stairs. Diligently we climbed to the tenth floor when the Blackguard stopped. I thought he was out of breath, but actually, he heard something, so he cautiously opened the tenth story door. I noticed a fire broke out below us as a result of the grenades explosion. I wondered how I let myself get into this. I looked back at the Blackguard, who quietly slunk through the door.
Thats him!!! Someone shouted.
I heard one gun shot. I opened the door to peek and the Blackguard threw some throwing-stars into all of the punks who just walked off the elevator. He heavily walked over to the fallen punks. The Blackguard kicked a door in at his right and hauled the severely injured punks into the room with him.     
He dropped them onto the floor and walked over to a window. The Blackguard looked outside for a moment, before he grabbed a punk and held him close to his helmet.
You were all like brothers to me just yesterday. Now, I need to send your pals a message and you are going to be the messenger. The Blackguard spoke in a slow deep growly voice.
The Blackguard pushed the face of the punk up against the glass of the dirty window. Leave here now and I will let the rest of you live! shouted the Blackguard. The punk twitched and opened his eyes as both he and the Blackguard waited for an answer. It made my skin crawl. A single bullet broke the window from outside and pierced the chest of the punk. The Blackguard pushed the dead punk out through the window. Broken glass followed the punk as he plunged ten stories to his absolute death.
No!!! I yelled.
The Blackguard turned quickly and asked, Whos there?!
I did not answer. 
Whos there?!!! The Blackguard demanded even louder, searching the room unable to hide his confusion and frustration. You better answer me, or else... The Blackguard paused.
I did not want to give myself away, so I remained silent. Careful to keep his body concealed and protected, he shouted out the window and announced as loud as he could. I am the greatest warrior there is, or ever will be!!!
Hearing the Blackguard speak I recognized him as Domin. There was no mistaking it, this was the same Domin I knew growing up on the Knolix Island. Somehow I knew it was him from the first moment I saw him. He recoiled into the room and grabbed a second and third punk to heave out the window as well. I made myself visible to Domin as I stepped forward and took hold of the victims before pulling them free from Domins grasp. Domin swung around and saw the punks fall to the floor. Domin was dazed at the sight of me but he also appeared to recognize me. With equal speed he turned again to take a second glance out the window. I took the opportunity to disappear once again while Domin's back was turned.
Abruptly, Domin ran out of the room. This reaction came from some kind of danger he saw from the window. Whatever reason he had for running, it was likely an important one. I followed him as he broke through a door into the room across the hall. The room we had just left, exploded in a thunder of destructive fire.
Ahurg! -- Rocket launchers! Muffled Domin under his breath.
Smoke puffed out from the seams of the elevator doors as it groaned with a giant deep hollow warning. The elevator belched up a roar and blasted out the doors. The doors sailed to the other end of the hall. Next, the staircase blistered and blew apart with fire, throwing splinters and hot shrapnel down the other direction of the hall in a powerful heat wave. Sirens screamed outside. Domin stood by the window.
Finally! Breathed Domin, The cops, now where are the choppers?
Evon. I said, Stay alert. If he tries anything, be sure to assist me.
OF COURSE, MASTER. Evon said. BUT AS LONG AS HE CAN NOT SEE YOU, YOU ARE QUITE SAFE. A brief moment of realization sunk in for the little sertz. OH, NO - MY LORD, YOU DON'T MEAN YOU ARE GOING TO...
I became visible for the Blackguard.
The field around me wavered and diminished, before the energy gel slunk off my head as far as my neck. Domin and I had a moment where we said nothing, we just stood staring at each other, before Domin tried to attack me. He threw a couple of darts at me. With the tones of chimes, Evon shot the darts with its gleaming little stars. This glanced the darts into the wall next to us.
A growl, the likes of which I had never heard before, came up from deep within Domins chest.
You disgust me. I said, attempting to break the ice of communication.
Domin responded shouting. Grizz is the greatest warrior there is, or ever will be!
I tightened my fist and drew back my arm. Domin did the same as he ran toward me wildly. With longer arms, I swung forth first and contacted Domin's stomach. Staying clear from all of his spikes, razors and blades, I swept Domin off his feet and sent him into the ceiling. A light fixture shattered and an impressive indentation marked the impact above. Domin fell flat onto the floor and just laid there for a moment.
He thought he was the greatest. I had the potential to have thought I was the most powerful being of this world and fly into a temper tantrum. Only, that wasn't my style. Domin could have probably leveled all of Metro city if he was a true volk.
The Blackguard rose from the floor and looked at me.
Believe it or not, but I want to help you. I told him with a suggestion of seriousness.
The only way you can help me is if you join me, otherwise, get out of my way... Eddy. He knew my name which confirmed it, this Blackguard was, Domin. He grew up on the Island and mysteriously vanished one day. The tone of his voice half hid the icy deception underneath it. I heard the sound of a helicopter amongst the sirens in the distance.
Fine, now follow me. I'll get us out of this, Domin. I received no reaction from the Blackguard. He just stood facing me. Studying me.
Domin is dead. I am Grizz and you can forget it! Retaliated the Blackguard as he removed his pouch of explosives and tossed them down the hallway toward the flames. If it is not my way, it is the highway. Grizz began to run, his rope and grappler hook in hand. Picking up a lot of speed, Grizz leapt out the broken window. I followed him, knowing the impact of the explosion would be too much for me and my capabilities to bear. We jumped out of the window.
At once, the apartment blew out at us from behind. Grizz tossed his grappler hook in mid leap from the tenth story window. The mechanical grappler caught the landing ski of a police surveillance helicopter. To activate the claw of the grappler, Grizz used a golden remote control ring.
The helicopter pulled away from the building as the entire structure collapsed. Grizz's weight began to tug at the helicopter. The search light swung around lighting our surroundings in the mysterious night. Aggressively, Grizz climbed his cable to the cockpit of the two pilots. Grizz punched through the windshield with his studded black brass knuckles.
The policemen panicked as Grizz opened the cockpit door. The officers shot at the intruder, but Grizz pulled them from their seats and dropped them from the helicopter. The two officers plummeted into the shallow waters of the strong and wide Fraser river. Grizz had to pilot the helicopter, but not knowing how to control the air-craft, he steered it aimlessly. Crashing into the river, the splash sprung fifty feet into the air. The rotors chopped into the river for a few beats, before they shattered. Pieces of metal rotor shards streaked through the air in every direction. I could see Grizz struggling to get out of the helicopter. I abruptly switched off my power of flight and let myself drop toward the river to assist not only Grizz but the police helicopter pilots.
Diving under the waters surface I steadily drilled my way to the helicopter. I clasped my arms and legs around the cockpit, applying some pressure, until the cockpit imploded. Grizz was heavy to move underwater. I pulled the brawny man with all of my might, and hauled him onto the sandy shore. I let him collapse limply to the ground.
I took off Grizz's helmet. His face was hard, as if he had muscles in his jaw, chin, eyebrows and cheekbones. I had never seen a face with so many scars as Grizz. With dark tattooed skin around his eyes, like a raccoon, Grizz was clad with unnatural weapons of power and a scruffy unshaven face. His hair was long, shaggy, wet and dirty. 
I placed my open hand onto Grizz's chest. Evon, warm this man and bring him around to consciousness. I commanded my sertz.
My suit, increasing with energy, became a very bright blue. Grizzs face began to twitch as he coughed, before he took a great gasp of air. Opening his eyes, Grizz looked at me, noticing who I was, he pushed me away defensively and stared at me with wide wild eyes. His pupils were fully open and intense with questions. He was unsure of my intensions.
A long double edged blade sprang forth from the upper wrist of his gauntlet. Grizz swung the blade at me as I lifted my arms in defense. Striking my romstrunn with the gauntlet blade, the blue energy gel of my suit began to spill out onto the ground. The damage to my romstrunn caused the blue energy of my volk suit to retract back into the unit. As the energy gel was called back to the romstrunn, it began to spew out from the opening of the damaged slash at the side of it.
The Blackguard was surprised and confused, when he saw the energy gel spurting out. With the intent to put some distance between us, Grizz clumsily jumped forward to climb the rocky embankment but he collapsed on a wet boulder. Falling forward he kicked back at my stomach. His heavy boot shattered my hickoop. I stumbled backwards into the river. I managed to regain my balance in the knee high shallow edge. The pieces of the hickoop fell away, into the river. I tried to catch some of the pieces before they were lost forever, but my efforts were for nothing. The hickoop was ruined and nothing could make it work now. I let the broken hickoop be taken by the river. I strode out of the water shaking my head slowly from side to side. 
Grizz destroyed something dear to me. Anger flared up in me yet I knew it would be a fitting demise to any object of the Ied era. I was responsible to make sure the products from the Ied era were either returned to the Ied era or destroyed in this world. No volk technology could remain because no human could be allowed to possess any of it to protect and preserve my home world. I felt responsible for causing any consequences which my actions might have on the future. Now the hickoop was broken, never to be successfully reassembled. It would have pained me to know a human somehow had it in their possession. Within moments, I was half naked, standing on the shore wearing only my boxers. Baffled, I turned my attention to my romstrunn where I examined just how badly it was damaged.
I was grateful to find the romstrunn was still operational, but the damage to the energy gel compression tank was beyond my limited ability to repair. I looked to the rocky river side with contempt. Grizz was scrambling to climb the rocks to the parking lot. His eyes were wide and his heavy armored suit was wet, causing him to climb awkwardly. I picked up his metal helmet from the rocks and threw it at him. The helmet struck Grizz at the center of his shoulder blades. His shoulder plates took most of the impact. From there the helmet bounced high off Grizz and landed in the parking lot above. I did little more than cause Grizz to turn and sneer at me.
I advanced one step toward Grizz and he was threatened by me. The water beaded down the grey skin of my chest. I could feel my anger begin to radiate from my eyes in waves of heat.
My smoldering glare was obviously intimidating. Grizz needed a little intimidation in his life as he was usually the one being a bully. Grizz retaliated, dislodging a large boulder and rolling it down toward Eddy. With one hand, I scooped up the boulder and tossed it over my head. A heavy '-thwump-' was heard as the river swallowed the boulder.
Only time could predict what would happen next. Grizz lost his expression of fear as a new emotion played over the features of his face. Grizz became confident and strong.
I would have killed you by now if that was my intention. I told Grizz sensibly. Now, put your little knives away so we can get out of here.
Ohhh, you'd like that wouldn't you. I give you just a sliver of trust, then when I turn my back, you would attack! Grizz, still very suspicious of me, felt everyone in the world was after him.
I'm getting tired of this. Would you rather we spend all night here on this embankment waiting for someone to come and kill us? I shook my head with frustration before I charged up the river-side slope toward the Blackguard. He began to growl, warning me of my dangerous action.
Stumbling to prepare for my immediate advance, Grizz flinched with surprise and a micro-second of uncertainty in his own ability. I wound my fist back just before I threw myself forward delivering a powerful blow.
My fist caught Grizz at the center of his stomach and sent him over the slight grade from the shore to the parking-lot. His upper back landed onto the hood of a silver corvette. A security alarm began to squeal irritatingly. Gaining control from the impact, Grizz snapped up and pushed himself away from the corvette. His long tangled hair quivered in the breeze, as Grizz lost all sense of fear or rage. A tooth filled grin of satisfaction decorated Grizz's face, before he chuckled at me. Eh-heh.
I was uncertain if I was correctly translating his form of expression. Little did I know, Grizz was sizing me up. Examining me as a hunter examines his prey. Grizz obviously loved the thrill of the hunt as equally as the challenge of the game. Using the strength I exerted in my punch as a basis for what he was up against, I became the latest challenge in his mind. To defeat me, a volk, would be the greatest victory... A masterpiece.
A stone cold expression settled over Grizz's jaw and his eyes began to burn. Speed and force came alive like fire as Grizz threw his arms around to slash me with his blades.
Easy, buddy. I said with my hands up for him to stop. Put your knives away so we can kill each other on equal terms?
Grizz did not listen. I tried to pop Grizz with a quick shot through an opening, but he was too fast and slashed my forearm. I put my other hand over the wound. Thick ruby blood began to seep through my fingers. Grizz was a mad butcher from the dark ages and he wanted to chop me up like a sausage. I turned and ran from Grizz but he didnt pursue me immediately. From a distance I saw Grizz had went back to search for his helmet amongst the parked vehicles. With long precise strides I headed across the parking lot and back down the embankment to a nearby drainage tunnel. The opening was blocked by a welded re-bar mesh with gaps small enough to keep out small children.
I wrenched on it to get an idea of how stable it was. A quick glance revealed Grizz was not going to grant me time for numerous attempts to open the tunnel. When Grizz found his helmet, he ran toward me like a vicious mad bull clad in dark armor. I gripped the bars tightly and heaved with all of my might. The concrete broke and the re-bar tore away. I swung the re-bar in Grizzs direction knocking him back onto the rocks.
Grizz rolled with the spinning re-bar before he quickly came back up on his feet. I dived into the tunnel and tried to shimmy through it as fast as I could. Ahead of me was darkness and behind me was the heavy cast iron boots of Grizz. His blades clanging and scratching at the inside of the tunnel and his half growl, half breath threatened my existence like a vicious stalker from a nightmare.
I could hear the Blackguard gaining on me. I felt the tip of his blade clip the heal of my volk boot. The tight radius of the tunnels space soon opened up to a much larger culvert. I rolled out of the pipe and stood up. Glancing behind me I noticed Grizz pulling his weight out of the pipe. I instantly started running down the dark shallow tunnel. I wanted to put some distance between Grizz and myself. The stench in the air was rancid as though there was a depletion of oxygen. I detected high levels of hydrogen sulphide and methane. Something behind me splashed with a wild vengeance. It was Grizz. Continuing on deeper into the tunnel using my hands to feel along the curved sides as I ran, searching for anything which might help me. Further ahead of my path, I saw light streaming through two small holes of a man-hole. Searching, I found something with my hand. My left hand slipped off the curve of the tunnels wall and fell away. I moved around the corner to look for the remainder of the wall, instead I found another tunnel. I was at a junction where the tunnels separated. Backing down into the left tunnel, I waited for the Blackguard to approach. His heavy boots pounding into the water was a dead giveaway of his location. I struck him as he ran up beside me. He was paying too much attention to the two distracting lights coming through the man-hole. I threw my weight into Grizz and jabbed my elbow into his side.
Grizz roared in pain. I leaped up to the man-hole and pushed the cover up, out onto the road above. An automobile of some sort flew over the man-hole and clanged its tires against the man-hole cover. I was lucky I didn't lose my arm. I poked my head out but I was too large to get all the way through. My eyes locked with the driver of a heavy loaded semi-truck. Locking up his breaks, the driver's eighteen tires squealed and he wrenched at his steering wheel to avoid hitting me. I ducked back down right away. His left front tire hit the open man-hole and the pin broke loose from his trailer. The flat-bed trailer, which was hauling steal beams, gouged into the road. It ripped through the road throwing chunks of asphalt into the air. Tearing through the man-hole, the heavy trailer dug the opening out wider. The load bindings broke and the steal beams fanned out over the road. The beams carried with them great weight and velocity. They speared into oncoming traffic and knocked over street lights.
The detached semi-truck was forced to veer off the road colliding into the heavily occupied parking lot. Behind the devastated trailer and clutter of steal beams was a brilliant speeding sports car. Moving too fast and too close to the truck and trailer to stop, the drivers eyes grew as large as baseballs before he swerved to miss the accident. Entering oncoming traffic, the little red sports-car collided head on with a dump truck. The dump truck mowed over the sports car with ease before it turned off the road and drove up a practically vertical slope. When momentum would no longer carry the dump truck any further, it tilted and rolled down toward us.
The Blackguard and I turned and retreated further back into the sewer system. The thunderous noise was so loud we truly believed the tunnel would collapse in on us. We ran as fast as we could, deeper into the tunnel. I heard the heavy dump truck slam against the pavement behind us before its load of gravel spilled out and buried the hole in the street.
Pitch black and through the sound of gravel settling, from the silence that followed, I could hear Grizz's deep breathing. We paused in the darkness to catch our breath. I could just barely see Grizz. He searched the darkness with the palms of his hands and his arms held straight out at his sides, blindly hoping to find me. If Grizz touched me and found me, he would surely try to kill me. Grizz could see less than I could in the dark but he may have had other senses to locate me. Jerking his head left, and right as he sniffed the air trying to get a fix on me, a distant squeak echoed. Like a sinister predator, the Blackguard snapped his head in the direction of the sound. It was a sewer rat scurrying in the dead of the dark, crypt-like silence within the dank bowels of Metro city. I could kill Grizz, but remembering Hals death, I vowed to never kill again. Besides, I was not a fighter. Not like the Blackguard, who's profession was to kill. Decorated with a whole arsenal of weapons to use at his discretion, Grizz had me at a disadvantage.
It was a sensitive situation, like diffusing a bomb. Why fight? I coaxed him, deciding to open a dialogue to persuade him to speak rather than fight. He bent down lower at the sound of my voice trying to hone in on where I was exactly but the sound of my voice echoed off the walls. If he could find me, he would kill me. I remember you. I told Grizz as we circled around in the cramped junction of the sewer. Youre from the Island. Grizz slipped a little and splashed to regain his balance from the curvature of the culvert. He swore under his breath at his own clumsiness. What did they do to you, Domin? I asked as friendly as I could.
I am going to make this sewer into your tomb. the Blackguard growled.
Oh, come now, that is no way to talk to an old friend. I attempted to lighten Grizz's mood.
Grizz let out a drawn breath of exhaustion, I remember, Eddy. I heard his metal blades clash together, Ive always hated you.
Thats fine, I dont like you either, but Im curious, what are you fighting for? I asked at point blank range.
Grizz was taken back by the question, for all his life he had a fight of some form or another and it was always for the same reason, I fight to win! The Blackguard spoke with a swagger.
To win? Win what? I challenged him.
The fight you idiot! One wins and one loses. I dont lose. Grizz wished he could see Eddy.
I'm sure you don't. Listen, you are one of a kind, the last of your kind, right? I am the last of my kind as well.

Chapter 13

The thunderous noise of our motorcycles shook and echoed off the buildings in the wake of our high speed arrival. Throughout the streets of the city, I followed close behind Grizz. The dark night skies deepened to heavier hues of purple and blue. An eerie smog lingered above the city streets. I was reminded of simpler days, finding the buildings looked like of chard logs from a camp fire which were only lit by the embers glow.
Grizz had a talent for steering us clear of roadblocks and search helicopters. We hid from our, would be captors, most of the time. The sirens and rolling lights of the police seemed to diminish along with the average commuter vehicle. I suspected the army was tracking us and preparing a plan to trap us. Running red lights of intersections in a desperate attempt to out run the pursuing Boeing Sikorsky RAH-66 Comanche helicopters, the forces from the sky grew in numbers as the distance was covered through the city. Twin-turbine (tandem) armed reconnaissance helicopters came into play. These babies had stealth characteristics like retractable under carriage and weapons stubs, an angular over-all shape and engine exhaust slots under the fuselage. Grizz led us to the out skirts of Metro city. The Comanche helicopters lost sight of us for a moment when we hid under an over pass. Uncertain of our exact position, the city police in conjunction with the military were busy setting up roadblocks closer to the heart of the city to keep us from getting out. There are no innocent people. If those people were innocent they wouldn't have gotten involved and confronted me. It isnt me you hate, it's my military training.

A catastrophic event would bring an end along with a new beginning. Small varying degrees of altered events would ultimately make no difference. But if changes caused something catastrophic or altered the outcome of a catastrophic event, the affects would become long term. 
My mission to return to my home world included the destruction of any evidence pointing to the existence of volks. It was clear, there was no other choice but to remove Grizz from this world. Ya, but I feel like this is just another one of your ideas thatll back fire on us. a typical comment from Grizz.

The morning sun was just winking open at the distant horizon of metro City's tall towers. I attached a pole to where the rear wheel used to be supported. The pole stood straight up over my head. The propeller fanned out above me like a helicopter.
