A complex city was waiting below to devour him if his engine were to seize up.                                 
Despite the pressure of the chase I continued to stay in the near vicinity of Grizz. One F-35 seemed to swoop in from out of nowhere and appear right behind me. My motor slightly shook as I shifted gears then my engine roared. I bolted forward just as the jet began to fire upon me with ruthless thunder and deadly streaks of fiery light. I veered to the right around a sharp corner and on through a tight ally way. Catch me if you can! I toyed, indulging in the sensation of youthful invincibility. To my surprise the F-35 had short takeoff and vertical landing capabilities, or (STOVL). This allowed it to slow to a stop in midair, turn 45 degrees to my direction and with its wingspan of 36 feet continue after me through the ally. The last thing I would let it do was to get a target lock, so I pulled up and performed a full loop which brought me down right on top of the fighter jet. Landing flat against the F-35 cock-pit window, I seemed to have picked up a few bad habits from Grizz as I gave the pilot my own wide eyed roar cry. With a final measure of anger, I slammed my fists onto the bullet resistant glass. The powerful strike cracked the window. In the back of my mind, I knew Grizz was impressed. I knew spending too much time with Grizz would rub off on me eventually. The pilot of the F-35 took the opportunity to show off the maneuverability of his fighter. I felt the jet under me lurch to the left before it began to rise straight up.
I twisted my throttle full open causing my flight suit to pull me away from the F-35. I was air bound again! Turning my head to look back, I saw how the wing tip of the F-35 clipped the brick wall of the ally, accidentally, the momentum pulled the jet right into the building side. The jet fighter had lodged itself into the building structure where it began to burn. I continued on as I rose high above the ally and found Grizz still twisting throughout the tall Metro city towers. Locating Grizz was easy as wherever Grizz went, he left a thick trail of black smoke. 
Though Grizz's flight suit was damaged, it still functioned for the moment. Through desperation and a willingness to survive, Grizz worked the controls of his flight suit, aggressively navigating it incontestably. Picking up some speed then veering off toward a road, Grizz led us to the cleaner and more sophisticated part of Metro city. I had to ask myself, Where do you think you're taking us now?
The preceding jets came about and followed us, but they refrained from firing at us. I looked to the city streets below and saw military vehicles scattered throughout the roads. Besides the fast moving U.S. army trucks, jeeps and motorcycles, I quickly caught a glimpse of multiple SmartTrucks, M109A6 Paladin Howitzers, stealth tanks, Surface-to-air missile trucks (SAM) and stationed Multi Launch Rocket Systems (MLR). Amongst the heavy artillery, soldiers ran, taking up positions and preparing for their next move. Because we were currently so close to the road and military traffic, no order was given to fire at us from above or below, however, the governing powers on land and in the air were bent on tracking our every move.           

Making the most use out of our flight suits, Grizz and I flew over building signs, street lights and intersection lights as we accelerated through the city. Electrical cables were an ongoing nuisance as we were nearly ensnared by them often. We rose above and began to weave around and between tall buildings. 
From such a height, Grizz and I not only were able to look over Metro city but the little towns and cities around it. I saw the smoking ruins of a large damaged area of Liberty town at the outskirts of Metro city and I suspected, Grizz had something to do with it. He would have leveled the entire city if given half the chance.
The motors of our hogs bellowed with pounding noise throughout the city shaking windows and nerves. The two squadrons of six remaining jets, three F-35s and three F-22s, ascended and backed off to follow us with a distant birds eye view. From their altitude the jets gave us little to no chance for escape without being noticed.
The military ground assault came alive. Like an eruption, they launched everything they had. Ammunition came streaking at us in lines of fire and smoke. Missiles were linked to the most sophisticated tracking computers. The odds were stacked against us as buildings exploded all around us. Large pieces of concrete and metal blew out from the skyscapers and were thrown in all directions. I tried to stay close to Grizz, knowing if he crashed, Id parish along with him. We could not keep this up for much longer. Grizzs damaged motor was getting worse, sputtering at times and driving harder and louder than it was designed to. Grizz realized, as I did, we would have no chance of survival unless we escaped the war zone immediately.
The two squadrons of jets joined and dived into the city to clean up what the ground assault may have missed. As the jets moved in to follow our trail, the desperate need to leave the war zone grew.
Venturing around a large glassed metropolitan trades building, Grizz and I spied a large smoking hole in the side of it. Like many of the surrounding structures of the city, the military assault had recently blown it out. Flying right into the gaping hole in the side of the shattered glass building, Grizz reared his smoking flight suit up as he slowed quickly. I flew in right behind Grizz, entering the damaged section of the building. Cautious of our wide wingspan we were careful not to snag any part of our flight suits on the hot twisted metal. We could not continue all the way through the hole because it was just a big burning cavity. This game of cat and mouse could not go on forever. What we needed was a magical way out of this pressing situation. Magic?
Of course, a distraction, a slight of hand maneuver not unlike the magic I enjoyed studying. Yes, the city was a perfect house of mirrors only on a grand scale.
Pushing away from the broken cavity of the building, I flew out, setting the stage amongst the reflections on the sides of the glass, mirrored building sides. 
The structure of the main Occulous computer distributions company was designed top heavy where the left side angled out at ninety degrees. 
Knowing the jets would soon be coming around the corner in pursuit, I positioned my flight suit so the propeller spun over my head like a helicopter, enabling me to hover in place. With my back toward the jets as they came speeding around the corner of the large glassed metropolitan trades building. What the pilots saw was the reflected image of me looking right at them like a big easy target.
The two squadrons of jets tried to slow at once and open fire on me. a cluster of missiles sprang forth in curly random trajectories from the squadron of jets and detonate. Fire filled my volk image with a flash of twisted flames. My body was blown into countless shards of glass. Though momentarily confused, when I flew over top of the squadrons, unscathed and with full use of my flight suit, the pilots quickly realized they'd been duped. All they shot was the image of me reflected in the mirror siding of the building.
From the burned cavity of the large metropolitan trades building, Grizz sprang out, landing on the cock-pit of an F-35. He had cut himself loose from his damaged flight suit. The two samurai swords unsheathed, Grizz stabbed them in through the cock-pit glass. The blades criss-crossed, narrowly cutting into the pilot. Using the handles for leverage, Grizz held on tight. All weapons ceased fire as the building yawned and collapsed behind us. The ground forces, in shock, did not fire another volley with their own air force still airborne throughout the city.
The loud groans of my flight suit throttle echoed throughout the city, mocking the military's authority. 
A large caliber bullet blew a hole through my wing as I quickly realized it was the snipers who posed the greater threat. Uncertain if it was due to the pilot's actions or a mechanical failure, the F-35 which Grizz was riding began to dive toward the city streets.
The instinct of survival a buzz in our minds calculating every next possible action. I did not want to see Grizz plummet to his death as I throttled up and followed after Grizz.
The main Occulous computer distributions building behind us seemed to be made of glass as it shattered apart under the stress of the explosions. The soldiers and other military arsenal scattered for their lives as the building collapsed around them.
Despite our steep descent, two F-35 strike fighters swooped in at us from behind and behind them was the rising cloud of dust, concrete and glass from the great Occulous structure flattening out to ground zero. I continued to dive down after Grizz with my motor screaming to maximum RPMs. Although I was unable to gain on the speed of the jet, I pressed on. The two F-35 joint strike fighters did not deviate from the dive behind me. We were all in deep. Dropping into the abyss of the city with an escort to our deaths. Our hearts felt like they were going to pound right out of our chests. 

Grizz looked into the windshield at the pilot inside. The pilot was nervous and scared as he looked at the street quickly approaching and then to Grizz then back to the street. Pulling back on the stick, the pilot began to lift the nose of the F-35 and level it out. Time was running out and Grizz was trying to find an opportunity to jump free from the jet but such an ideal moment would never come. As Grizz watched the pilot reach for the ejection lever he knew his time was up. Before the canopy of the cock-pit blew off with Grizz still attached to it, he pulled his samurai swords free and jumped clear. Grizz tumbled with his arms and legs out stretched, still clutching a sword in each hand. The glass canopy had jettison below Grizz.
Parachutes sprang from out behind the F-35 as the pilot ejected. I had to spin to keep from colliding with the canopy or pilot. Steering the flight suit in such a high speed scenario was a difficult battle, but I had to pull up in time to grab hold of Grizz and veer off. The unmanned F-35 seemed to come at us as the parachutes began to slow it down.
The two jets following from behind were not ready for the slowing unmanned F-35 and they both slammed into it creating an explosion of jet fuel and wreckage to rain down over the scattering soldiers who filled the streets below.
Pulling up with all my might and with the throttle full open, the flight suit could not lift the weight of both Grizz and myself. I heard the wooden wings of the flight suit begin to crack. Our momentum would not take us higher, but for the moment being low to the street was where we wanted to be. Reaching out to Grizz's fists, which still held the swords, I cut the sharp blades through the straps of the flight suit. Grizz and I landed on the street with a tuck and roll. The unmanned flight suit flew to the side of a portable military generator trailer.
When Grizz and I stood up, we found ourselves surrounded by soldiers, only none of them seemed too concerned with us and no one had a weapon pointed at us. All eyes were looking past us at something terrible in the sky. When Grizz and I turned around to see what could be worse than us, we saw the rolling cloud of dust quickly approaching from the collapsed of the Occulous building.
Joining the soldiers, Grizz and I ran for our lives knowing clean air would soon be something scarce. I directed Grizz with a hold of his shoulder armour, toward a nearby alley way. There, I lifted the lid of a garbage dumpster and threw Grizz inside. I jumped in after and closed the lid.
A menacing cloud of dust grew out of the buildings destruction and rolled over us. Outside I could hear the panic. The dust was able to find its way into the dumpster anyway. Grizz and I choked on the dust as well as the smell of the garbage. I tore some fabric from my shirt and passed a piece to Grizz. Here, breath through this. The dumpster was dark, but Grizz knew what I meant and held the fabric to his nose and mouth under his helmet. We slunk out of the dumpster and crouched down. Under the veil of thick dust, Grizz and I needed to make our escape.
Stepping out into the main street, we were invisible but in the distance I heard the hum of a powerful vehicle approaching. The motor stopped as it seemed to take its time to examine what was left of the crashed and burning F-35s. A shot was fired and whistled through the air. Grizz and I backed in and around the dumpster believing we were under attack. 
As a twist of fate, the targeted air force wreckage was destroyed in a head pounding explosion. I could not resist the temptation and peeked around the corner of the dumpster. Through the thinning dust I could barely see the beastly military vehicle. It had six huge monster tires and the vehicle itself was shaped like a polished silver bullet. 
An RAH-66 Comanche helicopter approached from overhead and blew the smoke and dust out flat. The strange six wheeled vehicle spun on the spot until it was facing in the opposite direction. A large ramp leveled out at the back, before a door lifted open and troopers emerged. The small platoon of eight soldiers stood on the platform with their automatic rifles cradled in their arms. The ramp lowered them to the ground. The soldiers wore grey and black uniforms with pockets full of utilities at their disposal. Their helmets were decorated with an assortment of capabilities. For example; lights, radios and visual systems of international advanced helmet-mounted display functions. They engaged their infra-red targeting grids and turned on their miniature spot lights.
As the soldiers scoured the wreckage of the burning jet crash site, Grizz shook his head and placed his hand to his helmet. I noticed smoke filter out of the ventilation slits of his helmet as Grizz released a deep breath.
Remembering that Grizz was not a complete volk, I asked, Are you hurt? If Grizz wasn't up to the challenge of continuing on, it would become harder to escape the situation. 
Grizz patted me on the shoulder and stood up straight. Lets go.

The sophisticated foot soldiers started their search from the monstrous bullet shaped vehicle and fanned out across the wreckage area. Despite all of the dust which still hung heavy in the air, they covered about half of the hot and charred area. Other vehicles began to approach. A variety of groups were preparing to join the search. There were men and women, some dressed in protective radioactive suits and others setting up computers and other interesting scanning instruments.

Grizz and I climbed onto the ramp and let it raise us to the rear entrance of the six wheeled silver monstrosity. We walked through the open rear door. A quick scan of the compartment revealed there was no immediate danger. The place seemed to be evacuated. A sealed door at the far end would still need to be inspected. I closed the rear door as silently as I could. Seats with seat belts and re-enforced metal harnesses lined the inner walls facing in. The silver clasping buckles of the seat belts had a word engraved in them which read, 'ZYLREX.' In the center of the personnel area Grizz took interest in a long wide cylindrical gunner station. The engraved metal plate on the cylinder also displayed the name Zylrex. The cylindrical station was attached to a swiveling turret mounted to the roof of the silver beast. The gunner also controlled the side mounted heat seeker missiles. At the corner of the far end were unoccupied computer consoles and a closed door on the far wall which undoubtedly led to the drivers seat.
I reached for the handle of the thin door just as it opened. A driver casually stepped out, ducking his head to fit through the door, but when he lifted his head and his vision locked onto me, then to Grizz, I thought his eyes were going to pop right out of their sockets. Before I could grab the man, he ducked back into the drivers seat. I caught the door to follow the driver in. I quickly threw my upper body halfway into the cock-pit and reached for the driver. Again the driver escaped me as his seat, and the seat of the passenger, quickly sunk into the floor. I grabbed onto the steering wheel and held on for leverage as I watched the driver and passenger lower twenty feet to the ground below. When the seats had safely delivered the two soldiers safely to the street, they ran off out of sight. The seats retracted and rose to their original position at the driving controls.
I slid into the drivers seat and took a second to examine the controls. Once I made sense of most of the million or so switches, dials, buttons and levers, the rest was easy. 


Grizz get into the back and man the cannon turret! I told him lurching my thumb to point behind me.
Grizz removed his helmet. A twisted smile of deceit started a new spark of life in him. Oh, I like this rig. he spoke in a low growling voice of satisfaction.
This rig is a special forces Zylrex armored personnel carrier. I told him, but Grizz didn't care about the vehicle's make and model.
So what?
It's top secret. I turned my attention away from the road to look at Grizz for a moment. Our danger has heightened if the government has issued such weaponry against us. They are opening up all of their available strengths to stop us. Our destruction is their top priority.
Grizz nodded, Understood. and hustled into the back. This computer is useless to us. Grizz stated with a huff.
I looked down at my damaged romstrunn, still clasped to my forearm. I opened the cover and looked inside. The computer compact disk was still in it. Actually, that computer could be an asset.
Heads up! grunted Grizz from the turret. We have incoming. Twenty jets with strange numeric code names. They must be more of the Governments secret toys.
You scared, Grizz? I wondered though he didn't sound scared.
Are you kidding? They have no idea who they are dealing with.
Good. I answered back at him. 
Grizz had positioned himself in the cannon turret where he examined the triggers of the rifles. Starting forward, the six wheeled vehicle easily made its way over the area of broken concrete and scrapped jet debris. 
Grizz raised his head and saw distant soldiers begin firing at us. With a forceful click and a clack, Grizz cocked the two automatic rifles before he laid down a suppressing fire.
With a heavy foot, I stomped the clutch to the floor. The Zylrex jolted as I shoved the stick into gear and released the clutch. With a hiss from the air brake system, I performed a break-stand and the front end of the vehicle rose into the air like a reared up horse.
Our opposition was momentarily in awe as the six monster tires threatened the existence of the soldiers with an over powering fury. The front end came down hard but the massive shocks absorbed most of the impact. I turned the wheel hard to the right and spun the tires as we turned around. Hot fragments of debris were sprayed out over the variety of human special forces. As we drove away bouncing over the wreckage once again, a few gun shots were fired at us but not enough to count for any damage.
Set the missiles on auto. Don't leave the turret and concentrate on making every shot count. I was busy enough driving the Zylrex to help Grizz any further. Heavy shots from the jets pummeled the road and Grizz fired a shot from the cannon.
I had driver seat access to the main computer as well. It was all built into the dash. Scrolling through the systems capabilities quickly I found this baby had; Northrup Grumman advanced electronically scanned array (AESA), Multi-function radar, Snader/Litton Amecon electronic counter measures equipment, a Lockhead Martin electro optical targeting system, Northrup Grumman distributed operture infrared sensor (DAIRS) and a thermal imaging system.

The missiles dispersed as the auto targeting grids locked onto multiple jets at once. The jets moved together like a well organized flock. Just as they were diving in to strike, our ground to air missiles began to hit their intended targets. From a glance at the aerial chaos, I could see the jets were shielded with powerful electric fields. Grizzs shot from the cannon neutralized a jets electrical field but there didn't seem to be any damage to the jet.
The electric shields were probably spin-offs from one of my mothers science lessons which she held from time to time back at the Island. Luckily, she never submitted all of her knowledge but what she did disclose was more than enough.
At the impact of the first missile the entire squadron of twenty jets broke up. The jets had some fancy navigational capabilities and used their skills in conjunction with their speed. Some jets were able to defeat a target-lock by using either a stealth or jamming function.
Using the computer at my side, I wanted to find out just what we were up against. These top secret jets were beefed up spin offs of the X-43A Vehicle. Capable of supersonic speed (faster than Mach 5) and tested at maximum speeds of Mach 15. This means it was capable of flying worldwide in 90 minutes. Created in conjunction with the robotic air-force, these jets were un-piloted.
I drove us out of the city and made way to the off ramp. This led us north bound on the number five freeway. Grizz stopped firing. Whats wrong? I hollered.
Stupid computerized crap won't work for me. Grizzs voice cracked under the frustration.
Try to relay the cannons to auto fire as well. The Zylrex was built with a super computer core. Once Grizz engaged the auto controls the cannons functioned in an in-human manner. Every shot was a hit and the strange top secret jets took a serious pounding.
Grizz climbed back into the passenger seat beside me. With the computer in charge, I am no good back there. Picking up his helmet from off the floor, Grizz placed it over his head once again.
Fine, now hold on. This is getting ugly. Ahead of us was a military road block. Grizz, take the wheel! I commanded.
A steering wheel was mounted on both sides of the dash. I was rather large for the small cock-pit and awkwardly made my way out of my seat and crawled into the back. I took a seat at the computer console and fixed the road block as our new target. The road block was made up of one huge tank and six smaller U.S. army trucks. Foot soldiers hid in wait with weapons drawn. Just as the Zylrex opened fire on them, they opened fire on us. An X66 Mammoth tank fired its twin cannons, mounted automatic rifles thundered and a ground soldier fired a bazooka. Grizz veered off the path of the heavy artillery but the automatic rifles followed us. The freeway was chewed up behind us under the heavy fire, creating one big pot-hole. Our rockets blew a large hole through the center of the blockade and disabled the large X66 Mammoth tank, but we were no longer heading in that direction. Grizz drove the Zylrex off the road and up a steep embankment. Killing the lights, Grizz seemed to make the entire Zylrex disappear into the woods. Large boulders and trees could not stop us. Using the thick forest as cover, we crept up beside the wounded blockade. When we were in position, Grizz started us forward, full speed. We charged out of the forest like a mad bull. Over a short slope to the road, Grizz drove over some vehicles which were inflamed.
I was thrown about so much, I could not continue computer detail. Once we were back on the road, Grizz shouted back at me, Where do you plan on going, Ed-man?
Just stay on the main road, I'll let you know when to turn off. I answered back strongly. I reached up to the C.B. radio and hit the search button. The radio cycled through the frequencies and stopped when it found one. While I listened, I inserted the compact disk into the computer and tried to establish a link with the Knolix system again.
The dispatch was hollering and yelling in a panic. Augh! aw ghn. Sir, they've gotten through, sir.
Colonel, repeat your message, over.
The road block north bound on number five has failed, sir. The target is continuing north bound.
The radio hissed during a brief pause. Colonel, reassemble your troops and head out south bound. We will have a contact waiting for you. Over and out.
I successfully remembered the steps Sally took to establish her modem link with the Islands computer. With Evons confirmation, I used the original code clearance, 8462-TS. When the Knolix computer system was open to me, I began to scan through the video surveillance systems. I saw soldiers and scientists running about in panic. Orders were being shouted over the back ground sounds of yelling and screaming. The human attempts to keep control of the situation failed. All was chaotic. I noticed the other human subjects of the Knolix Island were gathered onto a sea vessel at the dock and sent away.
I thought of how much I despised the Island and how important it was for me to destroy it before I tried to return to the future. Otherwise, I would run the risk of altering the future and finding the same home my mother promised to me.
I reached up to the radio to scan the military frequencies again. The conversation was between high ranking officials who were discussing how to best plan their next move.
...no choice but to nuke'em. Initiate operation gavalin drop I heard the coldness of the rough voice crackle through the speaker. A chill ran up my twin spines. The military was on the verge of using nuclear weapons to destroy us.
No, sir. I must disagree. We have a new strategy. A hoarse static-filled voice spoke. We have called back our air force strike team and sent in a small squad of demolition specialists. Operatives are planting mines in the road which the target won't be able to see until they are right on top of them. And to follow our quarry from the rear to prevent them from turning around, we have deployed six Zylrex special forces attack vehicles. This will beat them at their own game, sir.
Okay, thats enough, lets switch again to a more secure frequency, over.
I fiddled with the radio a little more but came up empty. I gave up quickly and focused on the computer. We had a long stretch of road out ahead of us, and it would take time for the orders to be carried out for the militarys next plan of attack. I wanted to use what precious time I had to dig deeper into the secrets of the Knolix Island.
I worked at gaining access to all of the Islands perimeter defense weapons. After I brought all of the Islands defenses up, I encrypted a security code clearance for myself only, and a personalized voice clearance. Password: Genation. Before I used any of the defense weaponry, I punched up the files of all military personnel who were on the Island. Additionally, I punched up the files of all of the Islands subjects, which were namely me and the other citizens of the small Island. I established a link between the two files and began switching the scientists and soldiers IDs and subject codes. I replaced the ID code of Commander Bruno T. Hinton, with my own personal subject code. When I was finished, I inserted false information into the Islands defensive security system. This false information had the computer believe the subjects were running loose on, and within, the Island. This way the computer thought the subjects were trying to escape, which set off the security alarms of the Island and the defense programming kicked in. The only difference was the Islands defense was targeting soldiers as the escapees rather than the original subjects.
After I made sure to have some open doors to the inside of the Knolix Island, I left the computer to confer with Grizz. I went to the cock-pit and sat next to him. He was driving with all of his attention fixed on the road. Grizz, I was scanning the radio frequencies in the back and over heard...
Ya, I know. Grizz cut me off. I could hear it up here as well. It looks like we have two choices. To jump out now and let them whack an empty rig, or get off this road and find a new route.
No, I have a better idea, but we have to move fast.
I made a mental note to my sertz, if we ever survived and escaped this world with our lives and made it to the Genation nebula, and freedom, I would refer to this journey as the Genatia run.
Chapter 14

 Far away at sea, the Knolix Island was like a great ant hill which had been disturbed. People ran in a frenzy with no apparent sense of direction. Sections of the ground were unearthed and rose six feet in height. From under the ground, pushing its way to the surface were large double barreled turrets of high powered, automated tracking rifles. Within the chambers and hallways of restricted areas throughout the mountain of the Island itself, automated rifles with hours of ammunition dropped from the ceilings and pointed at those within. At once, all of the panic and confusion of the Knolix Island stopped. The soldiers and scientist now had a new sense of confusion and fear.
Freeze! Relinquish your weapons, you have twenty seconds to comply. The flat metallic voice of the turrets locked their sights on the soldiers and scientists. The voice of the defense programming was heard throughout the entire Island like multiple voices over megaphones speaking in unison.
Soldiers and scientists looked at the turrets which were pointed at them, before they looked at each other with disbelief that their own defenses could be turned against them. Some people were testy and continued on their way. A warning shot was fired close to the feet of those who tried to leave.
That was a warning! Cautioned the computer. Freeze and relinquish your weapons. You now have five seconds to comply or clearance will be issued for authorization to kill.
Most people dropped what they were holding, but a few rough necked soldiers decided to open fire on the turrets. The heavy rifles fired one shot at each of the rough necks and the soldiers dropped dead immediately. The shots and the screams came all at once and echoed throughout the Island. The turrets only needed to fire one shot because its bullets were ten inches long and had the potential to blow a hole through flesh at a radius of twelve inches wide.
To those who still survived, the computer spoke again. You are under arrest. Any attempt to escape will lead to an expedient death.

Meanwhile, Grizz and I turned off from the freeway and backed into some bushes where we could watch for the six other Zylrex APCs expected to be following us. From our vantage point, we were ready to shoot at anything that came around the corner. About five minutes passed before they arrived driving around the corner. They moved in pairs, side by side and took up the entire three lanes. I gave the command to the computer to release our fire power. The balloon tires of the first two Zylrex were shredded but when the tires popped the pressure exploded and the vehicles were launched into the air. They landed on the road upside down and hard as one of the Zylrex bounced and rolled right off the road. Pushing over a section of cement road barriers the Zylrex rolled down a steep embankment. The other Zylrex just slumped into a ditch at the opposite side of the road. The personnel within the damaged Zylrexs would not be getting up from such powerful impacts.
I continued to let our weapons fire and we managed to cripple a third Zylrex. We had a new problem, we were out of ammunition. Our entire weapons cache dried up. Grizz and I looked at each other, before Grizz pushed our Zylrex forward. We were driving straight toward the mess of vehicles.
What do you think you are doing? I shouted in dismay.
Playing chicken. Grizz came back at me like a stone of passive cool headedness.
As we headed toward the wreckage, one Zylrex from behind, drove over the first two crippled vehicles on the road. The six balloon tires wobbled and bounced as it made its way over the wrecked vehicles. The experience was like something out of a monster truck rally. The confronting Zylrex was fully armed but Grizz and I knew there was no turning back now. As we closed the distance between us we were more likely not to be hit by any missiles. However, we could not stop the gunner in the roof mounted turret from opening fire on us. The first shot blew our cannons off the roof. As they prepared for their next shot I noticed the barrels of the cannons fixing their sights on our cock-pit positions. Instinctively, I hit the controls which unlocked our seats and sent us on our slow hydraulic descent. The cannons fired and the near impenetrable cock-pit exploded above us.
Our seats reverberated under the shock-wave of the blast. We were still moving fast and the seats we occupied were still lowering to the road. The wind blew most of the smoke away from us. Grizz and I shielded our heads from the heat and random scatterings of debris which came showering down over us. In honour of the game of chicken, neither Zylrex veered off from their intended course of impact. Ramming into the other Zylrex, the collision threw both Grizz and I out of our seats and we rolled out onto the pavement between the six huge monster tires of the other Zylrex.
I reared up onto my haunches as Grizz was crawling to me. Com'on, we gotta get off the road. Grizz spoke through his clenched teeth, concentrating on what needed to be done rather than the pain which inflamed his body. We limped and staggered as we made our way to the embankment at the side of the road. Another Zylrex came through the wreckage and fired at us at first glance. The cannon hit the wrecked Zylrex behind us and we rolled off the embankment for safety. Grizz started sliding down the embankment helplessly, but I grabbed his wrist with one hand and held onto the cement road barrier with the other. When I looked down at Grizz I could see the destroyed remains of a Zylrex at the bottom of the gorge.
Grizz and I felt too tired to go on, as though our strength had been drained from us. We just hung at the edge and listened as a frustrated Zylrex approached us. From where I hung, I could just barely see a small part of the shiny silver hull. At the sound of the double driver seats finally descending from the cock-pit, I looked down and said, Don't you have any weapons left?
Grizz looked back up at me. Huh? Grizz was panting with exhaustion.
You know, one of your fancy weapons, a knife, a gun, a yo-yo? Anything? I tried to help jog Grizz's mind so we might be able to fight back.
Why don't you throw something? Grizz looked at me like I should already have the answer.
I'm kinda busy, in case you haven't noticed. My hand slipped a little. The double seats of the Zylrex hushed as it stopped at ground level.
Through a deep growl of boiling anger I heard Grizz say, You have two choices; throw and fight or stay and die.
I heard the two soldiers approach when I finally understood Grizz and slung him up at them. Just as the two soldiers bent forward to look over the edge, Grizz slammed into their chests and brought them down to the ground. Grabbing their weapons away in their disorientation Grizz struck them across their fore-heads with the butt of their own rifles. Grizz returned to offer me a helping hand to climb over the cement barrier. We dropped into the driver's seats of the new Zylrex and ascended to the cock-pit. Once we were locked into position the radio crackled to life.
Number five report, do you have conformation of the termination of the targets? There were only two Zylrex's left. Number Six referred to us as number Five. Confusion was our most dangerous card at the moment and I wanted to play my hand for all it was worth. I wasn't ready to break radio communication with the other Zylrex just yet.
I picked up the receiver. Thats a negative, the target still exists. Grizz hit my shoulder and I released the button of the receiver.
What are you doing? Grizz whispered with disappointment, We would be home free if you just said we had fallen to our deaths. he hit his steering wheel in frustration. Tell them we are dead right now. Grizz told me with a grudge.
I lifted the receiver to my mouth again, pressing the button I said, We have positive identification of both targets heading out north bound. They have split up, one heading down the road at a tremendous speed, the other has escaped into the sticks. I will pursue the one into the forest and you go after the one on the road.
Copy that, Five. Your voice is very different... It's deeper. Are you coming down with something? Perhaps you think you should go after the one on the road with us? the sergeant of Five's voice was full of suspicion.
These are two very slippery individuals, now move out and don't ask anymore stupid questions. I told him.
Roger, Five. Over. the answer came in the form of obligation. Likely Five was busy reporting to his authority on a separate closed channel.
I gunned the engine down the road ahead of the last remaining Zylrex. As the road naturally turned to the left, I steered to the right and headed up a steep embankment into the forest full of thick pine trees.
I noticed the other Zylrex continue north bound on the road in a high speed pursuit of nothing. When the other Zylrex was out of sight, I continued deeper into the forest. I stopped at a level clearing next to a strong creek. I opened the rear hatch and unlocked the soldiers from their harnesses. Using a small camera Grizz and I could see the soldiers in the back.
I keyed the com and my voice cracked over the speakers in the back. Alright men. The target has been spotted heading down the creek. You have all been ordered to pursue on foot. Now lets move out people! For a moment the soldiers sat with questioning looks on their faces.
Navigator! Spoke a soldier in charge. Have you forgotten practiced procedure? And how is it you have heard orders and we have not?
Oh, no! I whispered. Grizz lowered his eyes and shook his head. I had to think fast. Keying the com switch once again I said, I was given a special radio for security purposes. I wasnt sure if they would buy it so I hit the switch to extend the ramp from the already open hatch. I added, Sir. As a long awaited after thought.
Finally, the soldiers stepped out onto the ramp and I flipped the switch to lower it. Unpredictably, the team leader of the squad jumped off the lowering ramp right back into the Zylrex. I need one last word with our navigator. the platoon sergeant said.
Oh, great. Muttered Grizz.
The squad leader keyed the com. Open up navigator. This is an order.
When the last soldier stepped off the ramp and I began lifting the empty ramp again, Grizz opened the door surprising the squad leader. As he lifted his rifle, Grizz violently pushed him out the back and he fell to the ground amongst his squad. The gathered troopers below were amazed and bewildered. The back of the Zylrex closed up and I quickly drove off, abandoning the squad. I left them with the thunder of the Zylrex as I chewed my way into the forest creating roads where there were no roads.
Grizz poked his head back into the cock-pit and asked, Do you even know where you're going or what you're doing? I mean this is not exactly as we've planned.
There has been a change of plans. I told Grizz. But everything is under control. This is a short-cut.
In the distance we heard a huge explosion. What do you think that was? Grizz asked suspiciously.
I had reason to believe the road would be rigged with explosives somewhere further north. It looks like I was right, and I think I've also bought us some time. The military either believe we're dead or they're trying to locate us.
As we came over a mountain, I could see my destination. The cave was halfway up a mountain on the other side of a long, wide lake. We need to climb that mountain. I said as I pushed the Zylrex into gear. We headed down toward the lake at fifty miles per hour. The Zylrex muscled its way over and through the tall trees.
We drove off a small cliff and landed on some large boulders. Just as the terrain seemed to be leveling out at the bottom of the mountain, we dived off another cliff which over looked the shore below. We splashed down hard into the glacier lake. For a moment, we were submerged entirely under water. The six monster tires kept us afloat and the treads of the tires helped us to move across the surface of Anderson lake.
An alarm klaxon went off. It didn't take long for the military to figure out where we were. As the top secret version of the X-43A un-piloted Special Forces fighter squadron returned to cast their dark presence over our plans, I left Grizz to navigate our course while I set the auto guns on-line again. The Zylrex was very close to the shore and I returned up front to assist Grizz with directions. Our automated artillery pounded and blasted as we threw everything we had at the attacking air-force. Our powerful weapons shook our entire vehicle with each killing burst of fire-power. The inside of the Zylrex was loud like being inside Gods mouth as he spoke heated words of anger with a thunderous tongue.
With a lurch we felt the wheels touch the ground at the other side of the lake. We tore off up the mountain, all the while the missiles and canons were blazing. The jets were so busy dodging our fire power they rarely got a shot in at us. Finally, I could see the scorched trail left by the alien space craft many years ago. We followed the trail all the way up to the boulder which blocked the entrance of the cave. As we drove over rocks and trees, the front end would lift. Grizz had us pointing straight up in the sky at times. I feared we would roll over backwards, but Grizz managed to slow down at just the right moment to bring the front end down each time. Though we were traveling up hill, our momentum still pushed us with enough force to make us skid to a stop at the boulder entrance of the cave. The double seats lowered us to the ground while our parked Zylrex continued to automatically pound away at the air force.
We jumped out of the seats, crouched low, moved closer to the boulder, before I put my hands on it and began to push. Not even you could move that thing, pal. Grizz told me with doubtful faith in my strength. Better we just face our destiny and await our doom.
Don't start with another one of your end of life speeches, Grizz. Now is not the time or the place. Just keep on showing me that you are the greatest warrior there ever was or ever will be! The ground crumbled and small rocks crushed under the weight of the boulder as I moved it to the side. The cave was dark with a strange distant glow. 
Looking into the cave like it was an open throat to his death, Grizz said, Okay, Ive trusted your lead this whole time. Right up until this point. Im not going in there! The Zylrex stopped firing with a hiss of exhaustion. Our second Zylrex was out of ammunition. The enemy jets did not miss a beat and instantly laid waste to the Zylrex before firing on our position at the cave's entrance.
We ducked inside and I rolled the boulder back into place behind us. I led Grizz into the cave and he was amazed at what he saw. Grizz was in awe of each new step he took as he went deeper into my world. He seemed to know the smooth walls of the downward sloping cave was not man made as the walls were perfectly smooth through solid rock. At the entrance to the inner cavity, Grizz examined the glowing crystals and tried to make sense of the Zandith Crockmior and cocoon, for the fully grown Zandith Crockmior life-boat had broken free from its cocoon and was in need of its feeding. 
Following me out onto a suspended walkway, Grizz found chains tinkled above and a strange sound echoed from the distance like billions of insect wings buzzing. His steps were nervous ones, as were mine, because many of the wooden trestles creaked from damage. The wood of the trestles and scaffolding was dry and the color had faded to a rustic grey. The ledge to the cave's entrance was connected to a network of other swinging bridges which were strung throughout the belly of the cave. Gastonish and I had used this network of suspended bridges to build the cocoon. The cocoon measured thirty feet high and it was supported with chains which were fastened directly into the stone walls of the cave along with other cables and beams. Most of the wooden trestles built close to and around the cocoon were broken when the life-boat crawled out of its cocoon. Stay here, Grizz. I instructed. Don't touch anything.
Evon flew out of my ear. I dont think Grizz noticed. The little sertz flew to the Zandith Crockmior and joined with it to keep it from its hostile hunger. Long enough for me to release its intended meal.
Grizz slowly turned his head panning around to take in the entire wondrous site. He saw the glowing crystals which covered the walls and ceiling along with the pillars which supported the structure of the cave. Some cables were broken and some were not. Still, some chains held the massive, broken cocoon in place. No problem, bud. Grizz replied in awe. H-hey, what do you plan on doing? He asked as I began to climb down an unstable, swinging trestle.
I'm going down to feed it. I told him.
What? he thought about it for a moment. So your kind, I mean, volks, are some kinda food for huge insects? Is this a dream? What is going on here?!
Grizz, I am not bug food. I have to go down to get the feed, okay?
Ya, sure, if you know what youre doing. Grizz looked down again at the giant wasp, before he held my shoulder. You need some help? Glancing down again, Grizz wafted his hand in small quick strokes. Never mind, I take it back. With little understanding of the Zandith Crockmior, Grizz believed it was a giant insect with consciousness. Of course, though it was alive, it was still a vehicle first and a creature second for it had no sense of self awareness.

It was the picture of perfect health and Gastonish would have been proud to have seen it. I felt so tiny looking up at the wasp breathing down at me, and the giant damaged cocoon half standing and torn beyond it. Walking along the floor, I passed the benches and tables of used laboratory experiments and prototype DNA testing. Old blackened empty exo-skeleton remains of the original Zandith Crockmior still littered the floor. Looking at the equipment, I felt like my mother wasn't very far away.
Though I had known about the Zandith Crockmior most of my life, I still was not used to it. I understood how Grizz felt. This wasp was alive and breathing and I was walking into its lair, or so I felt. Evon told me the Zandith Crockmior was more of a machine to obey my commands than it was an insect striving to survive. Right about now I was kicking myself for not asking more questions when Gastonish was with me.
I made my way past the Zandith Crockmior to one of the twelve doors which lined the out skirts of the caves floor. I chose to open a door, to a chamber of insects, at random. MASTER, THIS INFORMATION WAS NOT PRESENTED TO ME BY YOU OR YOUR MOTHER. The sertz spoke in a flat tone.

MY LORD, MULUNAC WOULD TAKE THE ZANDITH CROCKMIOR L/X TO FEEDING PORTS WHEREIN THE ZANDITH CROCKMIOR L/X WOULD BE FED AND GROOMED WHILE HE WAITED.

Grizz leaped from the tunnel entrance and with his nun-chucks, he hung from a tight sloping cable and rode his way like a zip-line to the floor where he landed on his feet. The insectular life-boat reared up and came to life flapping its wings with a sort of excitement. It recognized the insects and so did I. They were mosquitoes. Ugly, horrid insects with their shrill sounding wings and obtrusive long needle-like mouths.

The insectular life-boat quickly pounced on the huge mosquito. After pulling it from Grizz, it jabbed its massive stinger through the mosquitos thorax. Continuing on, I opened the doors to other chambers freeing cicadas, caterpillars, beetles and winged female ants. The insects ranged in size from that of a toaster oven to as large as a small car.
A trooper stepped up to the edge of the caves inner entrance and gasped with disbelief at what he saw. The Zandith Crockmior was quickly, and violently eating the over-sized creepy crawlies. It was shocking and disturbing yet magnificent. The Zandith Crockmior was doing all of the killing and feasting with no assistance necessary. From a slight angle, I jumped from the floor to the rock ledge. I used the crystals as leverage to leap higher from ledge to ledge until I climbed right up to where the trooper stood. Many more glowing crystal fragments broke loose and shattered to the floor. Chains and cables snapped and fell away from the ceiling. Grizz turned around and noticed the insects crawling closer to him. The life-boat did not break concentration and continued to feast on the smorgous board of creepy crawly entrees. Just as Gastonish told me, the life-boat would tear off the wings from the female ants before eating them. When the honey bees joined the rest of the multi-cultural collective party of insects, I moved on to the last and final chamber. Grizz was ready for this at the other side and let go of the door. I had pulled so hard I lost my balance and fell to the ground amongst the creepy crawly insects. Were you able to do that all along? I asked the sertz.
OF COURSE, LORDSHIP. THROUGH THE DICTATORSHIP OF OUR LAWS, AND THE SPECIFICATIONS OF OUR SITUATION HAVING NO CONTACT OR EVEN KNOWING EXISTENCE OF A THRUSTLE-T PROTECTORATE, I HAVE JURISDICTION TO USE MY CAPABILITIES AS THRUSTLE-T SUPREMACY. Evon explained in its odd fashion.

THERE IS NO CLIMBING INVOLVED, AS I SAID, THE LIFE-BOAT WILL RECEIVE YOU. The life-boat stopped eating its honey bee and let its half eaten carcass fall to the floor. Such an air-craft could carry 40,000 lbs of weapons, precision guided munitions, gravity bombs and a range of maritime weapons. B-61 and B-83 nuclear MK 84 conventional bombs and the B61-11 which was an earth penetrating nuclear bomb. Also AGM-129 Advanced cruise missiles and it has two rotary launcher bomb rack assemblies.

Uh, oh,. I heard Grizz say from behind me.
Don't worry, nothings gonna happen. As I spoke the words to Grizz, doubt began to chill into goose bumps which ran from my head to my toes. A voice activated password was required. Genation. Grizz and I were quickly cleared because our IDs matched those which I changed previously from the computer within the Zylrex. Again, Grizz was impressed with me though he didn't want to show it.

With a large hiss, unseen motors groaned. The floor descended slowly. Tall side walls rose up and converged above us. When the floor lowered us one level, it stopped. Vertical fluorescent tube lights flashed to life and lit the once dark, spacious chamber. At the lower level, we stood amongst four elevators, north, south, east, and west.
Which one? Grizz wasn't sure how we would choose.
It makes no difference which elevator we take, they all take us down from here. I hit the call button and a small screen on the panel lit up and read, LEVEL 1-AA ACCESS REQUIRED. Grizz and I tried all of the elevators, to find only one responded. When the doors slid open, Grizz and I entered, leaving the wasp-like Zandith Crockmior standing at the center of the landing pad as though it was watching us go with sad insect eye clusters.

The elevator doors slid open and we were among humans in white lab coats. Hostile heavy armament hung from the ceiling and had their sights locked on the people. Two dead bodies were on the floor with steam rising out of the eight inch wide hole through their chests.
The sense of tension was thick as each of the five living men stood erect with fear trembling in their eyes. Sweat dripped from their fore-heads, as they were too scared to breath much less say anything. I noticed the eyes of the men shift from the sensitive automated guns to us, their faces red and large veins throbbing over their necks and fore-heads.
I leaned toward Grizz, You'd better stay here, I'll take care of this. Grizz folded his arms and watched me as I entered the computer facility. Don't mind me. I told the humans, I will only be a moment. Sitting on a chair in front of a computer terminal, I nudged a human to the side with a wave of my hand. Touchy, isn't it? was my snarky remark, though it did not seem funny to the targeted human.
My fingers danced over the key board of the computer as I made certain no doors or elevators would be closed off to me. I found it odd how the computer would require a higher security code clearance. My previous efforts with the computer should have been more than adequate to grant me access to any of the four elevators. Unless there was someone on the Island who was free and busy trying to deny me access to its secrets, any other possibility didn't seem clear. You are listening to the voice of Grizz, the human turned guinea pig for this Islands twisted experiments. I am mostly volk now, thanks to you, and I have returned with my brother, Eddy Evon. You already know the consequences.
After switching off the intercom, I tried one last time to quickly scan through the system and find who else might be on line. You do realize we came in through the other elevator. Grizz whispered.
I am aware of that, thank you, Grizz. Grizz huffed as I spoke the pass word into the elevator call panel. Genation. Once we stepped into the elevator, we turned around to face the five humans, still quivering in their places. The doors slid shut and Grizz and I were on our way to the heart of the Knolix Island.

I felt a chill of suspense run through me when I felt the elevator slow to a stop. The doors hushed open to a long hallway. Red rotating lights were lined down the hallway along the ceiling. A distant voice kept repeating, THIS IS A RESTRICTED AREA... THIS IS A RESTRICTED AREA.
Walking through the hall, Grizz pointed at the bullet holes which were scattered along the walls. What happened here? he wondered.
If you are wondering how I know my way around this place, it is because I have been here before.
So have I. Grizz muttered under his breath.
The hallway came to an end and we found ourselves in a familiar lab. The research laboratory was the same white room I had driven my car through before. It was a spacious high walled warehouse with broken beakers, Bunsen burners, test tubes, computers, scanning equipment and other utilities which were not familiar to me. Skid marks from my tire treads were still seen documenting the path I took when I first went through the place. A few bodies were laying lifelessly on the floor. They received the same grievous fate as the others. Those who still stood in fear were mostly Knolix agents dressed in ordinary white lab coats.
I remembered the computer map revealing a hidden door to the room. I searched behind computers and filing cabinets, before I found the hidden door behind a vending machine.
I spoke, Genation. into the panel and the door opened for us, sliding the vending machine to the side with it. Grizz and I stepped in and noticed levels of computers and fancy equipment. I realized I was within the brain chamber of the Knolix Island which had been monitoring me and Grizz all our lives.
The chamber was dimly lit with blue and green lights from a complex structure hanging from the ceiling. It shone down over the master computer system. There, I saw monitors with skyward satellite perspectives. The monitors depicted profiles of the people from the small town. There were charts of my anatomy, extensive detailed studies on my DNA, and relative comparisons between me, or volks, Ornocks and humans.
The entire area seemed evacuated. There was Eddy data, Gastonish data, alien data. As I entered in further I noticed a large cage with huge thick bars all around it. I saw a sign above the heavy metal door which read EDDY. I looked into a small window on the door. The room seemed like a very clean, but bland prison cell. The cell was prepared for me, with my name on it. Hung beside the cell door was my old axe from my days as a logger. I took it down from the wall and palmed it in my grip letting memories fill my thoughts. Grizz began to take an interest in my ax. I remembered Hal and lifted the axe to re-hang it on the wall.
A clang of metal against metal was heard from a level above us, like spare change or keys falling to the floor. What was that? Grizz whispered lifting his head at the sound.
I changed my mind about hanging my axe back on the hooks and kept it in hand, Lets find out. We headed up the metal stairs to the second level. My acute senses detected movement at a work station. Telepathically I touched an intelligence. This was the mole who was hacking the system. Sure enough, hiding under the desk of yet another computer terminal was a Knolix agent. Uh, um... nothn. the agent quivered in fear. I moved the axe away from his throat and plopped him down into his chair.

Neither do I. If you were doing nothing then why is your computer on? I examined the screen and saw this was the human trying to break my code. Having trouble gaining access are we? the agent spoke not a word believing anything he said would be used against him. Answer me, and you would be wise not to lie...
Still, the human did not answer for he was frozen with fear. I lifted my axe over my head to chop the lap top computer in half. The agent thought I was about to split him in two as he shut his eyes tightly, but I did not drop my axe at all as I heard something else, a slight muffle of static coming from the speakers of the lap top. ...is recorded time of impact. spoke an officers voice broken with static. Repeat, direct hit. Factor and targeted site destroyed. Situation successful and secured.

I suppose they used it to make comparisons between the alien and myself.

I asked knowing it was possible he had vital information but not expecting it.
I could not break your code. the agent answered.
I know. I answered him with a telepathic suggestion where he was hiding something.
I am not a very good hacker so breaking the code was just a waste of time for me. Instead, I accessed some secret files, code; Dainna, and brought the volk soldiers on line. I suggest you let me out of here to shut them down if you want to survive. the young agent became cocky.
You threatening me? I don't believe you. I brushed him off, knowing he was telling me the truth. I am the only volk on this Island.
These are clones. he spoke with a thicker sense of attitude, like I was too stupid to figure it out. Check if you don't believe me. I've programmed their mission objectives to target both you and Domin. not only did he challenge me, he really wanted me to call his bluff. My name is, Grizz, you little smart ass! The echo of Grizzs voice boomed through the chamber like thunder.

They were not changed when I accessed the Dainna files.
Realization hit me how the Dainna files may not have been affected by the files of the Knolix system. The Dainna files could have been separate files. I immediately tapped into the nearest computer and searched the files for Dainna.
So what does Dainna stand for? Could it be DNA? I wondered out loud.
Hence, volk clones. These are the most dangerous of our military's bad boys. informed the bratty agent. The file was found almost instantly, and a feeling of dread purged my veins. It was not part of the Knolix files. They were independent files and were not affected by my alterations. The cloned volk soldiers were loose and hunting Grizz and I. They knew our identities and they could track us through the computers surveillance system. I only hoped they hadn't found us yet. It was too late for me to change ID and subject codes again and I would need more time to undertake such an extensive job. We should not have come back to the Knolix Island. To keep the game interesting, I altered the computers tracking system. I told the computer, Grizz and I were on the west side of the Islands surface. All I had to do was wait for the clone soldiers to move out in the other direction before we continued. It was imperative we avoided accidentally crossing paths with even one cloned volk soldier.

What was it, Consort One? Did they get any sort of identity?... 
Bogy was positively unidentified, sir... But it was spotted heading out in the direction of the Knolix project at 14:36, pacific time...
...We have lost contact with the Island... came a response with a grievous sense of dread.

Hey, don't leave me here! the agent shouted. Let me out!
I rose from the computer and took my ax. If this data is true, you'll be safer in there. I hit the button preventing sound from escaping the cell. 
We turned and fled from the chamber to investigate the noise. Something heavy hammered on the elevator door. It was not the elevator we came from, but it was the elevator I planned to use next. Swooping the wide blade of my axe upward, I defensively protected myself. The edge of my axe met the solid head of Wally's huge sledge hammer. Not only did the sledge hammer win, and send my double bladed axe back at me, he also chipped my blade. As my axe bounced back toward me dangerously close to a severe chop, I rolled with it. When the momentum of my axe began moving past me, I shifted my weight again which put a swing on my outstretched arms and sending my axe back around for an ultimate death blow.
Somehow, Wally predicted this move as he was ready to block it as I moved in. This time, my axe came to an instant stop at Wally's sledge hammer. With a quick maneuver, Wally hooked the inner blade of my axe with the handle of his hammer and yanked it clear from my grip.

Grizz threw his swords around with his sharp edges shimmering in a confusing dance of storming blades. Andy was not intimidated by the random skill of Grizz's sword's play. With the loud gas powered angle grinder in a buzz, Andy used it to cut at Grizz's swords. Whenever the blade of the swords met the diamond cutting edge of the heavy duty powered grinder, the swords would be kicked back in a shower of sparks. This frustrated Grizz and his anger escalated, but no matter how angry Grizz became, Andy just kept coming. With two big swings of the angle grinder, Andy managed to knock the swords out of Grizz's grip one after the other.
Glancing down at the weapons he wore at his belt, Grizz determined he did not have what it took to defeat the powerful angle grinder. Andy jumped toward Grizz, but Grizz conducted a perfect back flip landing on his feet. Finding he was amongst the hanging laundry, Grizz took a pair of mechanics coveralls from the rack and whipped them out at the angle grinder. Instantly, the high powered grinder grabbed hold of the clothing and it spun onto the circular grinding disk. The grinder seized up and Grizz was right on top of Andy dropping a heavy volk fist of fury. 
SLAM!!!
Grizz was sure good at being bad.

Wally lifted his huge sledge hammer over his head with a blank robotic expression as he prepared to finish me. A lucky random rocket bullet shot, or at least lucky for me, hit the handle of the sledge hammer and the enlarged hammer head dropped to the floor with a heavy thud.
I rose up instantly and booted Wally hard, right in his stomach. Falling backwards clumsily, Wally smacked the back of his head along with his upper back against the loader and couldn't find his balance until he lay flat on the floor. Turning his head to frown at me, Wally reached into his open lunch box and pulled out a silver fork. Throwing the fork at me, I quickly lifted the unconscious Andy to shield myself. The little fork came twirling at me quickly, but when I lifted Andy high enough, the fork struck him just below his left eye.
I reached around and pulled the fork out of Andy's cheek bone and threw it back at Wally. This distracted Wally enough for Grizz to make his way around and get the jump on him. With a quick motion, Grizz separated the mind control devise from Wally's head. Without the mind control devise, the cloned volks were unable to think for themselves. They were like dead people.

Rocket bullets came showering in around us, shredding everything in the shop as the countless cloned volk soldiers came storming into the shop surrounding us. 
Grizz and I ducked for cover behind a cluttered tool cabinet to avoid being hit by even one of the blazing rocket bullets. Canisters of various compressed gasses exploded in the cross-fire like bombs. The explosions and rifle rockets shook the entire Knolix Island from the inside out like it was a volcano ready to explode.
Grizz found his samurai swords on the floor where he picked them up and slid them back into their holders of his belt. Next, he took hold of his grappler hook and began to unwind the rope.
What're you doing, Grizz? Through the chaos and noise, I wondered what Grizz's plan was or if he even had one.
I'm going to out in a blaze of fire and I'm taking as many of these zombie volks with me as I can. Straightening up enough to peek over the edge of the tool cabinet, Grizz saw the cloned volk soldiers were advancing quickly before he tossed his mechanical grappler hook at them.
One of the clones saw the grappler coming at him through the air and used his rifle to shield himself from it. Grizz pressed a button on his remote control ring to close the robotic fingers of the grappler. The grappler established a strong grip, clutching around the clone volk soldier's rifle. With a powerful tug, Grizz pulled the rifle to himself.
Oh, great. You have a rifle, Grizz. You know you only have a hundred others gunning for you! I didn't see how his rifle would be an advantage against the others.
Grizz looked at me with a slight, coy, shake of his head, then he looked past me at the huge motor suspended from the overhead crane, Eddy, perhaps you can learn something from me after all. Lifting his rifle, Grizz took aim and shot the chains of the crane which held the weight of the massive motor.
After Grizz did this he turned his attention on the advancing clone volks, firing off all of the ammunition the rifle was stocked with. I observed how the clone volks didn't know pain. When they had gotten shot, they didn't acknowledge their wounds or the other wounded clone volk soldiers around them. As long as their bodies were still capable of going on, they just kept coming.

Breaking free from the chains, the heavy engine dropped to the floor with a shock wave on impact where it creaked with the sound of twisting metal. The shift of weight started a momentum of movement as it rolled toward the army of cloned volk soldiers.
The shooting from the loud rifles mysteriously stopped. Grizz dropped the empty clone soldier rifle to the floor and took hold of a single samurai sword. I was empty handed and I wondered if the silence was leading to a moment of escape so I took hold of the empty rifle at my feet. I could use it to bluff a threat or treat it like it was a club. It wasn't my first choice as far as defensive weaponry goes, but it was all I could get my hands on at the moment. As Grizz and I looked to see the clone volk's situation, we found ourselves surrounded by the countless, mindless soldiers.
Beyond the crowd of blank faced clone volks, the great heavy, slow rolling motor came sauntering by and squashed a trail of cloned volk soldiers who were dumb to the dangerous incident. 
Grizz and I were captured at the center of the great crowd of clone volks. All of the clone volk soldier's rifles were pointing inward at us. I thought we should put our weapons down and lift our empty hands in humble submission of surrender, but Grizz remained still, holding stiff arms to his samurai sword. I had a telepathic sense that Grizz would soon expect us to fight rather than surrender, side by side.
Still holding my clone soldier rifle, I looked at Grizz's sword, and spoke quietly to him, I'd sure like to be holding a sword right now. Evon discretely flew out of my ear and attached to my lintin. The lintin began to glow as a ray of light shot out of the little sertz's eyes to the rifle in my hands. The heavy caliber rifle manifested it's shape to form a wide bladed sword worthy to to be welded by only a volk.
Nice trick. Grizz remarked, as he welcomed any advantage in our time of desperate survival. If you can do that, can't you disable any rifle held by the clone volks? This was our zero hour.
Perhaps Grizz's idea would work. I told Evon to disable all of the rapid fire rocket bullet rifles and the little sertz flew off to carry out my command. I saw Grizz get a look of confidence in his eyes as a half-smile grew from the corner of his mouth.
The cloned volks began squeezing the triggers of their rifles, but the rocket shots never came. Evon had managed to disable many of the clone's rifles in the near vicinity, but many cloned volks further away still held functional rifles. 
I tore off a metal door of the tool cabinet from its hinges to use as a shield. Three rocket bullets exploded from my new shield instantly. When Grizz saw this, he too tore off a door from the tool cabinet as well to shield himself from rocket bullets.
The clone volk soldiers spread out and dispersed when their rifles did not function properly, but Grizz and I did not want to let them get too far. With a shield in one hand and a sword in the other, Grizz and I went to work, slashing and striking at the clones.
He unarmed clone volks retaliated by throwing tools and bolts at us very hard and from very long distances. My new sword was hungry to make certain no clone volk would have arms enough to throw a thing. We defended ourselves well though the thrown objects became heavier projectiles and dangerously more powerful. The fast action of the clone volk soldiers kept Grizz and I from dismembering them as we could have.
Through the pummeling of metal objects, Grizz and I found a corner where we ducked behind for safety. There, Grizz gave me a little advise for the battlefield; Eddy, for a ninja, everything is a weapon. gallantly, Grizz spun around the corner and faced the clone volks. As I watched, he tossed his sword high over his head as he caught a crow bar out of the air that was meant to strike him and returned it with great force. The crow bar caught a clone volk right in his glowing red eye.
Another clone volk rushed him, but Grizz leapt into the air with a spin as he caught his sword which was falling to him from above and he thrusted it into the chest of his large volk assailant. Many other clones stood in Grizz's warpath as he carved his mark right through them with his sharp samurai sword.
A sneaky clone soldier tried to get the jump on me but my sword cut him into three red squirting pieces. The sword was great, but I felt most comfortable with my axe.
I joined my brother on the warpath, whistling my large sword at the clones at close range and kicking pieces as they were collecting in quantity at our feet. During the battle, I watched carefully to be sure where my axe ended up. I found the clones were programmed to target the volk who carried the big double bladed ax. Watching from afar, I found my theory to be true as the clone volks would take turns lifting my axe to examine it. Each time a clone volk picked up my axe, the clone volk would be targeted by one of his own cloned brothers and executed with a rocket bullet to a vital part of the body. They had no fear, no mercy and no regret.
I turned to face the sound of a motor as it started up beyond the volk soldiers. Noticing the gathering of clone volk soldiers splitting up to make room between them, I took interest as the chain-link fenced gate blew open. The heavy duty engineer mechanic volk, Wally came bounding toward me riding the same miniature Honda fifty motorcycle that I lost in the traffic jam. 
Swinging a chain with a large metal hook at the end of it, Wally thundered the short cycle by me, as he let the hook and chain out at length to strike me but I used my sword to defend myself. The chain wrapped around the sword and with Wally's powerful tug, he pulled it free from my grasp. Only, Wally pulled so hard, the sword embedded itself right into the front tire spokes of his motor cycle. The front tire seized to a complete stop and Wally was launched off the seat. Hitting his head hard on a metal I-beam, Wally sat with a few teeth missing from a dazed smile on his face. I could almost hear the chirping birds flying rings around his head.
I turned from the fallen volk engineer to ready myself for what the other clone volk soldiers were about to try.
Still wobbling with a little dizziness, Wally still rose up to go after me, especially when I was unarmed. Taking hold of the hilt of my sword from the front tire of the little motorcycle, Wally tightened his body, frowning at me like my time was up. He was going to shove my sword up through my back so hard, he would push the wide blade right out through my chest. 
I was not sure how much Grizz had seen from Wally, as Grizz was busy defending himself from another platoon. Without knowing I needed him, Grizz flew in from out of nowhere holding a large black tarp. Kicking the sword out of Wally's hand, I turned around in disbelief. The tip of the wide sword embedded itself into the wooden ceiling, fifteen feet above us.
Grizz punched Wally in the head before he wrapped him up in the black tarp then quickly winding him in a white cord, Grizz stood back a pace to admire his work.
Wally was completely covered tightly within the black tarp. Only Wally's steel toed work boots could be seen. The tarp began to move as Wally was beginning to move inside.
Grizz jumped and with both feet, he kicked Wally toward a vehicular work pit. Bouncing off the guardrails, Wally ended up sliding down the stairs to the pit, head first. Grizz chuckled at the sight of Wally's head bouncing off every step as he slid all the way to the bottom of the stairway.

As the cloned volk soldiers continued to invade the large mechanics shop, I wondered if Grizz and I would ever actually make it out. Marching upon us and our position, I began to rely on my quick thinking magician techniques of slight of hand. The clones almost cornered me as I slipped into a door to a cover all closet. There I was bombarded with a volley of fire power which peppered the metal closet construct. The blows came at close quarters, but the closet was long and I escaped from a door at the far end. The clone volks did not consider I would shimmy my way unseen, so quickly.
The assault continued on, but neither Grizz nor I were about to give up the attack. We lunged, and thrusted or swords, cutting up the clone volks like an eruption of unstoppable punishment. The clone volk soldier raid did not show signs of slowing down as I saw a steady stream of them entering the far doors. After a while my mind went into an auto pilot mode, the onslaught of fresh soldiers made no difference. I split up from Grizz as I charged up the ramps leaping to high scaffolding. At times it seemed Grizz and I were winning the battle until another group entered to strengthen their advance.
Grizz did not seem to need any assistance from me as he besieged with a professionalism I had never experienced before. Even from my untrained eye, it was obvious Grizz was using extensive fighting techniques besides his ninja training. The combination of Grizz's battle experience, training, strength and untamed rage made him the warrior storming machine he was created to be. The way we over powered the clone volk soldiers built us up with a confidence that could not be explained, only experienced.
In a sneaky manner, I kicked out the lights near and around the janitorial area. I took a rifle from a fallen clone volk and made a stop at the soap station before the rifle was returned. When the cloned volk soldier tried to use the rifle on me, only a bunch of bubbles shot out of the end of it.
Both Grizz and I used the illusion of disappearance for the sake of confusion and adding fear, though the clone volks did not have more than one emotional expression so I don't believe they knew fear. Grizz set off smoke bombs before he would vanish from sight, which was part of his ninja training. I used a simpler means whereby when I tracked a clone volk I was engaged in confrontation with, I could move behind an object and either drop down or leap up to be somewhere or nowhere that I was visually expected to be. With this method, I could get any of the clone volk soldiers to follow me. I would also use my shadow as a tool to mislead or confuse the clone volks where I could trap them or cause them to fall from a great height.
Using many of the variety of tools and power tools, Grizz had his swords put away so he could defend himself and fight with an eight foot pole. He was very comfortable with this choice of weapon, but was there a weapon Grizz couldn't handle? 
The numbers of the clone volk soldiers began to thin with the number of casualties decorating much of the mechanic's shop. Both Grizz and I paused in awe as a volk clone who was much bigger and taller than the rest came stomping toward us. With a thunder clap, the giant cloned volk cracked his enormous whip. I could only speculate of some chemical growth defect which must have occurred in the lab somehow.
Grizz made his way to me by using his nun-chucks to slide down a tight cable where he supplied me with some new advise as he recalled his intensive training; Balance, Eddy, I am watching you and you are off center a lot. Now, clear your mind and be mindful and ready for what will happen next, but first always, you must know calmness.
Calmness, Grizz? Is it really you saying this? Perhaps you should take a spoonful of your own medicine? I told him as I thought I was doing very well.
Grizz did not respond with a snappy come back or with anything at all, he just flew at the giant new clone volk as he demonstrated the perfect acrobatic defense positions, of a ninja.
I tried to get in close enough to take some shots at the giant clone volk but I was too busy keeping the other clone volk soldiers away, breaking bones and smashing the mind control devises.
Through a series of repetitive moves, the giant cloned volk would be brought down. When the cloned monster volk lifted his whip, Grizz had to quickly climb the giant's body and flip over it. When Grizz was behind the tall soldier, he would rapidly punched it in its back with his studded brass knuckles.
